author: {'steamid': '76561199073417334', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1696956134}
review:
cute game, fun with friends.

we didn't finish the whole thing because we picked up other games, but it was still a nice experience.
it did have a few bugs here and there, especially during combat and respawn, and the repetitiveness of the quests made it a little boring at times, but we still had fun, which is the most important part anyway.

would I pick it up again to try and finish all the quests? probably not.
would I play a sequel that's maybe done just slightly better? yeah why not

overall 7/10
üåüComment 4 Commentüåü

author: {'steamid': '76561198135852719', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1705983828}
review: I wanted to like this. But less than an hour in I found it to be lacking in just about every area. The graphics are disappointing, even seemingly in comparison with the screenshots. I'm a sucker for the infinite replayability of procedural generation, and I understand its limitations, but that being said, the environments still felt bland and uninspired. Character models are ugly, movement is janky. There was very little to entice me to continue exploring beyond the first island.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107713560', 'num_games_owned': 1107, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1705762695}
review:
[h1]Ne ha viste tante[/h1]

Salt √® un gioco che √® stato tanto criticato, ora sono passati anni e quello che √® rimasto √® un gioco gradevole, che ha delle meccaniche interessanti, come la cartografia completamente in mano al giocatore, ma che ancora mostra l'enorme potenziale sprecato. 

Il prezzo √® modico e penso che sia godibile, consigliato se apprezzate il "gaming da stanco morto dopo il lavoro"

author: {'steamid': '76561197973099999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 14852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14414, 'last_played': 1705345511}
review:
Salt is primarily a game about exploration and sailing. The graphics are pretty basic but nonetheless often beautiful.

The overall feel of Salt is generally tranquil, for example when you're out sailing, fishing, or exploring. It can be a very relaxing game.

The combat is also pretty basic, except it can be challenging if you bite off more than you can chew. I personally found this aspect fun, as you can always return later with better gear if you're finding things too difficult. There is a hardcore (permadeath) mode if you're looking for even more challenge.

Another surprising aspect of Salt is the depth. Not necessarily the quests, as they are usually straightforward, but the number of items and figuring out what to do with them will keep you busy for quite some time, especially if you don't Google the answers.

Salt is basically an excellent game if you enjoy this genre, and great value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561199066869520', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 5692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5692, 'last_played': 1683561905}
review:
Salt, the cheap mans sea of thieves. This is an abandoned indie game with a short storyline, all this game will have you do is to travel from island to island and searching for loot. With no real character building or environment changing this game will test your luck in finding the right island in a infinity pool of islands to get the right enemy or loot.

3/10 - Simple, abandoned and repetitive.

review: if you can get a second person, its been one of my favorite gaming experiences. It just feels right, you don't need to look anything up but its not hand holdy either. You can talk about other things, indulge in recreational substances, or really get into it. Its never serious and doesn't need to be. Its flaws are perfect and its attention to detail is amazing. In a world of open worlds this one stands out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198422578084', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1682464081}
review: I have played this game in other accounts and had to buy it once again in this one, The game is the best piece of artwork to ever exists. I can not explain you how much fun this game gives you. The amount of emotions it gives can not and will never happen in any other game. After this i wont be able to play any other game in the same way. It is an only one way thing so before you get hooked up to this masterpiece think twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987759976', 'num_games_owned': 645, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1702163993}
review: This game looks simple and possibly even low effort on the surface, but it's not. You'll get quests from various NPCs, find pirates, treasure, build bigger boats/ships, and sail all over he place and still find new things to do. If you get it on sale for like a $1.50 like I did, it's worth every penny x10.

Tomate una tacita de cafe y prest√° atencion. Este juego es un minecraft-survival basico, no esta mal en cuanto a graficos y jugabilidad (inventario, pelea, crafteo, etc.) pero es aburrido si lo jugas sin compa√±ia y honestamente tampoco es que es muy divertido.

Es un Sandbox infinito osea que podes grindear de por vida y las islas son limitadas en tama√±o lo que complica las cosas, en Minecraft dentro de todo hay cierta continuidad territorial.

Creo que no esta tan mal pero no me termino de convencer la propuesta.

4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198042954807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1678218683}
review:
Well i am 20h+ in and this game is quickly becoming one of my favorites. Its a great exploration game with something new to discover around every corner. They don't make games like this anymore...I love that there is no map and you have to mark the islands yourself as you play. Simply brilliant.

Salt 2...I'll try it once it leaves EA...I just hope they stuck to similar gameplay as part 1 because they have something special here. We have plenty of garbage released these days...we need more games like this! 

Anyone into exploration and discovery with very little hand holding is going to love Salt. I highly recommend not looking anything up online because this game is based around learning as you go...google will ruin that experience for you. 

Its a steal at the sale price....I bought the developers other game (Wild West and Wizards) just to support them. Great job devs! I hope Salt 2 is a great success.  

Update: Currently playing theyre second game and its got me hooked as well! These devs are something special...SALT 2 is going to take over my life lol

author: {'steamid': '76561197970383595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1606664846}
review: Nicht meins. Ich stehe zwar total auf Survival Games, aber Salt ist echt nicht mein Spiel. Liegt es an der Grafik? Ich wei√ü nicht... Ich habe alles versucht, aber ich will es einfach nicht gut finden ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025816874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1673506301}
review: An interesting and odd island hopping, resource gathering, open world game.  I enjoy it thus far because I don't mind casual-ish exploring games with slow sea & land travel.  Twitch and action-oriented gamers will probably complain about vast open spaces, fetch-grinding quests, and no fps style shooting but this isn't that kind of game.  If you like a mellow, easy-going exploration adventure then you'll probably like this.  Sound is minimal because Robinson Crusoe didn't have synthpop on the isle he was deserted on either.  The waves, birds chirping, and mumbling Weeble Peeple provide an adequate background.  Graphics are kinda basic and chonky but if it were more pretty then the game would require massive resources and chug along at a crawl.  Gameplay and controls are solidly focused on discovery and exploration.  Good times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257951732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2176, 'last_played': 1710161016}
review:
I love this game, I come back to it again and again, even if I dont manage to play for long periods of time (personal not related to how good the game is). it's so open-world, but it gives you the chance to make your own story with the use of the journal. I like to mark out my days and write little notes before waiting by a campfire and come up with backstory for my character and stuff, just creating my own little world. Plus the ships are so...motivating? Like, moving up from a raft to a sailboat felt like such a HUGE upgrade, and then finally getting the last bits i needed to get a proper ship, it was just the second best ship there was, but it immediately makes so much room for personalization and you feel so accomplished!
The navigation makes me struggle a bit, but only because i'm awful at reading compasses, but i love that the mapping system is so personalized, that you can add journal entries for specific islands and mark them with symbols for what you find there (though I might wish the symbols were more concrete? that they had specific Meanings that were laid out, rather than just implied meanings? only because I tend to confuse myself with whether I use the pirate hat to mean there were pirates there, or there was a pirate captain there, or...etc).
I kind of wish that it had more varied scenery, especially with the trees? only one tree provides fruit, which makes the rest of the trees kind of useless? (though pretty)
I like playing this game when i want something relaxed and...not mind-numbing but soothing? just the sound of the waves and the occasional very loud slurp of health potions or crunch of food. (some kind of cooking ability would be cool too, since at the moment im apparently just eating raw deer meat)
A really lovely game that is absolutely work the money I paid for it!
I saw that they opened the kickstarter for salt 2 ages ago, and i'm still kind of hopeful they'll make it, but i haven't seen any further updates to the notice

author: {'steamid': '76561198193691363', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1828, 'last_played': 1670567176}
review:
Salt, how to describe this gem of a game?

The most chill sailing simulator on the planet, SOT and a lot of other sailing have nothing on this, perfect game to kick back, grab your favourite drink and snack and explore the world. Course there are the occasional bugs here and there but this is what your getting for only 2 bucks:
- Land + Sea Exploration
- Limitless Open World go wherever you want
- Complete random generation (or pre gen if you want)
- Many things to collect
- A non grindy system
- You dont have to pay anything in-game besides the 2.15 price tag
And if your not sold so far the game even has a demo which is FREE, to "try" (Last time i played the demo you basically got the entire game free.)

Now all and all Salt isnt a godsend of a game and it could have more features, which hopefully more things are added in the 2nd game. (Which is much more expensive)

Either way if your bored of all these huge titles coming out, are on a budget, drained from new horrible releases etc, I highly recommend giving Salt a go the perfect way to unwind after a big day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145808586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1142, 'last_played': 1666687469}
review:
I LOVE the idea behind the game. I had bought this ages ago and recently got back into it thinking maybe it had evolved into something worthwhile. Unfortunately, it seems the time vs update ratio isn't what I expected. Resources are few and far between for a true crafting game, and the islands are rarely of any interest. If you wait until night and go toward the lights you might find something interesting but other than that it's just hours upon hours of not a lot going on. The story line, as thin as it is, is predictably linear. One thing this game did REALLY well was the manual mapping. You aren't given any directions at all but mere coordinates (albeit rarely) and at one island you can claim rewards for how accurate your map is while having the ability of fixing mistakes for a cost. What this game could use is a levelling system, base crafting, and a deep dive into true crafting. Do I like this game? Yes. Would I recommend this game? Not unless you're incredibly bored and have hours and hours of time to spend mindlessly wandering, or it's on sale. 

Also another pet peeve; not all shops take coin but rather obscure items they purposely make you grind for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148317046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1516510306}
review:
Unfortunately after initial early access release not much has been improved or added, updates were few and far between, in fact I can't recall a single major game changing/enhancing update.
I could be wrong about there not being ANY major update but what we have is faaaarr from what was originally promised by the developers...
Salt 2 has now been released which I defiantly will not be purchasing now, the "changes" in Salt 2 could have very easily been implemented into Salt, I have watched gameplay of 2 and it mainly seems to just be a re-texture with some new minor systems, the devs are also already showing off DLC content for 2 which keep in mind is also only early access, very disappointing, I understand that as a game studio you need money however taking money from your original players only to now go and promise to create the very same thing you already promised to create before but with a fancy "2" following the name is an insult.

I love when small studios create a unique game, being apart of the early game development and watching a game grow is a lot of fun, I had that hope with this game, unfortunately as a player being apart of this step in a game's life is risky, you don't really know the devs you assume they are working in the games best interest, and I believe a lot are, including this company at one time, but after this behavior I will not be purchasing any further products from this studio, good luck with Salt 2 guys...

author: {'steamid': '76561198064254915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 14364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14364, 'last_played': 1609977035}
review:
Salt was in development for years before it's official release in 2018 and I personally had a lot of fun playing it as shown by my total playtime. It has a decent amount to it and is not intended to be a hardcore game.
      
         In regards to the relatively recent spate of negative reviews I feel I should point out that the people who claim the game was abandoned don't know what they are talking about. The devs are a small team of 3 people who listened to what people wanted during it's development and built a road map of what they were adding to the game. The game was declared finished upon completion of said road map and the devs switched their focus to their later games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175056251', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1585, 'last_played': 1685588093}
review:
Do you like games with crafting?
Searching for and extracting resources?
Finding treasure?
Sailing the seas with a map you must fill out?
Some lore and history?
Missions to send you in all directions?
Hunting? Fishing?
Exploring?
None of these things is overly complex on their own, but together they make a great experience IMO.
A little like minecraft on the sea.

Overall, I found this game very enjoyable.
The sailing while not overly complex, was both fun and relaxing.
It is one of those games that compel you to do just that one more thing. And you discover another path you can follow.
I always think there is something else to explore or maybe I should read one of the book I found for a clue to some fun adventure.
You can also play with friends. You can give them your kit. If your friends get lost and don't know where you are, they can teleport to you, should you chose to do that. 
If you are on a distant island and they are joining the game at map coordinates 0,0, they will need to do that at least once.
While there is only one save slot, if you die, it starts you at your last save spot at a safe distance.
I think the graphics are very good (the pirates being the only exception).
My only complaint is the fighting is a little meh.

They are working on a Salt 2. Hopefully they will eventually add multiplayer as an afterthought, as they did with Salt.
Either way it looks to be very much the same winning game design, with improved graphic, story and combat upgrades.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009311923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1658019141}
review:
Game starts with a huge info dump for a "tutorial" which I promptly ignored and got horribly lost. A few hours later and self-teaching myself the mechanics, I'm taking down entire camps of pirates and salvaging treasure from the ocean.

Not a very beginner friendly experience at all, but once you understand the mechanics, it's a very satisfying and fun ocean exploration game. I find sailing the sea incredibly relaxing and now I have a larger ship, it's incredibly nice to have a mobile base to return to between islands.

Got the game for about ¬£1 and well worth the price of entry. Very excited to hear the dev team are making a sequel that looks to be improving upon the foundations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007532525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1657789041}
review:
3/10 - Salt doesn't really get player attention up front and feels very unfinished.

I've been on a bit of a survival game kick lately, and when I noticed that Salt was on sale, I went ahead and bought, because it showed up on Extra Credits' "Games You Might Not Have Tried" series quite some time ago. Understand that I'm not blaming them for recommending a bad game, up front they told me that any games on the review aren't necessarily good, but they are interesting in some way - and I will grant that particular explanation.

One aspect of Salt is that you have to do your own mapping. Get a sextant, and a compass and go out into the archipelago to kill pirates for their booty and explore the world. Put islands on your map, write notes about them in a journal. In concept it is indeed interesting, but it doesn't go a lot further than that - at least, it hasn't yet as best as I can tell. 

In true form to the survival genre, Salt feels a little like a minecraft clone, but without as many immediately apparent options. Your play begins on an island in an endless archipelao - computer generated, of course - and you are alone on an island with one other guy. You pick up a few logs that are lying around, along with a pickaxe, and a few other odds and ends. The guy alone on the island with you tells you that the raft next to his camp doesn't belong to him, and that you can take it, and off we go.

You can technically craft your equipment in Salt. It just feels weird that I picked up my pickaxe randomly at the beginning of the game, and it just never wears down - as best as I can tell. I could hypothetically have this pickaxe for the rest of the game. I mean, yes, a little more realistic than minecraft's or Medieval Dynasty's setup where your pickaxe falls apart after 45 minutes of use, but where those games seem to have a direction that they're going, I can't figure out Salt, and after 3 hours of running across pirate island after pirate island, for some reason everything that I've come across feels pretty samey, and if there is a tutorial to this game, I haven't really found it yet.

This game could be a really cool and engaging game.... if it was a really cool and engaging game, which it isn't - as far as I'm concerned. There is apparently a Salt 2 in the works, which makes me think that they're just rushing out milquetoast sequels for the sake of cashgrabbing from an already milquetoast game.

I don't want to steer anyone wrong though. I've seen a few reviews with like 70+ hours on Salt, that give it the thumbs up, but right now, that's just more effort than I'm willing to give. To each their own, I'm just not very fond of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044987080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1657419970}

author: {'steamid': '76561198155623533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1657525991}
review:
2/10

Really wanted to like this game, but the reality is that it isn't much of a game at all...

Concept-wise, Salt is spectacular: sail around an infinite procedurally generated archipelago, surviving off the land and sea, fighting pirates, hunting and exploring. 

The actual game however, is just not engaging in the least.

Your sail boat simply moves forward regardless of the wind direction. You can't even adjust the direction of the sails for RP purposes.

There are "pirates" on the islands, but who exactly are they pirating from, considering that there are no other boats sailing on the ocean? Nor any towns on the islands? The average non-pirate population of the islands is 0.1, as in you find one person every 10 islands or so. And they are all male.

There's a hunger bar, but it depletes so slowly that you only need to eat once every 3 in-game days, and finding food is neither challenging nor interesting.

There's a health bar, but the enemy attacks are so weak that it's next to impossible to lose a fight so long as you are swinging your sword in the enemy's general direction. There're potions and other items to heal you, but the health bar regenerates so quickly there's no need for these items.

There's also a stamina bar, but this, when running, depletes so rapidly there's next to no point in running at all. 

None of the stat bars serve any meaningful purpose in making the game in any way enjoyable.

What exactly is Salt?

It's not a sailing game as there are no sailing mechanics.
It's not a survival game because surviving is ludicrously easy.
It's not an action game because the action is ludicrously easy.
And to be honest, it's not much of an exploration game either, as most of the islands are devoid of any interesting features.

Even a "chill game" has to engage the player in an enjoyable way. Salt just doesn't do that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014949948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 4291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1665781922}
review:
Beautiful, relaxing, with a lot of side quests and things to discover and do.

It is one of the most well designed games I have on my library.
The infinite procedural generated islands are unique, the map and journal mechanics are really remarkable, so you need to guide yourself with a compass and keep notes on a initially empty map sheet. It's fun to own boats, to play with a friend or two, to seek buried or undersea trasure.

It's a highly addicting game, so beware. It will consume all of your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035800546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1657225366}
review:
EDIT: After reading up on things I noticed the developers are working on Salt2.
With the impossibly rough and unfinished state they left this game in, I do not support or have any hope for the developers to grow, and do not think they deserve any more money than the 15$ they squeeze out of people.

Baby's first unity project.



The original review is below.
______________________________________________

It looks like a simple sailing and exploring game, something fun to play with friends!
However it is extremely rough around the edges:
-Connection with other players/host is very poor, hits on monsters barely register.
-Player names are small and hard to see, you will have a terrible time if you get split up which doesn't help as there is-
-No minimap. There is a world map but you got to fill it in yourself, which would be cool if you had any way to establish where you are. Though with how simple the game appears, I get it will throw people off who don't want to bother.
-The inventory is a mess and gets cluttered fast. There are tabs to quickly sift through your items though.
-The optimization is lacking, though it looks simple, it quickly reduces your framerate even on a decent computer.

?-When the host died, it kicked everyone off the server. Idk if this is intended but the way a multiplayer game is set up was quite awkward to begin with. You essentially join the party, then create/continue a world that has the same seed. Something that wasn't really clear and required us looking up to figure it out.

The positives are that it looks interesting, and could be something neat.
Different bosses and a bit of early game mystery with the ancient statues sounds promising!
I hope the game is/will be simple and fun, not try and be super deep and complex.

My suggestion is to hold off on it until it gets some proper TLC.
Not sure why the reviews are mostly positive, but then again the focus of this review is multiplayer.

review:
Relaxing is one way to describe it.  Overly slow and simple is another.  Sail aimlessly to an isle, find a chest, opening it says, "THREE DEER REMAIN" so sure enough, you kill the 3 deer on the island, open the chest, and you get a hat and a health potion.

... REPEAT OVER AND OVER.

Gameplay is slow and boring, crafting is slow and not exciting, combat is archaic.

Big pass here, there are too many better options.


=======================
I tried this again years later, and still even after another pass this game is just too boring and slow. I did a few islands to be sure I didn't miss anything.   I really didn't.

Pass.

review: Great game.  The graphics aren't the best, but they don't need to be.  Everything else is pretty well put together and it does a good job of fleshing out the ideas it has.  I really love the cartography aspect and I wish more games, especially procedurally generated ones, had a system that incentivises exploration so well beyond just the drive for loot (no complaints about the loot, either)

author: {'steamid': '76561198216973469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2059, 'last_played': 1650135742}
review:
Context: Paid full price for Salt after experiencing disappointing, frustrating open world solo play in Sea of Trolls (and the boring Story Campaign). I was a big fan of "Sid Meier's Pirates!"

Pro: This is the casual open ocean exploration pirate solo experience I was looking for. It's fun to hunt wildlife and clear out pirate-infested islands. The sailing is nice, immersive enough, and relaxing. Would pay full price again.

Con: I would have liked more open water content as all conflict and rewards are on land. Basic fishing bait should be easier to find. Trading would be a nice addition to the game, as I would have loved discovering procedurally generated trade routes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198968668923', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1391, 'last_played': 1649367884}

review:
It's a really fun game with a wide variety of loot offered. The combat is pretty good overall, and there's quite a bit to explore. The map is also infinite so you never run out of islands to loot. The best part about this game is by far the fact that you can build a base on your ship.

My only major complaint is that the game is still unfinished and the devs have decided to start making Salt 2 rather than finishing this one. That being said, this game is still worth the price in my opinion.

Das Konzept ist gro√üartig, nur die Ausf√ºhrung ist mies. Das Spiel k√∂nnt so viel besser sein.
Die Figuren sehen grauslich aus, vieles ist buggy, Ordnung in den Truhen halten ist der Wahnsinn- v√∂llig unausgereift. Die Gewitter waren cool, und Blitzeinschl√§ge haben es in sich!

The characters look aweful, a lot of things happen to be buggy. Keeping your stashes sorted is making you insane- totally insufficient. But Thunderstorms are nicely made and lighting really flashes in!
Thanks to wonderful guides and an very commendable wiki-page everything was achieveable after all, besides not without a great portion of luck (RNG).
Anyway i really enjoyed travelling the sea mile by mile and kept reflexively pickung up woodlogs for no reason even on the last island.

review:
It's kinda like Sea of Thieves, kinda isn't. It's more a survival/exploration kind of game than a "go out and find treasure and decorate your ship" kind of game, though that's represented too. Simple graphics, simple gameplay. Vaguely reminds me of Valheim.

I'll update this review once I've put more than an hour and a half into it. So far I don't think it's worth $15, though. Maybe $5. It's on sale for $1.49 currently (2/2/22) and that's more than reasonable, especially given that Salt 2 is planned for release this spring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089807427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 4164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1645866640}
review:
The graphics are a fun aspect of the game. A little simplistic, but effective, and do not, in any way, detract from the game play. The player characters look a bit like someone asked a Lego Minifigure to draw a Playmobil figure from memory, and someone bought the drawings from Wish...

The music is fun too, being just background incidental, and isn't overbearing like some game music can be. The game play is basically, survive. Explore, and survive. Explore, survive,  and have fun doing it!

Talk to those who will talk to you, kill those who attack you. find and loot all the crates, chests and boxes you can. Pick up all the resources you find. find or make tools, clothing, weapons, etc. Build a tiny raft. Build a small ship. Later, build a big ship, or a huge ship. Explore more islands. The map is an interesting concept. You start with a blank piece of parchment, and you have to create the map yourself. if you visit an island, it doesn't get marked on the map, this is a piece of parchment. You must mark your map with the island, and add map markers to show what or who you found there.

It is best played with friends, but is fun alone too.

It is client hosted on a peer to peer basis. One player hosts, and invites friends to join from within the game, but they must have Salt running to be invited.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996379595', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1545486352}

Allein in meinem Freundeskreis hei√üt es auch bei Fehlk√§ufen st√§ndig "Ach die 30 Euro..." anstatt einfach mit 4 Klicks eine R√ºckerstattung von Steam anzufordern. AUch hier wieder im Freundeskreis zig Beispiele. Hier werden Vorb4estellungen gemacht zu games, die nur angeteasert sind, man sieht ncihtmal Gameplay. WTF. Biomutant war da ein perfektes Beispiel. Haben sich einige Leute geholt nach dem Teaser von vor Jahren. Als es dann rauskam haben die sich gewundert. Gespielt eine Stunde und gemerkt wie doof das ist. F√ºr das Game hier hab ich nat√ºrlich gleich eine R√ºckerstattung beantragt und das sollte jeder tun, macht aber kaum jemand, das Geld bleibt beim Entwickler, der wahrscheinlich Tr√§nen lacht √ºber die Dummheit der K√§ufer und sch√∂n l√§ngst das Firmenlogo von der Tafel gewischt hat und ein neues draufgeschrieben hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008712099', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1436514363}
review:
You should honestly just buy game pass and play Sea of Thieves if you're looking for a sailing/pirate sim to play with friends. 

This game has been practically a heap of buggy mess since its released 5 years ago. I have never played it for more than an hour at a time as it's a very boring game and there's really not a lot to do other than tend to your boat and go find more empty islands with roblox-like characters. 

This may be someone's preferred type of game, but there are many other sailing/pirate sims out there that run better and look better. This isn't a knock on the devs who made this, but it's just a very boring game overall, and I feel they limited themselves with an engine that seems like it belongs on a Windows 98 machine. The performance is surprisingly not that great either considering it's mostly voxel and poor quality 3d.

The one positive that this game has over something like Sea of Thieves is the ability to build a base since it's more of a survival game than purely exploration. Not sure if people would compare these two game together, but SoT is just a lot more fun and rewarding.

At least they're working on a SALT 2.

The game seems like a beta version with placeholder graphics. Sailing around is fun for a while, but there are only a few different types of islands that all start to look the same. Twenty years ago, this would have been great, but it just isn't very impressive. 

For a few bucks, it could be fun for a bit, but it just feels like it is missing a lot of polish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037427689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1658206404}
review:
I played this game for only a few hours at least a year ago and I can't say I've ever come back. It's a really interesting open-world-pirate-sandbox-no-pun-intended-treasure-hunting-crafting game and I did enjoy the initial few hours.  However, this game falls flat in the long-run as is the case with these types of open-world sandbox games. There's another reason why I'm writing this review, however. Stay tuned, folks!

It starts off good. You learn to collect resources, you learn to craft items, find treasure, do quests, etc. That's maybe 2 or 3 hours in. Then, you learn that you have to travel for several minutes from island to island to make real progress. You do so in a boat, of course. You can put stuff on your boat (e.g. torches, chests, etc.) so there is a little bit of customisation, to an extent. The crafting is very mundane, unfortunately, and there's not a vast array of items to craft to where it gets complicated. I suppose the point of the game is to go around doing quests and finding treasure. Do as pirate does. 

My issue with the crafting and quests is that it is very shallow. It consists of "collect # of item" or "go to location, find item, return". There was only a few unique quests I found but they weren't too interesting, and a lot of them were at locations with higher-tier enemies, so a lot of my time playing was spent going around islands trying to find loot. You can't craft a lot that ultimately advances you forwards, and a lot of the loot and quest rewards aren't particularly significant. In fact, a lot of the better loot I had found is gained through grinding quests to get the unique quest tokens(or whatchamacallits) that you can exchange for items. So, to "advance" through the tiers of equipment you need to grind A LOT. It adds to the very simple feeling of the game but grinding never ends up being fun or good. This game has nothing to supplement the grinding itself.

The game itself feels very incomplete. The world is empty, there's little in terms of NPCs, civilization of any kind, and any significant landmarks of any kind. It feels like they left this game as "good enough" and moved on, which is very disappointing. There's surely more they could have added, such as cities (port royal was a real place, y'know), maybe big challenges / temples / forts to explore? Maybe ruins to explore? There's just so much missing and yet I do see one positive. I consider games like these "podcast games" or in other words, a great game to put something in the background and play this game as "filler" because who wants to stare at a computer screen for 2 straight hours listening to words?

So why am I *really* making this review? I just today(Dec 2nd 2021) have noticed that back in March of the same year, they have started a kickstarter for, get this, Salt 2. I'm beyond disappointed. Why not just update the original game? It's an exceptionally bad sign when a developer creates another game with the same name as the previous game but + 1. Presumably not much will even change and it will be the same idea and same execution. I will not be buying it. I got Salt 1 for a discounted price and I will only be getting Salt 2 if it's free because it's not worth buying the same game twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561199217624222', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1639153271}
review: Pretty fun and explorative game that gives a vast amount of replayability. The graphics give me a euphoric feeling as its simple design reminds me of games from the early years. The game is vast and leads you to find new things constantly. I will say that the introduction is very short, it doesn't really teach ypu the controls and it's pretty open ended on quests and such but none the less a great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052351172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 74374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74374, 'last_played': 1508980115}
review:
I loved this game a lot. Its peaceful on the water and can be a challenge on the land. I spent a lot of time watching the game grow. I bought it early and played every few weeks. For a while there i was able to get my jungle skivvy up to like 175 knots using a glitch.  I even helped out on the wiki a bit which I've never done for another game. 

Its simple, but its beautiful. Salt is like good mac and cheese or a warm chocolate chip cookie. The recipes themselves are not complicated, but if you assemble the right ingredients in the right way, it can be better than a 7 course meal. I used to play other more challenging or competitive games, but i would play this game to unwind. I don't play it much anymore, but I'm certain that other people would love this game as much as i obviously did.  I love this game a lot and so excited for 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156081468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7326, 'last_played': 1632553428}
review: Overall positive reaction. Biggest draw for this game is ambiance/environment. Sailing is great, colors and use of light is beautiful. Player movement is alright, if maybe a little clunky. But usable for sure. Lots of different items and adventures, a quest book as well as editable journal, and a map where you can place islands you've visited. Fight mechanics are a bit lacking, but at least killing isn't bloody, it's a bit cartoonish and it works with the overall feeling. Relax, sail, or go fight things in the dark of night and maybe survive. Find NPCs and get quests and loot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198962578053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1629085386}
review:
Overall its a solid game. 

Pros
-A decently done open world concept
-Sailing around on semi-crafted vessels
-Crafting options
-Missions within the game
-Difficult enough to not become monotonous too early

Cons
-Not a distinct enough world
-Not enough crafting with vessels
-Navigation could be done far better
-More interaction in the world needed.

I'll be looking forward to Salt 2!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013462546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1662386737}
review:
PIRATES THAT ARE AFRAID OF THE WATER,   "WHAT"! 2022 UPDATE:
Their are 3 things i like to see improved on map and markers that leave a good way to follow them and the things posted below.   
It's more of a Great first time game build and combat effort on what could be a well done game sold that way for the developers of this game! In Recommended as such for a low price not sure at this point for it could of had a lot better characterization an interaction to a lot of things.  
What makes this game good is the fact that is all works well enough and having a lot of Exploration and a lot of cool rear items but what keeps this game down is a few things yet it still works and can be fun for at the point of 14 hours of game play i found some interesting things and the huge ship you repair and get later is cool.   NOW WE COME TO THE CON'S IN THIS GAME!
Pirates that fear water and will not enter it using this is great in all for beginners  do to the enemy hits can do a huge amount of damage but it seems more of a quick fix to the balancing issue that just could of given a few more items as your seeking and exploring.  Yet it maybe just bad luck finding them on the very first island.  Items and flowers can make healing yet the issue is the enemy speed seems a bit over the top due to later as you go your armor and such helps a lot so this maybe a fix but not really.  Also pirates that will not go on a ship to have combat is some what unrealistic and maybe done for like they said exploration but it would not of hurt them to just have a few situations of combat to keep the feel of it real.  I hope they do improve a bit on the second game SALT 2 and what i see it looks that way.   In all this game is worth 5 or more bucks at the point i played it and was fun but interaction to objects found seem a bit off in characters and objects yet play out okay as you go.  Over all i like the game exploration style a lot and some of the island hidden quest of object that i have not yet figured out what or how to interact with. Its a great game in all but again not really a top of the game in looks or finished in some aspects but worth what i paid for it on sale!

I'd really love to see the first game finished FIRST, it's got some good potential but I'd hate to see it abandoned like a lot of other simple graphic games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006293953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6417, 'last_played': 1628239943}
review:
Love this game. 

It is kind of a survival game, cause you have to manage your "food-meter", but its usually no stress, the bar does not deplete quickly, and there is tons of food to find. It is part RPG, cause you can build your character with tons of different gear, that boost your stats, armor etc. At the same time you cannot alter your characters stats without items, and there is no lvl system. 

The graphics are nice, there is a lot of content, lots to do. 
I have played for more than 100 hours on the same save, and there is still a lot for me to do, even tho I've finished the main story. 

The main story didn't really catch my eye, can't even remember what it was about. But I don't really mind, the experience is still worth it by far. 

This is a game where you can grind forever. Fishing, killing for equipment, searching for treasure out at sea, looking for song sheets etc. It just never stops. I have never really enjoyed grinding in games, but in Salt I find it relaxing and chill. The soundtrack is nice, the graphics and sounds beautiful. 

This game was made by a small studio by a few people, and I think what they've made is very good. They made the best they could with what they had, and it shows. There are of course things that could have been a little bit better, but overall its good. 

I thoroughly enjoy this game, and I recommend it if you like these kinds of games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094229978', 'num_games_owned': 818, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1659529856}
review:
Minimalist, yet fantastic game about exploration and discovery.
This game had a small budget, so I don't blame it for the design choices, such as the simplistic visuals and control scheme, but it works and it works really well.

Salt is one of the best pirate games you can buy, it focuses on all aspects of a pirates life, the looting, the fighting, the sailing, but also the occasional trading ventures to make extra money. Salt isn't about bombastic and dramatic pirates, it's about a real and believable world that can immerse you despite the graphics.

Salt is about your story, not about loot or pvp dominance, just your journey from castaway to pirate billionaire.

author: {'steamid': '76561199062224891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1617559318}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003019731', 'num_games_owned': 1879, 'num_reviews': 368, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1626021712}
review:
Di√°rio de bordo, 28E, 18S:

"Frustrado com minhas experi√™ncias em Risen 2, lembrei de outro jogo que tinha em meu acervo com tem√°tica pirata, mas um vasto mundo aberto para ser explorado em busca de tesouros. N√£o, n√£o era Sea of Thieves. Era Salt, um infinitamente mais modesto t√≠tulo independente que eu havia testado em uma vers√£o demo, no agora distante ano de 2015.

Por fora, Salt √© um daqueles jogos de sobreviv√™ncia em que voc√™ precisa coletar recursos, construir coisas, tomar cuidado para n√£o morrer por causa de necessidades b√°sicas ou inimigos aterrorizantes. Na pr√°tica, ele est√° muito mais pr√≥ximo da vibe de Minecraft: um t√≠tulo para ser apreciado sem stress, no seu ritmo, sem grandes amea√ßas. N√£o por acaso, a trilha sonora principal de Salt √© o barulho das ondas e das gaivotas, intercortada em alguns raros momentos com uma m√∫sica suave e sutil que lembra muito o que a Mojang atingiu com seu t√≠tulo. √Äs vezes, a m√∫sica sobe para batalhas ou para trazer um clima √©pico no mar profundo, interven√ß√µes que contribuem para pontuar esses momentos, mas que n√£o chegam a subir a adrenalina.

A grande verdade √© que Salt √© um jogo que traz paz e n√£o assombro. Esse horizonte √© evidenciado tamb√©m em suas cores vibrantes, como se um Sol tropical beijasse o solo com graciosidade. Quase d√° para sentir a pele bronzeando. Em Salt, o verde √© mais verde, o azul √© mais azul, o mar √© mais mar do que em muitos jogos. Com rever√™ncia e um leve temor, jogamos nossa jangada nas ondas e manobramos o barco em busca da ilha seguinte. Mesmo quando se obt√©m uma caravela pirata, n√£o √© poss√≠vel se sentir conquistando o oceano, apenas obtendo um pouco mais de conforto e seguran√ßa em meio √† vastid√£o oce√¢nica. Somos convidados dessa beleza, nunca seus mestres.

Mecanicamente, por√©m, Salt est√° bem distante de Minecraft ou da maioria dos jogos de seu nicho. O jogo n√£o nos oferece a possibilidade de se erguer constru√ß√µes de qualquer tipo. Somos n√¥mades, explorando um mar que n√£o tem fim, com ilhas geradas proceduralmente. No m√°ximo, √© poss√≠vel construir ou melhorar barcos, mas nada que possa ser comparado √† complexidade de um Raft. O resto dos elementos fabric√°veis s√£o apetrechos que carregamos, vestimentas ou alimentos. O foco de Salt est√° mesmo na explora√ß√£o, no girar dos dados de cada ilha, que pode conter surpresas ou recursos necess√°rios para seguir viagem.

O combate, quando existe, √© simples e pouco desafiador. Isso pode frustrar alguns jogadores, mas acredito que seja mais uma vela que impulsiona uma experi√™ncia que se deseja explorat√≥ria. A noite pode trazer inimigos que d√£o sustos, mas tamb√©m pode ser facilmente evitada com uma boa fogueira. N√£o h√° lutas obrigat√≥rias ou que n√£o possam ser evitadas correndo. Se uma ilha est√° perigosa demais (?), sempre √© poss√≠vel navegar at√© a pr√≥xima.

Sem me dar conta, completei doze horas nesse universo, sem chegar a lugar algum. At√© porque Salt √© um t√≠tulo t√£o infinito quanto seu mapa. H√° inimigos gradualmente mais fortes, mas tamb√©m h√° equipamentos gradualmente mais fortes. Com paci√™ncia e sorte, voc√™ pode encontrar miss√µes e correr atr√°s desses objetivos, um norte mais n√≠tido do que havia em Minecraft ou na maioria dos t√≠tulos de sobreviv√™ncia, entretanto, na maior parte do tempo, voc√™ estar√° apenas deixando se levar, como uma onda no mar. Depois da primeira dezena de horas, h√° coisas que n√£o vi, mas tamb√©m houve muitas coisas que vi muitas vezes, o que acaba cansando.

Atingida minha zona de conforto, com um gale√£o pr√≥prio, bem iluminado, com cama, equipamento satisfat√≥rio e nenhuma morte nessas doze horas, fiquei tentando imaginar o que poderia estar na pr√≥xima ilha que justificaria minha perman√™ncia em Salt. N√£o me arrependo de nenhum minuto gasto sob esse Sol causticante, por√©m n√£o encontrei motivos para perseguir esse horizonte.

Deixo por aqui essa aventura e esse pergaminho, a ser encontrado por novos aventureiros."

Comandante Aquino

author: {'steamid': '76561197996018628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1624938758}
review: A fun, casual little game in Unity. Like Minecraft mixed with a bit of Wind Waker. Pretty straight forward; sail the sea, gather resources, craft things, and survive. It's pretty low stakes, you won't get stressed out about finding food or shelter, the penalty for death is pretty low. There is some depth to be found; quests, the cycles of the tides, and charting your own map. I found it relaxing. It's a really chill experience all around, mostly exploration for it's own sake.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009434744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1622969690}
review:
Hmmmm....hard to recommend unless you buy it at a huge discount like I did. Truth is there are better similar games out there. The Raft and Valheim are two examples. To be honest they are both similar to aspects of this game, but they are both better. Valheim will scratch your build a boat and sail around procedurally generated islands much more than this, and the Raft has more interesting things to do from the start, with much better progression. So I would recommend either of them over this one. 

However, if like me you have played lots of the Raft and Valheim, and like a simple gameplay loop for relaxation, then this could be the very thing. That is why I am recommending it instead of rejecting it, but only if you can get it cheap and have low expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067357199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1622571128}
review:
I'm not mad, I'm just disappointed. 

I've played this game for a solid 16 hours. 16 hours of finding nearly nothing of note. I had to stop myself after all this time and ask "Am I having fun?" And the answer was a resounding no. 

I'm not having fun navigating a massive map to reach an island exactly like the last four islands but maybe this one has a pirate on it trying to kill me. 

I'm not having fun when nearly everything you find is better than anything you can craft. 

I'm not having fun when I find an island, the size of four islands put together, and have to hunt down 18 pirates all to win a pair of boots I already have 4 copies of and some hardwood logs. 

I'm not having fun chasing a deer down in the dead of night because I'm out of flint and can't fast forward in game clock- for that matter, I'm not having fun chasing down an endless array of deer that will run to the opposite side of the island at the slightest provocation.

I'm not having fun when fishing nets me mouthed basses from small, medium, huge, and gigantic and I literally just need "large" to finish a quest

I'm not having fun squinting at bamboo and having to check the wiki to understand why even though it's right there I can't harvest any 

16 hour play time and I struggle to find where the fun is meant to begin. 
And if the game isn't fun, what else is it bringing to the table? From my experience, not a whole lot.

And with all that said, after all this time, checking the sale page and finding that this boring slog of a game has a sequel in kickstarter before the first game is worth playing? Well, I would suggest you don't waste your money on either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972921791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 23595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22271, 'last_played': 1622511148}
review:
It's a very finished game. The low IQ trolls posting negative reviews with little game play should stick to Animal Crossing. I've played the early versions and the finished version more than once. Multiplayer was added after the game was finished and that added more fun to an already good game. It's all about exploration, quests, collecting with some boss battles scattered around the map. I find it a very relaxing game and enjoy filling out map and collecting achievements.

Pros:
Fight pirates
Collect loot
Build or buy ships
Nice progressive map system

Cons:
Simple combat - slash and block mostly

review: Most of the reviews im seeing are from people who haven't really played this game. The problem with them is it takes time to get to more content, and yeah it may take a while, but you also have to look for it. There's Lore, There's stuff to do. The dev roadmap got completed. The game is finished. everything that was supposed to be in the game was added. there were a bit of limitations with the engine this game was built on. I think that salt 2 should definitely get made, and I hope they take advantage of more current engines.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996464882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1476660749}
review: THIS GAME IS DEAD!!! It is an Early Access Alpha, never finished, never balanced. I can only warn to buy this game, even for 1 buck. I often buy Early Access Games, because some have good and "out of the box" ideas, like this game. But to leave a Game unfinished, with poor Graphics, poor fun and in the same moment begging for support for Salt II, this is a slap in the face of every person who want to support Indie developers or a good idea!!! You can have fun with this game for a few hours, this is undisputed. But if you want to have cheap fun, without to pay much, search for Abandonware or a free Indie Game, those are far more developed and you have longer fun

author: {'steamid': '76561197961167439', 'num_games_owned': 1579, 'num_reviews': 720, 'playtime_forever': 2871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2871, 'last_played': 1611208051}
review: Surprisingly good minimalistic sea exploration game. Plenty of islands to explore and quest to do. Game gets progressively more difficult and even throws in some boss fights. Sailing across the sea can be very relaxing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984425808', 'num_games_owned': 1205, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1517950142}
review: Released the game early because he didn't want to make it anymore and now is asking for Kickstarter money to make Salt 2.  You didn't even finish the first game, what a dick move.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216970284', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 6393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2204, 'last_played': 1700159705}
review: Hard but fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198372742500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2871, 'last_played': 1643850897}
review:
Every time I played I found the adventure and challenges got bigger and each achievement I made, made me want to play more.  I'm really looking forward to Salt 2 when it arrives.

- The journal is a nice touch, which is found with the tab key.
- Thumbs up, a terrific relaxing game, cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198974396158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1630553599}
review: had to turn down my grass settings to see any floor loot. but after that its been "smooth sailing", exploration feels exciting and i love the feel of the world. sailing for the first time is truly exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129846727', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1643586149}
review:
A flawed but fun-for-the-right-person gem.
It's not immediately clear but there is an "end" to this game, with a final boss and such that I haven't yet reached.
But there's a demo, man, just try it out for yourself. Very chilled.

Genuinely looking forward to the sequel. More refined version of this with more content and graphics that don't look like a 2012 Unity game? Sign me up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153732172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 27271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25281, 'last_played': 1708668486}
review:
Hit 420 hours of gameplay on the eve of 4-20-2020! 
Had to. Anyway, this game is rad as can be. It's simple. not to hard to create some gameplay tactics to survive and enjoy the adventure. Not as bad of a learning curve as some games, highly recommend for any casual players looking for some exploration and minor crafting. Also, this game has some rad lore and I hope they build upon this in Salt 2 :D Which is coming. Salt 2 is coming erryone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052631357', 'num_games_owned': 1268, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1190, 'last_played': 1617463754}
review:
Was ist Salt?
Ihr erwacht auf einer unbekannten Insel (ich glaube bei der aktuellen Version seid ihr dort nicht mehr alleine)
Ihr habt eine komplett leere Karte und sonst nichts. Um euch herum andere Inseln und jede menge Wasser.
Was tut man also? Man versucht andere Inseln zu erkunden und im Prinzip ist dies auch schon alles was ihr in diesem Spiel macht.
Hinzu kommen ein paar tolle Mechaniken die das ganze abhebt von anderen Open-World-Erkundungsspielen.
Vorab, das Spiel f√ºhlt sich extrem unfertig an und wird auch nicht weiter Entwickelt. 
Salt2 steht schon in den Startl√∂chern.

Ihr sucht euch Material zusammen, baut ein Boot und erkundet die Welt.
Die Map f√ºllt sich aber nicht von alleine! Alles was ihr auf eurer Map stehen haben wollt, m√ºsst ihr selbst dort eintragen. Dabei k√∂nnt ihr Orte mit Symbolen, oder sogar mit einem Info-Text markieren.
Auf eurer Reise findet ihr ein paar interessante Quest-NPC's, H√§ndler, jede menge Piraten und noch ein paar andere Bewohner, wir wollen ja mal nicht zuviel Spoilern ;) 
Ihr k√∂nnt gro√üe Schiffe bauen/kaufen/finden und stetig eure Ausr√ºstung, sowie Schiffe ausbessern.
Die Quests erledigen sich eher durch Zufall, meist wisst ihr nicht wo sich euer Ziel befindet und stolpert nach mehreren Stunden erkunden zuf√§llig dar√ºber. Macht euch also nicht verr√ºckt, wenn ihr bei euren Quests nicht weiter kommt.

Das ganze l√§sst sich inzwischen wohl auch im Co-Op zocken, was ich noch nicht ausprobiert habe, aber demn√§chst werde.

Aktuell kostet das Spiel im Angebot 1,49‚Ç¨ und damit Empfehle ich absolut JEDEM sich das Game einmal anzuschauen.

Der Normalpreis von 14,99 ist meiner Meinung nach nicht mal √ºberzogen, kann man √ºber die unfertigen Elemente hinwegsehen.

Grafik: 6/10
Gameplay: 6,5/10
Freiheit: 10/10
Story: 5/10
Spieldauer: 10/10
P/L: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198148676717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 541, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1639159008}
review:
3 above average
2 average
1 below average

loot 2
crafting 2 and 1/2
combat 2
replayability 1
game mechanics 2 and 1/2
customization 1
story 1
visuals 1 and 1/2 

fun. for a while
hours of play. endless, if you can stand endless boredom
bugs or lag. None found


It's a beautiful cell-shade paradise with great game mechanics, zero character customization, and limited content. At least at the start. The two quests I found were pretty lame: find a pick axe, find a missing treasure so you can get these pantaloons to give to some wacko sailor. 

Your avatar is a near-featureless blob that looks like a mini-staypuff. There are no stats. No builds. The first person view has no hand to hold your weapon. 

Though the islands are plentiful and the raft easy to place in the water, there is little to see. There are plenty of trees and stones everywhere, but the trees can't be chopped, and you don't have a pick axe until you do that quest. There is some variety in what is found on an island. I found pirates on one island, a hunting stand on another. Found no wild life other than birds and deer. There may be other animal types on other islands. I have no intentions to find out. 

the water environment is under-utilized. No fishing that i could see. No ship to ship combat. At least not at the start. No water treasures or sunken ships. Maybe all of this exists in other parts of the game world. Maybe they will be added later. 



Conclusion

man, that store page shows some real great stuff. It may be worth sinking a few hours into the game to get to all that great stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167726391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1643516340}
review:
Un jeu qui donne toute sa dimension √† l'exploration. Au d√©but, on se sent un peu comme dans Ylands, retourn√© √† l'√¢ge de pierre et plus ou moins contraint de prendre la mer en investissant la plus grosse partie de ses ressources dans un radeau peu pratique (mais n√©anmoins suffisant). Apr√®s avoir collect√© ce qu'il faut pour un sailboat et r√©gl√© les probl√®mes de nourriture, on prend vite go√ªt √† se d√©placer d'√Æle en √Æle en se demandant ce que la prochaine cache. Du gibier ? C'est l'heure d'aff√ªter ses fl√®ches et de refaire le plein de viande. Des pirates ? C'est le moment de se battre et de s'enrichir. Et toujours plus de ressources, qui repopent p√©riodiquement (tout comme les ennemis, le gibier, les qu√™tes et les tr√©sors). C'est donc sans fin, pour l'amateur du genre...

Et l√† intervient LE truc qui permet de ne pas tourner en rond en terrain connu : la carte. C'est l'occasion pour que j'explique √† Casstoidla ce que j'en ai compris. La carte est un immense quadrillage vierge sur lequel il faudra dessiner soi-m√™me ce qu'on apprend au fur et √† mesure. Pour cela, deux outils compl√©mentaires. Le sextant permet de donne les coordonn√©es de la position actuelle (au-dessus de la barre d'outils), on peut alors la reporter sur la carte. Si on se trouve sur une √Æle, un clic gauche suffit √† placer une √Æle aux coordonn√©es d√©sign√©es. A droite, plusieurs ic√¥nes permettent de d√©terminer en quoi la position est int√©ressante (marchand, bateau, monument, ruines, etc.). La boussole permet quant √† elle de d√©terminer l'azimut pour se rendre d'un point √† un autre, m√™me si le sextant pourrait √† lui seul permettre de se rep√©rer par localisations successives. A propos d'orientation, une info int√©ressante : dans le jeu, le soleil se l√®ve bien plein est et se couche plein ouest. Utile pour attendre la boussole...

Compte tenu de l'immensit√© de la map, je pense qu'il peut vite devenir r√©barbatif de tout cartographier, mais signaler ses trouvailles me semble indispensable. On pourra √©galement regretter de ne pas pouvoir construire un home sweet home (du moins, dans les premiers temps de la partie). Peut-√™tre un manque, moins √©vident quand on √©lit domicile sur un bateau.

Fans d'open world et de libert√©, ce jeu est fait pour vous !

author: {'steamid': '76561198065228351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1279, 'last_played': 1559842656}
review:
I have to say, if there was a posterchild for why steam early acess has such a bad rap, this devloper would be a classic example.   It's not because they don't have a bad game or that they don't care about it, it's that they still have the nerve to charge full price for something they have no intention of finishing, instead of just sticking with it, they offer to make "Salt 2: Devlopment Hell Electric Boogloo"   

The real tragedy is that the developers are great people, and very limited, but because steam has very few long term support tools other then "Make a DLC, etc"  they have to make a decision like this if they need money, and basically tank any respect the community has  for them.   I understand it's as much an issue with the platform as the developers, but then again many developers just plod along and stick with something, or reduce their price, rebuild it, get more outside support if they need it, document and broadcast their progress, then pull the price back up once they have a solid product.  There are a lot of examples of this.  No Man's Sky, Ark: Survival Evolved, and quite a number of others.   It's a question of brand image, honesty and community trust.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014004266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1539306846}
review:
It started out as a really good idea and then after a short while, it stopped being fun after the updates stopped.

Seems the devs ran out of money as Arsat said in his review, now they are asking for more money for the second iteration of the Title, what a sham.

This is why Early Access is so risky, will they fulfil their side of the bargain, or will they just stop working on it for two years and then start "Salt 2" without finishing the first one. Its bare bones at best, sorry its just not up to scratch even for EA.

Buy this, or the second one theyre making at present, at your own peril. It will probably go the way of the dodo too...

PS. No idea why my time says 2 hours, ive played ages on this title?

author: {'steamid': '76561198042026617', 'num_games_owned': 737, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 3208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3207, 'last_played': 1614901645}
review:
There are things I DO like about it, BUT...

It's also riddled with bugs, QoL problems, and other such glaring issues the devs are too lazy to fix. That they continue to sell a subpar product with so many problems kinda speaks to their character.

And these aren't just your normal design flaws. I tried to boot the game up just tosay to revisit it after 3 years, and found myself plagued with a strange issue where I couldn't select text boxes and my character spun in circles. A trip to the Steam forums confirms this is a gamepad issue that even unplugging my gamepad did not fix. The game is basically unplayable for me now, and the fact this is a KNOWN BUG where the ONLY fix is to UNPLUG YOUR GAMEPAD is asinine. Imagine having to unplug your gamepad to get a game to work.

If you can get past those issues - and I haven't yet - you do have to deal with a game that has a lot of neat ideas which feel mostly under-utilized. It really is half a game. I LIKE the things that are there, I like the way island mapping works, I like sailing around looking for loot, but things like fishing are incredibly shallow and it really feels like an early access game the devs threw up their hands on and just quit one day.

There really is nothing else like it. Its closest contemporaries are games like Sea of Thieves which are grief-heavy MMOs, so the only way I'd recommend it to someone is if they really just want a pirate game that is designed as a "completable" solo experience. Unfortunately, this is the best we have for that, and the second something better comes along, I'd jump ship for it immediately.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972355522', 'num_games_owned': 1811, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 1617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1617, 'last_played': 1550116002}
review:
Salt is a stunning accomplishment for a two-person team; a laid back, Caribbean Pirate themed explore-survive-craft fest, complete with tons of quests, sailing, fishing, and a lovely soundtrack. When Joanna & I started doing regular co-op gaming, Salt was the game we started with; and while she was eventually ready to move on to other things, I never tired of it.

Its ambitions frequently run up against its budget and the relative inexperience of its designers. Combat is an extremely basic (very much Minecraft style); enemy variety is minimal; and various bits of the game are undeveloped, pointing to features that the developers ultimately didn‚Äôt have time for (for instance, you can get cannons to equip on your ship & cannonballs to fire, but there is no ship combat in the game). As a full-fledged Pirate Skyrim, it falls short, and it lacks the creative construction elements of most Minecraftbuts, but as a sunny place to sail around, it‚Äôs second to none.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963885058', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1639011101}
review:
I've owned the game for some time, got it cheap with a coupon and... I didn't mind it, felt very inspired by the Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker with simplified combat and crafting.  But I couldn't get into it.

Then I bought copies for my friends during the last Winter sale.  When we sit down to play, despite a few bugs and hiccups, we'll play for hours.

Enjoyed Wind Waker?  Want a fun survival game where you play a good-natured sailor, hunting pirates and treasure?   Maybe you just want to jump on a raft, or craft a bigger boat, or even a majestic ship and just travel the seas while enjoying some wonderful, and sometimes haunting, music?  Then this is your game.

It can go on VERY cheap too, so don't let the price tag scare you off of this amazing indie game.  It's well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042092950', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1494, 'last_played': 1610828369}
review:
Underneath the bad graphics is a great sea exploration game.  There's something charmingly fun about mapping the world out yourself, with sometimes vague quest hints.  It's very reminiscent of the Morrowind era of gaming.

I do wish combat was more involved and there was a bit more to do on the sea itself (both underwater and something like ship-to-ship battles) but that might be addressed in the coming sequel.  I still have more fun in this game than Sea of Thieves, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198331876293', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1609598584}
review:
My fist "open world survival craft" game. Didn't have any expectation when i bought it. But so far i have a good time with this game.

The exploration and adventure part is very fun and obviously the selling points of the game. The combat isn't satisfying but it does its job well. The story is just there. I think the graphics supposed to be charming and artful, but it also quite ugly to be honest. 

The world is huge, but not always in a good way. It's pretty confusing because as i said earlier that exploration in this game is fun, so the map should be good because of that, right? BUT, the world is so empty making it boring when you sail from one island to another island, and also not every islands are interesting. if the map is like 50% smaller, this game would be more fun and less tedious. And most importantly, the fun of exploring in this game will stand out even more.

Don't know how good this game compared to other similar games like The Forest and ARK though, probably this game is far inferior by a large margin. But hey, it's a VERY cheap game. If this game looks interesting to you, and because of the price alone, might as well just give it a try.

Also, just found out that the developer made a similar game but with a wild west settings. Pretty tempted to try it. And they also currently working on the Salt 2, that's cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999542503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 21737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14992, 'last_played': 1630722755}
review:
An awesome game overall! Simplistic graphics with a more than awesome music! Some clever mechanics such as knowing when there is not much sound or stuff happening on screen and this amazing music starts playing out of the blue!
Sure the battles are rudimentary, basic and with not much variety but the whole story is intriguing and it makes you keep pushing to find out more and visit one more island.
If I had to describe the game I would say it is 60% a relaxing simulator and 40% game. You can spend endless hours walking around an island or simply sailing and watching those amazing sunsets with no obligation to do nothing else at all!
I heard that there is already work on Salt 2.0 and I can't wait to see it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029508562', 'num_games_owned': 2560, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1608697922}
review:
Sailing and walking around deserted islands with no particular aim is peaceful, especially with Salt's soothing soundtrack. The lighting (along with the Sun, Moon and stars) helped set the mood too. The game did that well. 

Having said that, actually doing anything (like gathering materials, looking for treasure, crafting, fishing, combat and looting) felt shallow, with little sense of reward, wonder, joy or meaning for making discoveries. It didn't help that Salt makes gathering materials a hidden objects game, requiring the player to carefully look at every inch of the screen to spot materials that may be camouflaged in the ambient. 

There is some enjoyment to be had, but overall the core gameplay flaws outweigh the qualities.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084556418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2081, 'last_played': 1605133845}
review:
I do like and recommend the game but it's not for everyone's taste.

The game is mostly about going from island to island, killing pirates and gathering wood and ores.

There's a few boats to craft but repairing an old pirate ship is the most simple and easy way to get your first floating base and it'll serve you well enough. It's not the fastest but honestly you don't really need to bother with building better boats because they're just a mean to an end (that is going from an island to another) and have no other utility. The Maidens are very nice looking vessels but the pirate ship already offers you more than enough space to place your bed and your chests.

There's no big objective to accomplish or story to follow since it's just a sandbox type of game and what you can do is pretty repetitive. Same thing with the islands; there's thousads of them to explore but it's always the same things you see and after playing a few hours, you have seen everything (except the jungle biome but since its vegetation density is the same as everywhere else, it doesn't feel different) so like I said at the beginning, you either like or dislike that kind of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062339996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4667, 'last_played': 1591423570}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086287250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 33681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30889, 'last_played': 1605990102}
review: FREEDOM! Explore, discover, craft a raft and set your sights on one island after another. Hone your skills at fighting, pirates are land-locked for some strange reason, kill em loot em, steal their booty, use their weapons against them, trade and improve your armor, weapons, and of course ship(s), join minor factions to improve trade even fishing skills.... the choices are yours! Vibrant and alive graphics with many many many islands to explore. Fight your way to ultimate pirate kingdom - common pirate crew, harder scavenger, navigator, and captain, battlemasters, and brutes - ultimately defeating four pirate kings.... FREEDOM to choose your own path - addicting and fun answering to no one but a bigger and badder blade and of course the forces of nature!
