author: {'steamid': '76561197987505629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1600472037}
review:
This game is pretty fun but gets repetitive quickly. Sail to an island, fight some pirates, buy/sell some stuff, repeat. There seems to be more to the game than that, but it's hard to want to even figure that out when it started to feel tedious like 3 hours in.

I tend to dislike games that make you spend a lot of time managing your inventory, and this game is pretty bad about that. You're constantly picking up loot that includes:
 - Maps (of which you get a lot of duplicates, but it takes a bit of work to find out it's a duplicate), 
 - and of course gear that's like every MMO, where this has +1 to that stat, but your current gear has +1 to this stat, and if I get the set I have +5 to that stat....this shit is not fun when the reason you're trying to min/max is to do better in combat which is extremely basic, awkward, and slow
 - Tons of miscellaneous items like fragments of things, coins for specific purposes, types of food, bait pieces, crates, crappy clothes, etc. 
Which wouldn't be so bad, if you weren't also unable to sell a lot of it, unless you find a vendor that wants those specific items. So you're just constantly carrying around a inventory filled with stuff you don't want, with the choice to either sell it or trash it (which you don't want to do since it's all worth money).

review: Terrible, hated the play style. I like survival and sim games but this is just terrible. I bought it, got busy for a couple weeks because work and life, played some other games (barely) in that time and when I finally did boot it up and hated it, I couldn't get a refund because it's been over 2 weeks (This is the third week/1 week more than allowed) though It's obvious I've put a quarter of the time in that I could before a refund isn't viable anymore. It was cheap so it's not a huge loss, but I wish I had played a demo or something before throwing any money at this clunky game. Maybe it'll get better in time, but it has a very long way to go.

review: I suspect some will find this too 'gentle'. It's an old game. The sea looks beautiful. The rest of the graphics are understandably behind today's standards. There are missions to do and islands to explore in this open world adventure. The real  joy is playing with friends, launching a boot and sailing around on the ocean.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000527551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2632, 'last_played': 1623298687}
review:
I remember playing the demo for this game back in 2014-2015ish and saw it was on sale recently for <$2 so i got a copy for me and a friend to mess around with for maybe a couple hours... so almost 45 hours later i guess it's worthy of a recommendation.

This game is pretty fun but, the game still feels early access and very unfinished but it really nails the sailing and exploration. The combat is rather dull but the bows are fun to use. The survival aspects can be completely ignored as far as I could tell, I'd forget to eat for days and it didn't seem to effect me at all. The multiplayer is rather glitchy and unstable but it does work ok and the game is a lot more fun to play with others.
So if you want a good survival game, look elsewhere. If you want a really good sailing and exploration game with enjoyable lore and story then you could do a lot worse than Salt.

review: Been playing this game non-stop with a friend these couple of days and it's but no doubt one of my favorite games at the moment. I like the grind of it, I hated not being able to cut down trees at the start but it wasn't a problem further in to the game. Me and my friend already have 4 or 5 ships and soon the "best" ship in the game. This game was worth every penny and I would definitely recommend this game. We can sit and talk for hours just gliding around on the sea occasionally going onto an island to get some quick loot. Simply amazing but if this game seems to be bad looking or badly optimized ( which it is ) don't worry cause they are working on Salt 2 which looks amazing so I hope you give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160362855', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1139, 'last_played': 1678840240}
review:
I really enjoy this game, but it's not a game for everyone. Salt is a game about adventure and exploration, where you get to take to the seas and fight a myriad of pirates and monsters. But mostly it's about sitting on your ship and going through whatever tasks you feel like doing while listening to the sea air. 

It's a pretty janky game though, and it's visuals aren't that high quality, but its art style does grow on you. Also I can't really overstate how relaxing and atmospheric this game's soundtrack can be. 

In that sense it's kind of like Morrowind, but with boats (without the RPG elements, but in terms of vibe it's similar). If you think you'd enjoy that, this game's for you. Pick it up while it's on sale (or should I say sail) for less than the price of a big mac, and you'll get many hours of enjoyment out of this little game. And watch out for the sequel.



Also press F2 often, you'll thank me later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028817176', 'num_games_owned': 2483, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1598675168}
review: Great, that such a little game could be this addictive. Alone, not so much, but with friends is very entertaining. It's an open world game with a lot of sea to travel. Granted, is a low budget game (don't expect SOT) but more like a very distant cousin. There's pirates, ships, some rpg elements and even some crafting. It's a relaxing game, you can play with your friends and there's no other playes but the friends you invite to your private seas. We found ourselves spending hours without noticing and wanting to come back for more. I totally recommend it, for either taking a break from other games or just to have fun with friends. Also, get it on sale, because it has trading cards and you get your money back by selling them, so it's kinda free in the end =) There's no excuse for not grabbing this one on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992004622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1609, 'last_played': 1598801369}
review:
This little game is great, its simple and yet it has a good amount going on. It's been on my wish list and I snagged it on sale for 1.49. 

I love that you have to  create your own map as you explore - using a sextant and a compass instead of just an auto map really gives the game a unique feature, even giving you a journal to fill out to remember special places and items.

Inventory management has it's ups and downs. I like that there is no weight limit (yet?) and that I can create "pages" and sort my items my own way, but having to move items one at a time to get from page to page is tedious. 

Sailing along the ocean and seeing an abandoned ship or a large grey tower on an island is really exciting and makes me feel like an explorer. Trying to navigate tall areas of land and hilly areas is not exciting. 

Combat is easy enough that I don't feel like i'm over powered, but I also have had to turn from a fight a few times as well. Overall this game is very relaxing and I don't really feel rushed, allowing me to do things at my own speed.

I hope there is more coming from this game as I am really enjoying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055089474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1596866227}
review:
Not a great game sadly. Feels incredibly unfinished. Due to the overall lack of content and depth the game is mostly just tedious despite some of the neat core mechanics it implements.

* Combat has no finesse, and hunting is drawn out needlessly between weapon damage and animal health.
* Exploration holds little value since most islands have virtually nothing on them. 
* Gathering materials feels like a chore as you comb cookie cutter islands for logs and specific rocks. (Being unable to cut down trees while holding an axe in my hand feels somewhat frustrating. Only bits of wood you find on the ground are suitable.)
* Crafting seemed shallow and mostly pointless.
* Poor audio and music design.

On of the few good things I can say about this game was that the navigation and mapping system was fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198890467536', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2480, 'last_played': 1649389468}
review:
This is on god the best game i have ever god damn played. you can swim on your big ol boat while listening to sea shanties with your buccaneer buds, you can kick pirates' asses for being racist and steal their rum, and you can go fishing in the deep ocean (Heck yeah!!!) its a real hoot. Me and my buccaneer bud looked like master sailors then destroyed sally brown on the red maiden then killed dragon for watching. Salt is a fucking masterpiece and salt 2 has some real fucking competition if it wants to beat this. I literally cannot stress how fun this game is, give it a try unless you're a loser who doesn't like fun games.

I had to edit this, to all the people sating theres no main quest, there literally is. and everyone says the devs abandoned it, ofc they did; they're making a second game.

-your favorite sailor, lil uzi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198809213398', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1595260552}
review: i played 8 hours alone and it was different game. you can't cut trees, no thirst (only food),  you can't make base (but you can customizate your ship. so your base is your ship). some basic materials hard to find. example fabric, bamboo pole, log. i traveled 25-30 island and collected only 5 bamboo pole. raft difficult to use but you can craft sailboat after 2-3 hours. pirates and chest markers is hard to see nearly useless. finding your own way was my favourite thing in this game. you have to find a sextant (for your coordinates) and compass. after that you can find your way and mark the islands on the map. fishing simple. inventory and controls weird.  there are a lot of item in this game. optimization a little bad. i played 30 fps (normal graphics). oh i hated stamina on this game. i have stamina items and still no changing. still exhausting in a short moment. this game not fun alone. i'm a lonely wolf but i bored after 8 hours. after repair an old pirate ship i left the game. maybe i can play again with my friends a few years after (and it's just 700 mb).  i have to warn you, some people can bored even with his friends because this game not for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165654207', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4703, 'last_played': 1707364747}
review:
I adore this game, easily one of my favourites. Even though the gameplay loop is repetitive and combat is extremely shallow. This game requires you to take initiative and seek out things to do. There's a lot of things to do from collecting crafting ingredients or searching out a boss at night, but if you don't choose to do them you'll be wandering around without purpose and you'll get bored pretty quickly. This game doesn't hold anything back and anything can be found, the game has a lot of rare moments and even with many hours in, you'll still find completely crazy and new that you just never expected to find. Personally this keeps me on edge as I feel as if the little noises in the track for the rain actually means a terrifying rare boss will come out at me, you just don't know with how vast the content is. It's a shame development has ceased, as if this were to be built upon, that feeling of excitement and anxiety of genuinely not knowing what could happen would stick around for even longer. However the content we have now is enough to evoke the feeling for at least 20 hours. 

A few mechanics are explained in the help book, but who reads that? Once I figured out the ability to create different sets of items, it completely expanded the way I played, hunting after rare items to give my sailing set a boost, or my running set additional stamina or run speed.

I would not pay the price ¬£11.39 (Normal base price for the UK), catch this game on a sale and it's worth the money. Friends make this game more enjoyable however it can lose the personal attachment to the world/character you've built.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134182354', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 3448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3448, 'last_played': 1585960770}
review: no big issues, cute characters, wonderful scenery, but what do I do? Farming is so easy that surviving isn't difficult, but every island is the same: kill some things (deer, pirates, etc) and then the island has nothing for you, as far as I can see. After killing what you're prompted to, there's no more prompts, unless you go to another island, but it's basically the same. There was a guy that wanted me to find buried treasure, but that felt like a side quest. Maybe I'm missing something, but I really don't know what to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988279838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1593652811}
review:
The good
water looks great

sailing at sea is nice and peaceful.

crafting system is well done.


The bad
not able to gather wood from trees,fiber from grass/bushes or stones from some stones.

pirates that don't sail a boat at sea

the world makes no sense, its pirates which don't sail. and people by themselves.
where are the towns and societies? this world would not last. i never saw a single woman either...

navigation is horrible even with the tools you need to find..

islands are bland with little interesting to see on them.

building bigger boats requires a lot more resources and time but they are barely better. you can put a bed/supply box on it as an actually useful feature. otherwise the early boars work well enough.

they should sail significantly faster than the early boats.

there is no mode for unlimited supplies and no hunger.

overall
there is no point to this

review:
I played some Salt in single player and found it to be enjoyable, but ultimately a little obtuse and I never figured out the map system or the overall play loop. Co-op with a friend on the other hand, freaking amazing! Probably 10 hours in at this point, having crossed massive distances, built a small sailboat, and opened up a handful of quests. This game is excellent and despite it's low fi graphics, it manages to be more evocative of exploration than Sea of Thieves. 

Compliments to the devs. I'll be following your work.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976266068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3598, 'last_played': 1514843599}
review:
I DEFINITELY WOULD recommend this game as it's *REALLY* enjoyable and relaxing, especially when you fix your first abandoned pirate ship and set the sails. 

Unfortunately though, development seems to have stopped a longer time ago, which really is a pity.

If you're in for a neat game for a few hours of nice exploration - go, get it. 
Despite the game being nowhere near finished, I like it a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154436103', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10404, 'last_played': 1673408451}
review:
This is one of the best games I've played. The gameplay is perfect, the boats are beautiful, the story is engaging, and the multiplayer is well executed. The exploration part is very relaxing and exciting at the same time, when I was first starting out it was very enjoyable running around each island without knowing what I could find. The ship customization is a very appealing, whenever you find or craft a placeable item you can place it anywhere on your boats/ships (sadly you cant put furniture on islands). The game doesnt tell you alot about each item or boat so when you get something you have to test it out yourself which can make you feel more accomplished. 

I would recommend trying the demo first to make sure it runs well and it is the right game for you. When I first got the demo I was playing on a 7 year old HP laptop which had a bit of trouble running the game but it showed me that when I get a better computer this would be a very good game. After getting a faster HP laptop this was the first game that I bought and it still runs perfectly to this day like 3 or 4 years later.

review:
Great game with great mechanics for exploration! It is however a bit lacking in multiplayer experience. I do enjoy that you can play with your friends and I enjoy the exploration and questing. I do however wish that the islands didn't feel so empty. I don't know how that could be remedied. There could be abandoned tents on every island or there be conspicuosly placed flags. Idk really.

Still a great game but the single player experience is noticeably more polished than the multiplayer one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066171675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1587680857}
review: By no means a perfect game, but it can be used to scratch that open-world pirate adventure itch. Much less expensive than at least one of the alternatives, I expect to be able to get at least 20 hours or so of enjoyment out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064775587', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1587454024}
review:
What started as a great experience in an ever reaching sea full of islands quickly turned into what I saw as 11 fps steady as soon as the rain began. I figured the rain would go away so I kept playing, this torrential downpour lasted for an entire fortnight. While I was beating pirates in the face with axes and chasing deer with swords I quickly realized that it wasn't worth it as I got a single deer meat from what felt like 15 minutes of chasing and swinging an axe. My normal fps of 100+ was quickly ruined due to poor optimization and a rain that was worse than a real life hurricane. I got my sailboat up and running and had to stare at the ground for the rest of my journey before my computer caught fire and died due to this horrible lag. The computer I built so I could enjoy Salt just wouldn't pull it off. My current computer is 5x better than the recommended and it just didn't want to cooperate. I am deeply saddened by this state of affairs but will probably return soon and hopefully this century long rainfall will be over. 
-A saddened 21 year old

review: This game may not look like much, but for a crafting exploration game, it has a lot of surprising depth to it. Definitely check it out if it is on sale. I enjoyed my almost 30 hours playing it.

review: This game is a great concept, and will bring you a lot of joy for the first several hours. There are many cool features, like having to map the world for yourself, but besides that, it's very shallow. The devs haven't updated it for over a year now. I'd love to see this game get touched on at some point in the future, but i fear that it will never happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066684808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12898, 'last_played': 1657820806}
review: Personally I adore this game. I find it to be a good game for explorations and relaxation. It gives an experience that many games can't right now. It allows you to explore for yourself and learn the secrets of the game, because the community is so small not everything is uncovered and I find that very refreshing. It is not perfect by any means though, it requires beefy computer despite what specs are recommended and has plenty of bugs. I think if Lava Boots patch those bugs and make the game run better it would have much more positive reviews. I recommend this game if you have a computer that can run it at 60 frames.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079026928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1585367571}
review: Controls and interactions are clumsy at best which makes for a frustrating time. Interactions only work if you are standing in the perfect spot, the sensitivity of movement controls seems to change randomly, or are just so imprecise that you feel disconnected from the movement and end up just clicking randomly hoping to get the right response. Love the idea and atmosphere in the game but the controls are just too frustrating

review: This is one of these games you forget the title to and look for ages for (futuristic gauntlet!?). I was almost, but then not disappointed. The Roblox style quest/side quest cartoon open-world the game exists within has me accurately enthralled. Realising there is not much to the random mechanics as for the price was also accurately anticipated by me towards this only being a 'fun' version of a much larger game. Hey Ho!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045360886', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 5806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5272, 'last_played': 1642211453}
review: Salt is a game about being a pirate, and a good one at that. There's unlimited islands, fishing, treasure, and magic! You have a steady line of progression that isn't too hard, but isn't too easy and that's what makes it great. There's an in game hint A.I that points you towards most of the quest in the game allowing you to enjoy the game without the need for online guides if that's your kind of thing. The game features some things that aren't all pirate like but are welcome editions in my book which include, mining, fishing, and scavenging for loot. The game features a wide variety of ships with there being 3 late game types that are mainly used, and the same type of weapons can be used throughout if you wish. This is one of the best games o have played to date, and I would recommend it to anyone that has the need for a new breath of fresh air in an "open world survival" game.

You spend your time mostly charting islands, but it still somehow manages to be engaging.  The game itself isn't some super hard and intense thing, so it's a great game for unwinding at the end of the day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097670907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1579921234}
review: I really wanted to like this game. Graphics are horrible right from the get-go, and when I got to "deer island", it was impossible to tell where my arrows landed when I was shooting. Not worth the frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066561437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1580111388}
review:
TRY. THE. DEMO.

Do not buy this game even on sale if you haven't tried the demo, it lacks polishing and feels like a beta. You "can" have fun with this though, it's very relaxing and there's some fun sides to it but it very much feels like something that was released way too early.

It's all about what you want really, it's hard to explain and everyone will have their own opinion about it. Therefore, you should try the demo.

That having been said, I think they're quite a bit of enjoyment to be had in Salt and with the now added multiplayer it's sale price of ‚Ç¨ 3,74 might yet be worth it.

I cannot however, endorse this kind of practice of releasing a game too soon. It's a bad practice and should not be tolerated under any circumstances, I think we're lucky that Salt turned out the way it did, it could've been much worse.

In conclusion, I can't recommend the game in general, but maybe have a look for yourself anyway.

review: I play this game to relax. I love the sound of the ocean and the boat creaking in the water.  The massive waves in stormy seas are also quite memorable. Put on some music and enjoy. Havent done much of the story or missions but there is content for 100s of hours I expect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077552012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1679, 'last_played': 1581526451}
review: Addictive! Relaxing! Challenging! It has it all and beauty to boot. I'll admit it takes some time to figure the controls and mechanics and sometimes it can feel like a bit of a grind to find materials. But it can be as casual or a grindy as you make it in my opinion. No map means the world is an open book. Explore at your own pace. Fight pirates  or stalk some wildlife for pelts to craft armor. The world is at your feet as you sail through the vast ocean in search of treasure, fame, or whatever your heart desires. In this girl's opinion don't forget to stop and listen to the gentle waves or stare up at the stars by a campfire lit night. Let nature sweep you off your feet and enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215152701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3026, 'last_played': 1650018155}

author: {'steamid': '76561197964752476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1640629020}
review:
It's the surprise of the year for me. Bought it on a winter sale for many kids in my family plus for my brother and for myself. 6 copies for under 25EUR, first I thought it was a bargain, but turned out it's also a really hilarious game with lots of fun in multiplayer. 

Sailing together on a ship we built together, fighting pirates, hunting, trading, searching for treasures, doing quests. It was extremely fun to explore the game with friends. (Finding out together how to gather resources, how to craft things, reading all the messages found in different books, "living in the adventure" adds so much to the enjoyment of this little masterpiece, so I suggest not to use wikis or web search  to beat the game fast, instead just explore it for yourselves. Riddles, quests, enemies - they are all not too hard.) 

My only negative experience is the way a multiplayer game has to be started. Every player has to be in the lobby, one cannot join after a multiplayer game has been started. I read that multi has been added to the game just 2 updates ago, so it may be developed into a more comfortable version later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040882512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1555017860}
review:
I am so divided on Salt. On one hand, it‚Äôs an endearing, relaxing survivalist game. It‚Äôs like‚Ä¶ ARK minus dinosaurs times Nintendo. It wants you to survive and explore, and the experience is truly relaxing and easygoing and honestly that‚Äôs nice to see from a game in this genre ‚Äî the whole IT HAS TO BE SUPER HARDCORE thing tends to mean you have to sacrifice your life grinding to experience the game. Not so with Salt. The game is really focused on sailing and boatbuilding, and the feeling of setting out over the water to find new islands is a very good one. It‚Äôs constantly autosaving, so if you do die, you don‚Äôt get set back much. All the islands are full of fruit so you don‚Äôt starve. If you jump in the ocean you don‚Äôt get attacked by sharks and you can‚Äôt drown. And the effect is a good one ‚Äî it‚Äôs a game that feels like a deep breath.

The problem with it, and the main reason it‚Äôs in this post, is that unfortunately the dev abandoned it. It looks like they did juuust enough to justify taking it out of EA and then gave up. And for all it does well, it does feel very unfinished. It never progressed to other boats being on the water, or adding villages to islands, or basebuilding, or a lot of the staples of the genre. There are only a handful of boats to build, there‚Äôs no music, and the AI is not. There are also still lots of bugs. Which is all a shame because it‚Äôs so close to being a very good and pretty unique game. I get that eventually you want to move onto new projects as a developer, but it is hugely disappointing. There‚Äôs just not enough here, certainly not enough for a $14.99 sticker price ‚Äî that it some audacious shit. (I paid $3.74 for it which is the upper end of fair.)

This is actually the first time I‚Äôve gotten burned by an EA purchase, incidentally. I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm particularly judicious, but I do buy EA games from some frequency and I‚Äôve had a pretty great experience with the system ‚Äî past purchases include ARK, My Time at Portia, Slime Rancher and Staxel. I guess I was kind of due for a dud.

This game makes me feel like i'm a make-a-wish kid and they forgot to get the cast of Avengers to come see me so they brought me this instead. The developers must've given up half way through making the idea for the game, you can swim on land and walk on water. I hate this game even though my gay stallion buddies somehow had fun without me. Even while I was complaining the whole damn time.

-Your King, Riff Raff's #1 Fan

author: {'steamid': '76561198365389953', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1574618234}
review:
As of now, I haven't played this game a lot but I have to say: For what seems to be a shitty game at first, you really can't let it go in the end. As others said, the graphics aren't great, the enemies aren't too entertaining and it's a really simple concept, but the exploration is so fun! Wouldn't spend the full price on it though. Buy it when it's like 30-40% off
Now in detail:

GRAPHICS were the most frustrating thing, even though it looks beautiful in general, the NPC's look a bit too simplistic to me (clothes are great, but their body shape omg). Also there's a big problem whem hunting on an island. If the animals would always be marked I'd be okay with it but god damn it, everytime deer run off even on small islands it's so hard to find them again. Especially with lots of grass or rain the footprints don't help at all! And cause of the sometimes crowded-feeling environment you can't differentiate a deer from a rock or tree from a certain distance. So frustrating. I also find it helpful but weird that you can sometimes see campfires from far away but not the outline of the island it's sitting on. 

ANIMALS are so weird when it comes to hunting, aiming with your bow seemed quite intuitive when it comes to deers but I haven't shot down a single bird up until now, oof. You also have to stand on a big enough mountain to do the latter as they only seem to fly on a certain height. You do know that birds sometimes fly higher, lower or even sit down?

FOOD was the only thing you seemed to have to worry about if you kept away from pirates until you got a good weapon and took them seperately but honestly... I've had an empty food bar for a long time now and it doesn't seem to matter. Which is nice, since there are little to no apples (which even if you sometimes can't even grab) and you often just don't want to hunt or have deers nearby. So only before/ after a battle should you eat to get that health regen.

MAP is the one thing I found the most interesting/ original, since it doesn't reveal at a certain radius around me, which I found super boring in all games that do this. Instead, when you have your sextant (and maybe compass) ready to determine your location you put the islands in yourself! Sure I'd like some kind of checkmark to tell me that I put the islands in the right spot or something to feel confirmed with but just this little thing adds so much as said by others!

EXPLORATION is the thing you should do to enjoy this. DON'T try to stay on every small island for too long, see your boat as your base and home. Islands should be more like mines, in which you stay a while till you got all you need (especially chests) and then go on to put the next one on your map. You'll just end up confused if you try to even remember where exactly what is on an island.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029084197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 73432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49403, 'last_played': 1654210617}
review:
Great game! Very Stable, lots of ways to enjoy the game. Does require you to learn how to navigate with a compass!  You map all your islands and discoveries. Many different missions from several different sources. You can easily take dozens of hours of play to get even the starting story line finished. Plenty to do even after that!
Don't expect super graphics, but it's by no means inadequate to enjoy the game. The game play is GREAT! If you use different starting map seed, you'll always have a new experience with the same story lines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092213236', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1885, 'last_played': 1685857468}
review:
I haven't played the story all the way through, currently working on it with a group of friends. However its quite fun, especially if you have a player being a good cartographer. Its notably calm on the seas and can be very relaxing. Board an island and fight the baddies, I'm never really searching forever for anything (loot, chests, pirates, so on).

Boat physics are buggy when you tp to people on them or move them via 'replacing them down' in the sense that its Gmod physics going wild. Nothing breaks and no one dies, but its certainly amusing.

Multiplayer
-Loot is instanced, so everyone gets their own loot(randomized for most things).
-You can trade with other players.
-You can assist with sails or steering on boats that are not yours and such.
-Light sources (handheld) are for both you and them.
-HOWEVER, you LACK the ability to utilize placed equipment on boats that are not yours, like chests and I think torch holders and such. (You might be able to use the cannons).
-You also cannot place items on boats that you do not own.

Aside some rounding out on multiplayer aspects, i think this game is excellent. If you had a small group of friends willing to play together as a crew then I would estimate the value of this game to be 15-20 dollars. It has a small sense of feeling unpolished, maybe that is mostly the multiplayer mechanics, but as a whole it feels as a rather nice and fulfilled game.

If this style of game is your jam you will definitely enjoy it and if this is on sale for anything less than 10$ you should grab it for a fun spin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034432403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 23565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14362, 'last_played': 1650936223}

author: {'steamid': '76561198266073876', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 351, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1555493040}
review:
Salt is a game that has no right to be as good as it is. There's little to actually do, there's a few simple "quests", which are more just fetch missions. The game is riddled with bugs, and the "pirates" and more just hostile island dwellers. They never ride in actual pirate ships or attack you on the sea. Combat is lackluster at best, essentially coming down to clicking on enemies and running away if they are too strong. The graphics are poor and at a distance islands can look pretty ugly.

But where Salt really shines is in an area few other games can. The sense of exploration you get from just sailing around is unparalleled. The loneliness is strangely comforting. Oftentimes you don't really know where you're going, and you don't care. You just want to see what you find. Even when its the 1000th pirate island, or just a small desert island with a trader, it always somehow feels exiting. The game gives you a blank map, and its up to you to fill it out. It might not be for everyone but I personally loved charting my progress and marking islands I found on the map. It made everything feel more personalized, like you really are the first one to chart these unknown lands. 

The ships are probably the best modeled part of the entire game, and they should be. You spend the majority of the time on your ship, sailing between the many islands, so might as well be proud of it. The sense of achievement when you acquire some of the larger ships is wonderful. You grow attached to them as you personalize them and live upon them. They become like a home, and the sight of your galley silhouetted off the shore of the island you just explored is always welcoming.

The simplistic art might not work all the time, but it mirrors the core simple aspect of exploration. Everything seems calming, even if that means it isn't particularly gorgeous. It doesn't need to be. It's simple and welcoming. Just charting a course for the nearest inn island and sailing there, which would normally be a menial and boring task, is somehow enjoyable. When that music kicks in you don't care that you aren't really doing anything. You're alone on the high seas, on your trusty ship, and it's homely.

Though a lot of enjoyment can be had from calming solo exploration, the game does benefit from multiplayer as well. The multiplayer can be buggy at times, as with the rest of the game, but is nonetheless entertaining. You and your mates can form a more concrete plan for your sailing, seeking out Pirate Kings Outposts or the elusive Jungle Island. As homely as your ship may seem by yourself, it is even more so with friends onboard. They can also significantly help in fighting bosses, which are often difficult by yourself (in part due to the lacking combat mechanics).

On the topic of price, I can't say I recommend the game too highly at full price. With the little amount of actual content it contains, I do not believe the enjoyable exploration aspect enough compensates to the pricetag. However, if you can purchase the game on sale I highly recommend it, provided you like simple exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198388666827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 1430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1231, 'last_played': 1567301668}
review: Salt is one of the few pirate survival games. It has a generated endless world with some guilds and quests to grind through. Collecting stuff for bigger ships is motivating and the graphics are fine. Negative aspects in my mind are the bad performance (framerate) and missing end game content, you have seen everything after a short time. But its still a pretty cool and relaxed game that you can also play with friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994426571', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 17702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 12, 'playtime_at_review': 11820, 'last_played': 1711383935}
review:
Incredibly relaxing game!

Wonderful lowpolygon graphics with great colours everwhere.
Fun and big world to explore, also procedurally generated.

Alot of items to find and to craft, mission to do and mission to discover.

Ships to build, ships to be discoverd in order to build and even decorate them with items you craft and/or find/loot.

Great fun as soloplayer and even more with friends!

Recommend 10/10 especially for players with patience and can take their time into enjoying large worlds with very guidance on where to go from the start.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973928303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3518, 'last_played': 1596888183}
review:
I like it.  It's relaxing, fun and interesting.  You have unlimited inventory, so it gets to be one of those games were you have too much inventory, and too many choices for weapons, clothes, and equipment.  But after a while, you'll figure out to have a set for heavy combat, hunting, sailing, etc.

The world is huge, and I'd imagine it's randomly generated.  There is no ship/ship combat, which is something I'd like to see.  Maybe meet other pirates to either trade or fight while on seas.  

The graphics are nice.....no they're not lifelike, but the colors are pastels and beautiful, the animation is decent, and has excellent sun and moon effects.

It't a nice, fun, relaxing game.  Buy it for a few bucks, sit back and sail the seas.

review:
Quite a lovely little survival-crafting game with a simple but deep progression and adventure system. The required materials are not to excessive or easy to obtain and the sailing system is very fun, however you can't go AFK with it or you'll crash into it.

Overall it's a steal if it's on sale, so buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023257938', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9817, 'last_played': 1635040120}
review:
Even though this game is basically abandonware at this point, I will still tentatively recommend it to on-the-fence buyers, with a few caveats.

The game is not for everyone. One of the things I enjoyed the most about it was the fact that you have to manually create your own map as you play, and the game encourages you to explore thoroughly. It's a very slow-paced, relaxing experience‚Äîsomething you'll either love or hate as a player.

The combat is pretty janky. There aren't (in my opinion) enough biome types. It needs more quests and other content. Really it's not an entirely finished product, but I nevertheless managed to sink an ungodly amount of time into it. Kind of frustrating that the devs have basically abandoned it, as it had the potential to be an incredible game‚Äîbut it's still enjoyable in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067884501', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1385, 'last_played': 1668888133}
review:
I purchased this game on sale at roughly the cost of a movie rental. At that price it's a fantastic bargain in my opinion.

What I love about it is the sense of adventure, no GPS type maps or hand holding, you have to work out your course with a compass and a sextant and draw up your own map as you go along. I also really enjoy the atmospheric immersion, walking on the islands hearing the waves on the beach and so on.

It is a small game and has limited content so yes it becomes repetitive after a while, this would be my biggest complaint about it, however at the price it's hardly fair to hold this against it.

Also worth noting that this game actually runs on Linux even though this isn't advertised on the Steam store page for some reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027857896', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1695422784}
review: Salt is mostly a meditative experience for me, sprinkled with the joy of exploration, mostly challenging combat and some tedious grinding. The visuals are very appealing, everything appears hand-drawn and has a golden hue, which adds some great atmosphere. There are few things as relaxing after a long work day as staring into one of Salt's beautiful sunsets from the shore of an island while drinking an ice cold drink.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014163253', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 2120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1532, 'last_played': 1602717915}
review:
[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
I would describe Salt as a slow paced archipelago-exploration cartographer's experience. At the time of this review I've played 20 hours and I'm still only getting started... Honestly even after repairing a ship and getting enough resources to make several chests and boxes, that was just positioning myself to begin my journey across the deep blue sea.

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] There's lore in the game books... But much like Elder scrolls lore books, I only read when the curiosity outweighs my desire to explore... or I'm never curious and your books go unread; however there were some funny books in Oblivion and Skyrim that I did actually read.

Why did you wake up on an island? Who knows. Not me. I choose to believe that my character was born from one of the fruit trees [i]...and that's why he has a chronic fear of using axes on chopping down trees because that would be so much nicer then picking up wood on the ground one log at a time![/i] GAH!

There is a quest based system, even a quest log, but I had the darndest time trying to figure out the user interface. Inconsistent playing sessions didn't do me any favors here... And I can't review what a quest giver wanted, other than a tiny note saying "Find the Pirate Hat in the Silver Chest, on the island with orange grass and stumps". Thanks Game... I'll do that... coordinates would be nice, but you'll leave those to me to figure out in Cartographer simulator 2018.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Salt is as free an open as a game can be... Almost too open ended. You wake up on an island and gather materials to make a raft. TADA your tutorial-hand-holding phase is done!

This is what everyone longing for player freedom wants, right? It's that moment after you step out of the sewers in Elder Scrolls Oblivion. It's after you leave the first zone in the Witcher 3. ...Only now you're hit with the quandary: "Uhhh... what now?"

Well, there was some guy talking about finding an Inn... and some light that would bring me to it... but I didn't find an Inn until 19 hours into the game and looking on the steam discussion page for hints.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2250226508

So... I can't tell you much more about questing in this game because 20 hours in, and I'm starting to figure out how it works myself because I just found the stupid Inn.
But I hear you asking inquisitive reader "Atratzu, what did you do for those first 19 hours?" I'm so glad you asked!

I floated around on a raft worrying about what would happen if my inventory filled up (It never did by the way),  I would press the M button occasionally and then get scared and close it. I keep calling this "cartographer-simulator" because it's your job to get the tool that tells you your coordinates, then you need to mark down where the islands are! When you start a new game and press M, you see NOTHING... you scroll through the infinity and it looks a lot like Algebra graph paper, and I didn't like that. Nope nope, not one bit. [i](To be fair, as you mark islands it gets kind of refreshing and pleasant ------ to think that no one is to blame for cartography errors but me, OH GOD WHY!)[/i]

After floating along I came across a trashy pirate ship, but HEY it's a freaking ship! So I repaired it and then took a year hiatus where I played a bunch of other games [i](Including Raft)[/i] and moved IRL.

Eventually I was guilt ridden and came back to finish what I started. But now I had to relearn everything... thankfully this old salt sea dog can learn new tricks.

So I set out again! This time with intent to at least get more of the achievements... at least more than 2 of 29. It's about this time that the Stockholm syndrome set in, and I thought "well, at least this is relaxing".

However, again note... I now had a decent sea vessel, cabin space, I could summon my raft whenever I needed, I had resources saved up. So I think it's very safe to say I restarted playing at a good time, because I was already set up. The only problem was I still had/have NO idea where I'm going and what I'm doing.

I came across a spider Queen, and I murdered her face. I found a pirate boss completely by accident, and murdered his face. ...Mind you I got some decent armor from some pirates because it seems completely random where strong and weak pirates are located.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2250226119

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Looking back over this review. I feel like I haven't really started to explain Salt... much like how I'm 20 hours in and I haven't even started PLAYING salt. This is the type of game that will appeal to certain people, mostly those who like extremely free player experience, and have lots of patience for clunky cumbersome user interface.
It has the staples of most highly popular games: Crafting, combat, exploration, survival, sandbox... however it lacks a level of polish that leaves others frustrated and exasperated.

I'll try to explain more and cover more basic mechanics, and extrapolate in my video on Salt. If you're curious I'd encourage you to check it out. Otherwise, I hope this review has been useful for you, thanks for reading!

[b]Unscripted Thoughts Video:[/b]
https://youtu.be/bEnJ8ec7iws

review: This game has a lovely, atmospheric beauty about it. The music is effective and composed brilliantly. Often I come back to this game to get lost in it either on the open seas crafting and decorating in huge ships or exploring islands some of which have beautiful vistas. The pirates are rendered simply and have a cartoon style about them but it just adds to the charm of the game. It is sadly lacking in active life on the seas making it just you yourself island hoping, crafting, ship building and decorating and fishing. Its nice to fish watching a beautiful sunrise! Its just a lovely game!

review:
Salt, c'est la fille que tu trouves physiquement pas terrible la premi√®re fois que tu la vois.

Puis tu passes du temps avec... Tiens, elle est jolie dans le soleil...
Quand tu parles avec elle, tu te rends compte que tu vois pas le temps passer.
Tu d√©couvres plein de trucs que t'imaginais pas.

T'aime bien son style en fait... Ouais... Tu la kiffes, en fait, t'as envie d'aller plus loin.
Tu veux faire tel ou tel truc, avec elle.

Le reste commence √† ne plus exister, y'a qu'elle. Et c'est trop bien.
t'aime bien les autres hein, mais pour le moment, c'est elle.

Tu sais que √ßa va durer en plus, parce que t'as tellement de trucs √† d√©couvrir et √† faire !

Tu regrettes pas. En plus, elle te met de bonne humeur parce qu'elle est calme. Des fois √ßa fight mais c'est normal, √ßa ajoute du piment !

Et quand tu te rends compte que tu aimes √™tre avec elle juste pour la regarder parce qu'elle est belle, t'as compris qu'elle est vraiment bien :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198260516060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1040, 'last_played': 1677735057}
review:
[h1]ABSOLUTELY WORTH IT[/h1]

Salt is an interesting game. It's got an extremely long plot, near infinite amounts of (admittedly fairly similar, but still enjoyable) gameplay, and is very much a slow burn. [b]You will not get 'good', or even arguably do anything meaningful in your first hour - or 8[/b]. You may very well even end up hating the game for it. Many of the reviews from people with less than an hour reflect this - do I blame them? Are they 'wrong'? No. 

It took me a lot of frustration in the early game, at how slow the gameplay was, at how confusing navigation was for me, as I'm sure it was for every new player, without a Compass or Sextant to tell me my positions and directions - I do still have many incorrectly mapped islands from my first 20 hours - and at how much of a grind it was for me, stranded on a starter island, waiting around for a good real-life hour, waiting for wood to spawn (missing the fact that you could open up the crates a certain [spoiler]Mysterious Figure[/spoiler] was sitting on), so I could repair the raft).

Yes, it was tedious. But it did have its fun moments, even back then. And, after another few hours of discovery, exploration, and frustration at the Raft's less-than-perfect, extremely basic steering mechanism, I built a new boat, and was relieved at the significantly easier steering. I also discovered an [spoiler]Ancient Island[/spoiler], and got multiple very helpful weapons 
and ammunition from [spoiler]Hunter&Pirate Challenge Chests[/spoiler] which really got me interested in the game.
After that, it really got interesting. But that's for you to find out, if you decide to buy Salt.

The soundtrack is additionally fantastic, and - unlike most survival games - you don't need to keep constant track of a bunch of meters to stay alive. It's really worth a try. And as if all the content currently in the game wasn't enough, it's still being developed. In conclusion, I'd absolutely recommend purchasing Salt at $17.49 CAD (or your regional equivalent).

author: {'steamid': '76561198131236826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1690569048}
review:
I adore this game.

Every time I start a new playthrough, I head in a different direction and just try to enjoy myself. Whether it's in the quest for bigger and better ships or better equipment, I enjoy my time, no matter what.

I remember the first time I played this game seriously and for longer than a few hours, and it was an awesome experience. I repaired the old pirate ship, then began sailing north, for days on end, occasionally foraging on islands, and that was fun. But the part that really sold me was then writing down my adventures into my own little journal.

Doing little things like that really made me immerse myself in the game, to try and actually build a character, rather than just be controlling a completely blank slate of a character. In fights, I'd try to be smart about what I did, rather than just having potions and bandages galore and simply whaling on people with the sharpest stick I could find.

Now, I don't agree with the developers calling the game finished. I think that, just like with Shoppe Keep 1, there's still a lot of polishing that needs doing, since the game is a little bit broken sometimes. But, despite that, I'm satisfied with the game as it is, and would recommend to anybody interested in the game to try the demo out, and maybe snap the game up when it goes on sale during the next Summer Sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260672080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2789, 'last_played': 1611596182}
review:
This is my first review for a game, and its mostly because I was very surprised at finding more than what I initially thought. This is probably the first unpopular game I've played where I think the devs lack in a bunch of stuff (their graphics handler seems to be inexperienced, even for indie standards) but seem to have alot of potential in many of the other areas. I won't get into any of the nitty-gritty of why I will follow these devs into their next project since this a review. Before I get into it though, I DO want to make it clear that...

There's a lot more content to it than you think, trust me. Keep exploring.

[h1]The Review (Spoiler Free)[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]

What the game really does really well encourage exploration. The devs vision clearly aligns to scattering the lore, tips, loot, and quests all across the world. You may find a strange pillar with no idea on what to do with it. You may wonder how on earth do you climb a tall mountain with a smoke coming out of the top. You may wonder if there are other islands besides the generic plains ones. All of the information are scattered randomly throughout loot, which really enhances the exploration aspect for the game, especially early on. This is one of the few games I've played where you don't explore to look for fun, but to explore because you want to learn more about the world and the tales in it. 

Another thing that the game does really well is do the said exploration in a pirate way. A really good pirate way infact. Probably the best I've seen. If you're looking for a game that really captures the [i]Sailing the Seven Seas[/i] type of playstyle, this is the best on the market. Wind Waker is the only game of this category that (obviously) beats this game in terms of sheer quality and gameplay, but Wind Waker doesn't have the extra quirks of sailing and pirate-type details that Salt does. This game also follows the myth/legends road that traditional pirate stories take, which really immerses you to be a pirate in this game (and yes, I also think Sid Meier's Pirates is a better game than Salt, but that game is too vastly different to be comparable to a pirate game like this).

So what the game does positively is best immerse you into the pirate gameplay. Along with being unique on the market, these unfortunately are where the positives end.

[b]Negatives[/b]

I wanna start by addressing the positives I had. The ideas the game has itself is superb. The execution, however, is only satisfactory at best, and at worse, dogshit. I seriously have no comment for the optimization and graphics for this game. Obviously, whoever handles the graphics and optimization is massively inexperienced, and its most likely the devs themselves, with some revolutionary-potential ideas but no asthetic prowess/vision, drawing the barf terrain and oversaturated leaf sway. Doing some of the quests seem enticing. Later on, you'll uncover some potentially sinister enemies, but the enemies themselves look like the [url=https://www.pillsbury.com/doughboy] Doughboy from Pillsbury[/url]. If you couple this with the lack of sea enemies as you go about sailing around, its clear that these ideas are shrouded with barebones effort.

Gameplay is extremely straight forward, blocking seems almost unoptimal (even while parrying exists, as a block seems to have a longer start-up than 2 sword swings. Kiting the enemy is not very reliant, though exploitable if you experiment enough to see how it works. Is realistically impossible in multiplayer. [i]Note to low spec users: When I played this on my old laptop, me and my friend took actual coffee breaks when we landed on a new island because the loading time was so slow that pirates, trees, wood, and such only loaded AFTER being on the island for 10 minutes. For each island.[/i]

Unpolishness is another downfall to this game. Back in Alpha (I pirated the game at that time [strike]seriously no pun intended[/strike]), there was no crafting hints. This made the tips and recipes books extremely valuable, and really made collecting every item worth it, as you have no idea if it was needed for quests or would really enhance your stats and exploration. Crafting hints work similarly to current Minecraft crafting hints, and seemingly were added due to the almost severe lack of guide/hand holding. Though interesting, it made first impressions really unpredictable due to the nature of RNG islands. You would have either knew how to craft a bow in 2 islands, or in 20. Though an alright fix to that, has made the guide books to crafting swords, bows, torches, and even the rare items largely useless, as all players magically know how to craft stuff. This is just one major flaw, along with others, that slide into this category of major unpolishness that seem to reek the end result of this product.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
Though this game is extremely unpolished and uncreatively executed with some novel ideas and visions on the pirate take, the main aspects of immersing yourself as a pirate are largely there. If you dont give a shit about graphics, essentially whacking your enemies to death, and just wanna live the pirate dream (better than Sea of Thieves in vision imo), this is the game for you. This game does not hold your hand, and knows you played this game to be a pirate, doing everything it can to help you reach that. Why do I recommend this game? Because I just wanna sail around and loot shit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066728261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 9948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9948, 'last_played': 1547865294}
review:
I bought this game quite a while ago, when it was a little less developed than it is currently. I found it interesting both graphics-wise and gameplay-wise, but invested time in it with the hopes of change. I've spent plenty of hours enjoying the world, looting, and sailing, but those were suffocated by the hours of frustrating combat, repetitive NPCs/quests, and unavoidable, game-breaking glitches. There's no clear way to tell how enemies scale, hit boxes are questionable, and any help from armor and accessories seems immediately underpowered. I haven't attempted to play this game in multiplayer, so I'll let others speak on the quality of that addition. I will say, however, I believe it was implemented prematurely and shouldn't have even been on the developers' minds at any point in it's production, even up to now.

This is not a finished game. It's had a few useful updates since I purchased it, along with some interesting additions in world-building, but it's not polished, optimized, or fleshed out. I had a lot of hope for this game, but ultimately it's disappointing and I'm *ahem* pretty salty about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998889633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2160, 'last_played': 1563246755}
review:
I love this game, however I don't think it's finished. 

So getting into i bought the game when it was on sale for 4$ to me this alone was worth the investment. After playing it for about 30 some odd hours I do say this game is when started and was worth the 4$ I spent. 

That being said I do not find this game is anywhere near completed. 
Some of my main issue the following; 

Chests of ships can only be opened by the ship owner. There is no friend system in place to allow sharing. (you can trade but that's so much more time and basically because there is no limit on inventory makes chests useless.) 

There are no dangers on the open sea. You can equip and use canons on your ships which is really cool however there is 0 reason other than decorations to do so. 

If they are going to call this game completed then at the very least I would like to see an open server list in game so that you can join other players worlds and at least have some open water sea battles. 
That being said for this game to be in a completed stage I think they need to include a friend system for chests, limit the on hand inventory to about 3 pages and to have pirates sail the seas and attack your boat/require you to repair it from time to time. 

That being said if you ever get the chance to get the game for the 4$ price do it. You will have enough fun with the game that, that is worth the price. However I could not nor would I justify paying the full price for this game ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974297465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 4780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1557546441}
review: To be honest I don't understand all the negative reviews about this game. For all those complaining about the combat system it's important to remember the combat in Salt is a secondary feature to the exploration aspect much like it's secondary to the construction feature in Minecraft. Salt is what it was intended to be, a fun, take your time, do whatever you want, exploration game, with some combat. Sure it can get a bit repetitive but for less than $5 it's a steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198411716395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1555884499}
review: I like this game... that said it is very poorly optimized, at first i thought it was in pre-alpha. then i realized that it was the full game... but i swear i saw some replayability in there somewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147763653', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1629328054}
review:
This game is really fun but the combat sucks beyond belief and is pretty clunky. 
The AI is not balanced I got attacked by 3 pirates at once and could do nothing and generally its swing, run away, drink health potion, swing, and repeat.
The boats ill admit are pretty cool but the rest of the game makes it hard to enjoy even that.
The graphics are really nice and have its own charm. People who say games like this have bad graphics are the cry babies who think everything including the story is bad just because it doesnt look like the latest AAA title in terms of graphics.
There is a little bit of story but its more free roam than anything.

If its on sale id say buy it. Otherwise buy a better $15 game instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117739898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 7271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1556343238}
review: Got this for under five (pretty sure it was less than two). The overall world is comprehensive and the sailing  is fun (more than a little frustrating due to lack of HUD and decent interface but getting to spin the ship wheel make up for it). The resources gathering is daunting but if you can find a way to skip that the game is worth more than the 2 dollars I paid. Could be a truly great game with some building/resource gathering improvements but fun for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048900048', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1556069950}
review: If you have any interest in games like Minecraft, Stardew Valley or My Time at Portia then pick this up now while it's so cheap, it's an absolute steal. This is a very basic crafting and survival game that is extremely rewarding for those who just explore. Every island has the potential for you to discover something new. Don't go into this game anticipating in depth systems like My Time or even Stardew, combat is very, very basic; all of the crafting recipes are spelled out for you. Controls can be a bit clunky but servicable-I prefer a gamepad controller. Graphics are very simplistic but WOW there are some great scenic shots at night, during storms and sunrises. The mapping system is very unique and fun to track your travels with. Once you upgrade to the basic boat, sailing is just beautiful and a pleasure to relax to. I just figured out fishing and it's actually a pretty decent system with lots of options and rewards-beats chasing deer around and sticking them with 5 or more crude arrows. Even if you only play this for a few hours to space out with, well worth the sale price, but this game has the potential for a hundred hours or more of playtime with infinite replayability. Pick it up!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198070038816', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1649474913}
review:
You will probably find a lot of reviews with 1hr and say this game is boring and that its a waste of time, laggy or what else you can think of. The one giant thing that most people seem to miss is that you cant rush this game. It takes time and the point is to relax.  

This game is fun with friends, i currently have 2 other people and we split up are roles  I'm the captain, friend 1 is the nav, friend 3 is the brute. Food isnt a issue but more options down the road would be great.  Hitting trees is the easiest way to get food and Fishing is hella fun.

I recommend not using max setting as there is a lot of thing to render like the water and trees that could easily heat your gpu if you didn't bother to set a proper fan curve. If it rains best thing to do is just sleep a whole cycle that stuff is semi killer to fps

Not the best at typing reviews but i put some effort in. Tbh i think this is my first or second review D:

P.S: Awesome job on this game Devs

author: {'steamid': '76561198274685011', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1572121180}
review: This game went over my expectations, I was expecting to just sail to each island and kill/hunt for animals and pirates, but there is so much more to it than that. I definitely recommend it for people that like to travel and explore places. I also like how you can get bigger ships.

review: played this for about an hour and im thinking about returning it. You need to sail from island to island on a raft that is uncontrollable and you will get caught up on islands trying to turn it around and when you  get that damn thing pointed the right way it will launch you off it and sail away into the distance at light speed. Nothing about this game seemed relaxing . i payed 4 dollars for it but i still may return it i dont want to encourage devs to publish games that have something as horrible as that raft in it. i cant comment on much else cause i lost my raft and dont intend to frustrate myself again by playing this game.

review:
when not lagging a ton its actually pretty fun to play with friends, put 4 dollars in on its sale and got 2 hours of content that i actually enjoyed most of. hunting deer became increasingly difficult as the lag increased because you pretty much need to shoot them with an arrow.

Heading (i think that's the term) a ship is really fun and shooting your friends ship is pretty funny but sadly this and changing the look of your pirate through gear are really the only good gameplay features this has to offer. the rest of my fun came from friends.

I can't recommend knowing there are a plethora of better games to play with friends that offers more satisfying gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123575667', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1555465642}
review: Other games do the same thing better, whether that be ATLAS, Raft, or Stranded Deep. I don't care about graphics being realistic, but there is just nothing artistic about it. The combat is horrible. The game is filled with bugs, reloading the game will respawn loot. If the game had just came into Early Access than this might be acceptable, but this game has been "released" for over a year. Also I know I haven't got to far into the game, but all the islands look samey, even screenshots and videos show islands just recolored at the most. This game is not worth my $4, refunding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091448351', 'num_games_owned': 357, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1555801855}
review:
The game is really fun alone and with friends. if you like to loot stuff, fight pirates, sail the seas, and hunt animals then you're more than likely going to love this. there's different types of gear with different stats, bonus stats for set gears and so on.
the graphics suck, i ain't gonna lie and if you cant see past that then sucks to be you cause you're missing out on a great game. 
for full price I think its worth it, on sale, that's an absolute steal.
Hope the devs bring more stuff to this game because i plan on sticking around for many more hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995271189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1555379460}
review:
Myself and four friends dropped in. The first thing we noticed is that our GPUs were all not having a good time despite it being... well, this. We managed. Everyone was frozen, but you can adjust the settings so you actually refresh at a decent rate and use up some bandwidth for once lmao what, alright. Twenty minutes of jankiness and we all got on a raft, the host grabbing the rudder. Immediately everyone started slide-whistling into space, while we saw the raft turboing off into the distance.

Unfortunately, it's not really MP safe. It's also... pretty unoptimized jank even on a single player side of things. Which is a shame cuz it's solidly in that Bad Game But Play It Anyway category.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008324074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1555953083}
review:
First impression below.

Hmmm.....  A game of wait for the light...  Then spend a few minutes playing until it's dark again.  Half of the day is too dark to see much.  Another obviously failed ea title using Unity.   Wish these ea devs would stop using both Unity and Unreal......  not one ea title has ever successfully used them.  All have graphical and performance issues.  With an i7 8700k 16GB RAM and a 1070ti.... I'd expect over 60fps with max settings for this arcade, very limited textured detailed game, but something causes it to run around 25-30fps.

Hard to believe the devs have another title in the works when this one has obviously never been completed.

The game does have the idea down....  Like so many of these titles where the gameplay so many want is there, but it's just not up to par and falls flat due to the lack of dev time spent.

Can't recommend the game but can recommend the effort.  Just wish someone would finally get it right and on a AAA level.

Second impression.

The darkness..... Once you understand that it is part of the game it becomes easier to deal with.  Getting to that point where you can do things at night is a little slow.  Knowing that torches actually lose brightness as they age helps.
After playing many hours I can see the attraction.  The gameplay elements are there in a great way.  And I can see why it should be a classic.

Take this gameplay, add realistic graphics, a more realistic approach to sailing and the ship damage with repairs..... with a MP aspect you could have a huge hit.  Add some minimal base building.  Take the approach of a safe base that anyone can visit if they want they just can't destroy a thing unless allowed.  The allowed part would be setting up targets for other players to hit with cannons to gain access to a locked chest..... lots of possibilities for PvE and PvP with how it's set up.

Changing to recommend.  Was nice not expecting anything.....loading it up...seeing that it has issues with quality while thinking ..."oh no here we go again with another ea title".. but discovering that it has much more to offer if you can get through the start.

Funny.....then came Atlas.  Where Salt Devs made SP fun, Atlas devs can't seem to do AI or game design worth the effort.  Atlas devs could learn a lot from the Salt devs. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038864720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1553985682}
review:
I paid money for this, I cannot even begin to describe the amount of regret I feel for making that decision. To call this a ‚Äúbad game‚Äù is an insult to the other wastes of money on steam, so let‚Äôs refer to it as what it really is, interactive shame. At first glance this seems like a typical adventure game, wander about, interact with npcs, fight enemies, and things of that nature, in some respects all of that is true. You explore a bland lifeless world, talk to npcs with puddle deep personalities, and frantically flail your twig of a sword at whatever it is you‚Äôre trying to kill. Welcome to Salt. 

To start off I need to talk about the graphics. I usually don‚Äôt care if a game looks hyper realistic or not, especially if it‚Äôs stylized and knows how to look good despite it possibly being rather crude and unpolished. But Salt is in a whole other league of ugly, it somehow manages to not only look like s**t, but run like it too. I tinkered around in the settings, and it doesn‚Äôt really seem to make a difference if I have the settings at max or minimum, it‚Äôs still choppy and terrible. Which is totally unlike the wonderfully immersive gameplay, speaking of which.

Wow, wasn‚Äôt that a great transition? So the gameplay consists of the following, walk, fight pirate, run away from pirate because he hits like a freight train at full speed, heal, do this over and over until you kill the pirate, loot him, search the island for supplies, build a raft from what you found, sail to new island, repeat until you realize the futility of your existence, quit the game, and write a review to distract yourself from the existential crisis that this game induced. In all seriousness, I slogged through this torture for two hours today and I feel absolutely no urge to ever return to it. You might say that it is unfair for me to criticize Salt without having put more time into it, but I have to strongly disagree, I put more time into this thing than any sane person should. I got to the point where I could build a proper sailboat that would replace my raft, if there is a difference between the two other than aesthetics and how you utilize the awkward controls, I certainly couldn‚Äôt tell you. After this I gave up a few minutes later, because I realized it would be the same cycle of suffering until I got the biggest ship in the ‚Äúgame‚Äù and then I‚Äôd have even less of a reason to trek through the barren endless ocean. It‚Äôs painfully slow and monotonous, I doubt that this would have changed at any point during my ordeal, and honestly I‚Äôm not willing to find out. When I have to waste a substantial amount of my time in a game, just for the possibility that I might get to have fun at some point far in the future, that is as good a reason as any to cut my losses and quit, because that is a greater cost than one could ever write on a price tag.

I left Salt feeling depressed and defeated, it‚Äôs not just because I thought it was bad, it‚Äôs because it felt hollow. I got the feeling that no one cared when making this, that this was just a paycheck to them and that they put in the minimum amount of effort required. If something is bad, but it feels like someone put some heart into it, like they actually tried, then it is a lot easier to overlook some flaws, but this just feels soulless. I‚Äôm sorry that I played this, but even more so that someone had to make this. I don‚Äôt care if it‚Äôs on sale, or if they‚Äôre offering to pay you to play this, don‚Äôt. Forget you ever saw this and you‚Äôll better off for it. Goodbye, I pray you never come to this place again, I wish I had never ventured here, much less purchased a ticket to go farther.
