review:
Imagine Stranded 2 (excellent precursor to Minecraft, once upon a time), but being able to sail from island to island. That's pretty much this game, with quite a bit more to do. 

Unpacks nicely and at a leisurely pace. Pleasant walking simulator/sailing simulator if you don't want to fight, hunt or treasure hunt.

Game is complete, so you won't see more additions, but it's a nice pick up under $10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198282075836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12044, 'last_played': 1707427607}
review:
Graphics - Can be run on a toaster, if on low, but it can be cranked up to something almost worthy, and definitely needing, a gaming computer.  Either way, beautiful, in its own sort of way. +
Exploration - Although I kinda wish you could just use the treasure maps to somehow auto-mark the place on your personal map, it is somewhat satisfying that it doesn't. =
Combat - If your an expert gamer, it will seem boring, flat, and hard to be good at because there is so little to it.  Until you get to fighting pirate kings, and must custom coordinate your equipment to stand a chance, not to mention use your bow, potions, bandages, and dodge skills, plus manage the stamina used by the dodge and strong attacks, just to survive, and they aren't even the strongest bosses.  But if your not an expert gamer, the early combat is simple enough to learn, and can prep you for late game.  Though, to be safe, try and get more than the ragged gloves they give you start for armor, because even the regular pirates can kill an ill-prepared player.  ++
Story - The story is piecemeal, at best.  Which is great, because rather than being told all the lore at once, you can figure it out for yourself.  The identities/past of some early NPCs aren't revealed until very late in the game, and even then, only implicitly.  Although there isn't much, they do a good job of dragging it out to avoid feeling empty. +
Bugs - I almost am afraid of this game, seeing as how I'm arachnaphobic and insectophobic(if that is the proper word), because this game is riddled with bugs.  buuuut... when they let you get a decent vantage point on your ship, because the crow's nests are all behind sails, it isn't so bad, and there are honestly more game-fixing bugs than game-breaking ones. =
Satisfaction - When you finally complete that quest?  Yep.  Finding that cursed treasure cache?  Yep.  Completing a repeatable quest a dozen times before finally getting the one thing you wanted from the reward pool?  Yep.  Catching a giant squid?  Yep.  Catching a fish so large, it is classified/used as a club?  Yep.  Taking down a tiger?  Yep.  +++
Not worth $15, but anything less, and go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119500345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3685, 'last_played': 1568596400}
review:
Salt is a game that has no right to be as good as it is. There's little to actually do, there's a few simple "quests", which are more just fetch missions. The game is riddled with bugs, and the "pirates" and more just hostile island dwellers. They never ride in actual pirate ships or attack you on the sea. Combat is lackluster at best, essentially coming down to clicking on enemies and running away if they are too strong. The graphics are poor and at a distance islands can look pretty ugly.

But where Salt really shines is in an area few other games can. The sense of exploration you get from just sailing around is unparalleled. The loneliness is strangely comforting. Oftentimes you don't really know where you're going, and you don't care. You just want to see what you find. Even when its the 1000th pirate island, or just a small desert island with a trader, it always somehow feels exiting. The game gives you a blank map, and its up to you to fill it out. It might not be for everyone but I personally loved charting my progress and marking islands I found on the map. It made everything feel more personalized, like you really are the first one to chart these unknown lands. 

The ships are probably the best modeled part of the entire game, and they should be. You spend the majority of the time on your ship, sailing between the many islands, so might as well be proud of it. The sense of achievement when you acquire some of the larger ships is wonderful. You grow attached to them as you personalize them and live upon them. They become like a home, and the sight of your galley silhouetted off the shore of the island you just explored is always welcoming.

The simplistic art might not work all the time, but it mirrors the core simple aspect of exploration. Everything seems calming, even if that means it isn't particularly gorgeous. It doesn't need to be. It's simple and welcoming. Just charting a course for the nearest inn island and sailing there, which would normally be a menial and boring task, is somehow enjoyable. When that music kicks in you don't care that you aren't really doing anything. You're alone on the high seas, on your trusty ship, and it's homely.

Though a lot of enjoyment can be had from calming solo exploration, the game does benefit from multiplayer as well. The multiplayer can be buggy at times, as with the rest of the game, but is nonetheless entertaining. You and your mates can form a more concrete plan for your sailing, seeking out Pirate Kings Outposts or the elusive Jungle Island. As homely as your ship may seem by yourself, it is even more so with friends onboard. They can also significantly help in fighting bosses, which are often difficult by yourself (in part due to the lacking combat mechanics).

On the topic of price, I can't say I recommend the game too highly at full price. With the little amount of actual content it contains, I do not believe the enjoyable exploration aspect enough compensates to the pricetag. However, if you can purchase the game on sale I highly recommend it, provided you like simple exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054671755', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1636675960}
review:
Salt is god awful.

The combat is super rng, and has no actual combat mechanics. You spam right click and sometimes left click. The combat is either "spam potions and press right click on the pirates" or "right click, see that the pirate hurts at lot, run and spam potions, fire arrows while running, run up, right click to attack, and repeat". The big bosses are especially bad at this. Either you get him one-on-one and destroy him, albeit losing quite a bit of health, or you somehow manage to attract him and five of his goons and get insta-gibbed. All you can hope for is a good drop or find like I managed to do.

The world is so fucking buggy, and even on low, I have to save and reload for all the textures to load in.

Fine material is a fucking pain in the ass to collect/craft. 

Finding pirates on a huge island to get your chest of goodies is a fucking pain in the ass. There are no markers or anything, all you get is this tiny fucking yellow arrow, to the point where I've spent a good 20 minutes trying to find just 5 pirates. 

There is no actual map. All you get are "maps" that tell you where a location is. Then you have to use a compass and sextant. While realistic(?), it's so goddamn dumb. I actually don't know if your journal has a map, because there is no good tutorial system, and when I click on map, all I get is a regular journal to record some coordinates. 

You can't chop down trees. You have to find the logs on the ground. What the heck?

Fetch quests. Oh god, the fetch quests.

The graphics and quality look so bad.

The game just feels unfinished. When you want to record in your journal, you have to pause the game. I can't count the amount of bugs I've encountered or the amount of times I've almost want to rage quit because of the shitty combat. There's a lot of downtime when sailing to distant locations where you just do nothing. The game itself relies too much on the pirates, and not enough on exploration itself. It feels like a Korean RPG grind, just doing the same thing over, and over, and over again on islands, until you get to that one unique one.

And yet...

This game is amazing. 

Sure, it's potential was ruined, and it feels unfinished. But it still feels good. It feels nostalgic. It gives you a sense of accomplishment like no other, when you finally finish a task. 

The exploration is top notch. Theres nothing like island-hopping killing some [strike]Japs[/strike] pirates, and moving on. While downtime can be bad, it's also good in this. It gives you time to think, and craft. It's great being isolated, just being on your own and basking in the sunlight.

The bad quality and textures add to the charm. While shitty, it's just nice to look at. It makes you want to sit down on the top of a mountain, and just relax. I've only managed to get a sailboat so far, but even by itself, the little thing just looks so homely. 

Sailing is fun, and it feels fluid, charting a course is pretty darn nice too. 

And the music, oh god the music. It almost never plays, but when you're just out exploring an island, with the sunlight filtering through the trees, and the music starts, it's so peaceful and chill. It's really nice. 

This game offers a feeling of isolation and exploration no other game has been able to. The feeling when you finally wipe out an island of pirates is something a lot of games try to replicate, but none really do. Crafting is nice and simple, which I enjoy a lot. 

This game could benefit a lot from a workshop, like GMOD, where you could install mods. That could push the game into something fantastic, and far beyond what it already is. This game has so much untapped potential.

7/10 for this game. It manages to enthrall me in it everytime I play, and gives me a feeling like no other. It's definetely not for everyone though. It's not worth the $15 price tag, so wait for it to go on a major sale, and grab it then. $5-$8 is my recommended price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038162212', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2744, 'last_played': 1673575662}
review:
Salt is a game that plays like Stranded II.
Most models look like garbage and the game runs like crap on older machines as of 2019.
The combat is atrocious, I mean just awful, Its like a random number generator but somehow worse, the hitboxes are wack and combat is so unfair that the creator actually gives you a "Rage quit" function upon death that exits the game, as combat is the only real danger.
This game is unpolished and ocasionally bethesda level buggy, it could use some improvement on a lot of things, particularly textures, combat, user interface, and some small improvements to navagation.

Without OP PLZ NERF weapons and armor even the lowest level pirates actually pose a threat.

On larger islands its very hard to find the last couple pirates and even with the help the game gives you it can take MUCH longer than it should to find them.

You can't chop down trees and that bothers me wayyyy more than it should.
----

Even with all its flaws, I keep coming back to this game for at least 3 or 4 hours at a time.
It captures a sense of isolation and validation for your hard work that many games try to accomplish and fall flat.

Exploration is almost on the same level as games like minecraft, absolutely phenominal.
In addition to this, particularly with the larger vessels, the sailing feels uncannly similar to games like Assassins creed black sail, that is to say excellent and realistic feeling without the work.
It is however for better or worse much more lonely.
While many prefer the isolation whilst exploring, myself included, there are a couple of things you can do to pass the time while sailing between islands, chief among them fishing and navigating, which adds to the realism and keeps things entertaining.

Crafting is pretty basic but it gets the job done simply and efficently. Its also rather extensive with lots of useful decorative items that you can customize your ship with.
Hunger works for the game rather than against it.

Because of the poor quality of the terrain and foliage textures, the ships (particularly the later ones) look almost beautiful by comparison and perhaps subtly encourage you to get back on the ship and keep moving.

This is a interesting, heartfelt and independently made game that despite its various glaring flaws, shines like a diamond in the rough of all the unfinshed/"finished" early access beta games that plauged steam when greenlight was starting out.

While in its current state it doesn't warrant the 15$ price, I would pay 10$ all day.



Fantastic bones with interesting and enthralling exploration, decent crafting with rewarding loot and navigation but utter garbage combat and poor quality textures.

6.8/10



If you enjoyed this be sure to check out my other game reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018745231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1546485086}
review: I cannot honestly recommend this game. While the concept is fun and exciting, the game leaves a lot to be desired. Dying and then respawning causes you to lose the better items you looted from higher level enemies such as Pirate Captains. Resetting the game allows you to refight this enemy and drop the loot again, but dying will force you to lose it once again. Pirates and deer move horribly which makes it difficult to fight fleeing enemies. Other issues are incredibly common and make the game extremely frustrating to play. If you're looking for a nautical survival/exploration game, your money will be much better invested in Raft.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001444693', 'num_games_owned': 1180, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1225, 'last_played': 1546984280}
review:

But the more you play the more you realise there is actually quite a lot of things to do, bosses to kill, plenty of things to craft, massive boats and the game is very solid, never crashed on me at all. author: {'steamid': '76561198075562033', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1685857045}
review:
My friends and I bought this game and played it for around 6 hours last night and we loved it, amazing game. Going to difrent islands and having to chart your own map is a neat mechanic. This makes you feel engaged, because if you don't you will lose that cool island with all the deer that had all the cool stuff. Pirate islands are a cool idea and make the world seem inhabited. Having to push your boat off the beach after the tide went out makes you think of where you leave it. But there are also some things that could be improved and I hope that they continue to develope this game. 

(I don't know all that is in the game cause I only played for a few hours so these are just my thoughts so far, will change if I find new stuff in game)

Things I like:
-Tides
-Other pirates
-Charting maps
-Quests

Things I would like added/changed:
-Having pirates on boats that would chase/attack you and other boats to plunder to bring the open seas to life
-The water would look better if it was clear and if we were able to dive under water
-More ranged wepons like guns (other than cannons)

Very short time to learn everything and big rewards for exploring. 5 hours in and im still learning about new things (surprising considering i paid 5$), new islands and each one can grant you with something new in the game. absolutely love the game, its easily worth the full price but an extremely good purchase on sale. not the best graphics but who needs good graphics on this type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198305241162', 'num_games_owned': 282, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1643974773}

author: {'steamid': '76561198231584276', 'num_games_owned': 102, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1545601944}
review:
What looks at first glance to be a very simplistic game is actually a very deep and excellent crafting and exploration game.
Explore isolated islands to find resources and loots, sail from island to island using one of the 14 ships available in total.
If you are into exploration games, just go for it!

PROS:
+Co-op/Multiplayer mode 
+Slow-paced and relaxing game
+Bosses, merchants, weapons, wild animals, loots and chests, making this game entertaining and very fun to play
+GREAT soundtrack
+Survival system is very simple (could be a negative point too)
+Pretty complex crafting system
+Runs smoothly even on low end rigs
+Character models are cute <3
+Quests/Stories/Npc's are entertaining

CONS:
-The combat system is too simple, that's definitely not its best selling point.
-Many glitches remain in the latest version (quite a lot actually)
-Survival system is a bit too simple (I'm a Green Hell / Don't Starve / The Forest player)
-Graphics could be reworked (4 years since first launch)
-"Pushing" boats is a real pain
-Birds have to go on a diet XD

author: {'steamid': '76561198025143693', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1673750442}
review: Salt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057767761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1396, 'last_played': 1568179592}
review:
I actually like the gameplay. Sadly it crashes every single time I play it. Maybe it's graphics related? Anyways, I can't reccommend a game that I physically can't play.

*Edited*

After getting in touch with the developers, my crash issues are solved. Amazing customer service from LavaBoots. They got back to me within 24 hours, and my game is running like a champion now. The game itself is cool. I'm a huge sucker for procedurally generated maps. You get to decide how you wish to play also. (I'm also a huge sucker for sandbox games.) If you like exploring, procedurally generated maps, and sandbox aspects then get this game. It's inexpensive and worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109198779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2535, 'last_played': 1694656029}
review:
A rainy day kind of game.

Salt's entire premise is you sail between islands, do an island-specific challenge, and get rewarded for it. as you get more rewards, you get stronger. As you venture out further, the islands get harder.

It's good fun, and very nice to play with a podcast or your favourite flavour of background noise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972512650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3019, 'last_played': 1543885139}
review:
Disappearing NPCs.

Sleeping during combat.

Plants are everywhere. Plants as a resource are almost nowhere.

Disappearing NPCs.

Food is everywhere, but it doesn't matter because you can't die of hunger (or thirst).

iStock photo levels of piano music.

Takes longer to push a raft into the ocean in this game than it does in real life. Solved by giving the player debug powers.

Unity has crashed during start up.

Disappearing NPCs.

review: I love the game as it is. full of mystery and exploration. i get lost in this game for some reason, like in a  good way. the graphics arent the best but its fun. if you want to wander why something is here and never figure it out, this is your game.... lol

author: {'steamid': '76561197993670834', 'num_games_owned': 703, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 1589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1589, 'last_played': 1514349831}
review:
It feels like the devs got to a certain point and just sorta didn't know what to do from there.  There was once promises of base building and such, but they never came to fruition.  Multiplayer helps a little, but ultimately the game just fell short of its potential.  

Not a bad game, but hard to recommend at even $15.  It you see it for 60% or more off, give it a shot.  It's not terrible, it just lacks content.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973125764', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1541425968}
review:
This game destroys Raft in every way possible.

For one, you can actually control your raft by use of a rudder.

This alone makes Salt 1000x times better. The lore, expleration, and general ability to actually sail and explore make Salt superior to Raft in every way possible. 

Salt is an absolute gem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198809848441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1559350719}
review:
In a word... WOW !

I purchased this at full price and got WAY more than my moneys worth. There was nothing I found in Salt to dislike, except that I can't stop playing it (off-line SP). I had to force myself to take a short break to type this. Really.

Okay, I do have one complaint, but it involves my under-powered hardware. However, Salt has seen to it that there are plenty of graphics settings to allow even my slow machine to run it fairly nicely.

FPS is my main love, and Salt provides for this - in this case it would be First Person Slasher. Adventure, exploration, gathering, crafting, survival and more all provided by Salt.

And sailing! I have a great fondness for the water, and Salt has plenty of it. Sailing on a foggy sea, and watching an uncharted Island slowly rising up and appearing through the mist... just for me to explore. Nice. Maybe there will be pirates for me to slice and dice, or maybe not. If not, perhaps there might be deer, or some nice fat fowl. Then I could get in a bit of bow hunting. But I can, if I want, let the island wait, while I drop sail and drown a few worms. You never know what you're gonna catch in these waters.

Weather effects, day night cycle, the ocean swells, all add to the enjoyment.

As I continue to play, more aspects of the game become apparent. The attention to detail is amazing. It is obvious to me that the devs spent a lot of time thinking the project through.

And to top it off, there is even a demo version to check out. To avoid spoilers, I would only suggest being patient at the start. Once you get going it just keeps getting better.

I could go on and on about how awesome Salt is, but the waves are calling and I'm outta here.

SB

author: {'steamid': '76561198104675955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4623, 'last_played': 1514181948}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998491893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1558730427}
review: This is a relaxing, atmospheric tech demo that passes the time, but it's very unpolished and should really still be in early access.  Recommended if discounted to about ¬£5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108776555', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1560218053}
review: This game wasn't worth what it cost... It lacks any gameplay. It's mostly just sailing in one direction until you find something. That's the game. Don't buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006575550', 'num_games_owned': 1631, 'num_reviews': 625, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1517977010}
review:
Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f_I3OrpCY3w

I really enjoyed playing Salt! Most of the systems are really basic so I understand the calls that the game is boring. I didn't find that to be the case. I thought sailing between islands was relaxing and since you need to make the map yourself there's a real sense of discovery. I was always interested to see what was going to be on the next island.

I think the combat could have been a bit better and more random events in the water would have been nice. Still, if you have the need to explore Salt is your game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131475554', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1537628488}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011873284', 'num_games_owned': 723, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3428, 'last_played': 1522795036}
review:
Ein Spiel das man lieben sollte. Leider kann ich es nicht.

Die Grafik ist f√ºr meinen Geschmack fantastisch. Eigenwillig, aber hat man erst eine Weile gespielt entdeckt man den Charm dieser eigenwilligen Grafik. Leider fehlen dem Spiel elementare Bestandteile, die es "lebendig" wirken lassen w√ºrden. Eine Welt aus Inseln die es zu erkunden gilt. Sch√§tze zu finden und neue Rezepte zu entdecken die man craften kann. Nur gibt es so gut wie keine Zivilisation und die die es gibt besteht aus vereinzelten H√§ndlern und Questgebern und einem Haufen Piraten, die man einfach nur t√∂ten kann.

Ich pers√∂nlich w√ºrde dem Spiel 30-40 Stunden Spieltiefe geben. Ab dann habt ihr in der Regel alles erreicht was man erreichen kann und wart dabei recht langsam. Man kann keine eigenen Geb√§ude bauen, um so eine Insel vielleicht zu seinem zu Hause zu machen. Die Kartensteuerung, bzw. das erstellen einer Solchen ist derma√üen umst√§ndlich, dass ohne √úbung ein Questgeber kaum wieder zu finden ist. Eine gute Multiplayer-Plattform ist nicht vorhanden. Und NPC Mannschaften gibt es keine. Die Steuerung der Schiffe ist zu Begin interessant, wird aber schnell einfach nur noch nervig. Am besten f√§hrt es sich mit dem einfachsten und kleinsten Segelboot. Kisten und Material lagert man dann auf seinem n√§chst gr√∂√üeren Schiffen, die ja jederzeit an jedem beliebigen Ort einfach gespawnt werden k√∂nnen (Samt Aufbauten und Inhalt).

Alles in allem ein tolles Konzept, mit viel zu wenig Inhalt. Einer katastrophalen Map-Steuerung, einer toten, fast lieblosen Welt und dummen bis stumpfen Feinden, die es oft nichtmal Wert sind, dass man sie noch umbringt.

Sehr schade, da dieses Spiel ja nichtmal √ºber die Community mit Mods versorgt werden kann.

Fazit: Tot, aufgegeben, kompliziert bis stumpf einfach. Finger weg wer mehr wie echte 20 Std spielen m√∂chte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015850074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1537130621}
review:
I really really wanted to like this game and there's a lot to like - chilled atmosphere, relaxing sailing, beautiful weather. I'm a boat guy as well so I was looking forward to that aspect of the game. Unfortunately, the potential for fun here quickly becomes a dull, boring and repetitive grind. Literally all you do is sail around, find an island, look for crafting materials, kill the occasional pirate, then rinse and repeat.

For an exploration game, I was surprised to see that the game world in general feels utterly deserted - 10 hours in and about 20 or so islands explored, the only people I've encountered are the occasional pirate, the occasional merchant, and the innkeeper (who I've seen once). There are no boats out on the ocean apart from you. It's a very strange, unengaging experience.

The game revolves around progressing via its crafting system however the crafting feels unfinished and unpolished - it's unintuitive, clunky and unrewarding. For a game that is centred around crafting, this is really a shame and I feel like it could use a lot of improvement.

The combat, as others have pointed out, is amateurish at best and it feels as though the only reason it exists is to give the player a reason to go exploring for loot. 

My biggest complaint is the way materials gathering has been implemented. It is unrewarding, illogical and boring. For example, there are trees everywhere on every island but you cannot cut down a single tree to get wood - the mechanic doesn't exist. Instead you must roam every island you see in the hopes of seeing a piece of wood you can collect. Also, several materials that are required for progress in the game, are only available as random 'uncommon' spawns in random places, which makes crafting progression particularly with the boats extremely frustrating and depressing.

Strangely enough, the day/night cycle doesn't seem to matter or impact on anything other than stressfully forcing you in the early/mid game, to land on an island and quickly make a fire before night falls. I've read that night time is supposed to bring monsters, but I've so far only encountered the occasional pirate so I can't comment on that. I feel like there should be an option to just have it always day since night time doesn't seem to matter.

If you want to spend hours and hours grinding repetitively and aimlessly for the occasional crafting material then Salt might be worth a look but otherwise there are way better options in this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198227692752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1539258732}
review: I wanted to like this game like a lot of folks, but it just feels like it was made so lazily. Even after release it feels like an early access game with how limited the content is, and how flat and flimsy a lot of the mechanics are, especially combat. If you just want an extremely simple exploration game, grab it on sale, but most people probably won't play it more than a few hours. Just look at the reviews and even quite a number of the positive ones will vouch for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066590240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2800, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1536616488}
review:
[h1] Final Verdict: Buy on deep sale only [/h1]

So this game has been abandoned. It left EA and was officially released without it being totally polished, yet it does work. So it's not one of those games that was released in a broken state or where the devs forgot about it after selling it as EA. I don't want to rip on the devs as they did the bare minimum to statisfy their requirements, but they defiintely didn't do anything beyond the bare minimum so they're not exactly praise worthy. There's just so many bad devs that abandon projects in EA because it's not profitable enough that these guys may seem like good guys in comparison .... maybe they are sadly.

This is a crafting game with survival elements. It's definitely focused more on exploration though. Sailing the open seas is definitely the focal point of this game and it's also where it falls apart. There just isn't all that much worth discovering. Almost every island looks the same. There are differences obviously. You'll come across merchants, pirates, deers, spiders, cultists and lots and lots of birds. 

And yes some islands will have some ancient cultist stattue or some merchant structures that will differentiate it from other island. Yet, in the end, 90% of the stuff looks the same as the previous island you were on. And there's just some mechanics that are puzzling. LIke you can't cut trees down, you can only find them. You can mine some ore nodes but not others (usually not if they look big). Plants are rare to see. The rarest item to get is probably the plant fiber. Because plants are just rare to see and even when you pick one there's no guarantee you'll get a plant fiber. And you'll need several to fix the pirate ship. 

Combat is too simple. It's just a matter of what gear you have. You'll either outclick them to death or not. There's no challenge other than are you geared enough for the enemy. And it seems every action is too simple, except shooting stuff with a bow & arrow. You'll want to upgrade that or face having to hit deer multiple times.

I don't know. It's not a bad game. It's definitely a relaxing game .... except when you need an item like plant fiber that will take forever to get enough of. I haven't even mentioned the graphics. Well, you can see the store page and yes, the game is that ugly.

Rate 5/10. Very mediocre. I think kids would enjoy this more. This is like a step up from Minecraft.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104771549', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1527889328}

author: {'steamid': '76561198277015846', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2737, 'last_played': 1559072010}
review: So far I am enjoying the game. There is some things that could be improved upon, however, overall it is well put together. The character graphics are a bit cartoony, which honestly helps with keeping the requirements of the pc and laptop down. In my opinion, the base shaders and elements of nature are well done. Trying to find a crew to journey with me has been tough, as most of the people I know personally prefer the high end graphic games. Even without a crew, it is still fun to traverse the seas. If they add any kind of sea battle it will need a crew. But alas, it is a game worth farting around with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198242693162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1103, 'last_played': 1555990554}
review:
This is one of my favorite games now. It's not very polished, it doesn't look all that pretty, there's not 400+ hours of content, but HOT DOG is it one heck of an adventure. Just sailing across leagues of ocean is inspiring, the soundtrack isn't anything to  scoff at, and when you do find something of interest, you get a sense that you found something extraordinary. As opposed to most bland open world games I've played, Salt feels like an adventure.

I would like it if there were sea monsters, and the fact that you can't block with your weapon mid-swing is somewhat annoying, but overall, I'd give this game an 8/10. Highly recommend getting it if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980514994', 'num_games_owned': 801, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 1291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1291, 'last_played': 1535048765}
review:
Relaxing game with nice exploration, sailing, quests, bosses, crafting and graphic art style.

Try the demo. It's free. Like it? Buy the game.

Took me 21.5 hours to finish the main quest line, while ignoring other quests entirely. Don't rush the main story line and you will probably get a lot more hours of gameplay. The final boss was a good challenge and fun. Plenty of content, quests and bosses that I did not get to.

I did not encounter any serious bugs, just a few deers that got stuck. The game feels finished.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969736255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 813, 'last_played': 1534824917}
review: Do not judge this game based solely on the Demo version.  When I started playing the Demo it got a little boring.  Then my son and I said what the heck and paid our  $5.00 to own it.  When more than one person is on, which I strongly recommend, most resources are duplicated.  Meaning, if I pick up a piece of wood from a specific spot the other person can also pick up a piece of wood from the same spot.  We have played it for about 9 total hours and have logged a dozen or more islands.  The map is huge, the game is simple, but itis fun and imaginative.  I'm hooked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021625231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 1311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1311, 'last_played': 1514156939}
review:
It's way better then sea of thieves.
But it still leaves a lot to be desired.


There is no caves, dungeons, temples with large epic chambers full of dragons to slay, nor huge kraken rising up from the seas, no epic loot to chase... the world is pretty lifeless with not a whole lot to do, you'll probably be bored in just a few days of playing. Why do all the living at sea games have this problem?


Why the dev worked so hard to make the games foundation, a crafting system, and then hardly use it, is beyond me. There isn't very many recipies, bad guy types, or even quests. The quests you get are always the same thing. Go to this island nearby and kill the bandits, bring something from the loot back... rinse and repeat. The bad guys are always in clumps of 2 or 3, spread out over the island. 


It woulda been such a better game if it was focused on living on just a few islands, growing crops, building structures on land, protecting it from pirates once in a while, diving into caves, who knows...  Apparently the dev is still going to add more to this game, hopefully it will get some exciting content, until such a time my review stands for what it is now currently.



Conclusion?
Salt- sodium chloride... So tasty! and is one of the most intersting molecules with so many uses. If only the game SALT could have the same said for it. 
It's good, but it's short. Endless miles of water, but only 2 paws deep.

Recommended only to people who understand this and don't expect to much!

author: {'steamid': '76561198082108373', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1686584146}
review:
this game is good. i have played it a bit, and i am realy enjoying it. 

MAP
the map is a weird one when you first start the game the map is empty and you have to fill it out p√• placeing the islands on the map. that was a weird one for me as dident know how to use it untill i googled it. but when you get the hang of it is amazing and you can really feel your inner pirat channelling.

BOAT
you start with the raft wich is a platform with a sail and a stick. the raft sails nicely but it is hard to know the precise way the boat is sailing.

COMBAT
combat is okay. the game has a simple combat system that is made harder by the animations being shit on the enemies when you walk and fight at the same time.

BEST MOMENT
when i was sailing from the jungel island back to the merchant it was in the dead of night i could not se anything besides my tourchs light. i was on the old pirat ship at the time and i stood in the front of the ship to make sure i wasent hitting anything. when suddenly i saw sand. and i ran like the wind to the helm wich i turned like a mad man to the side and doged a massiv island. and at that moment i said to myself. in wich other game does this happen? it just doest happen in other games. only in salt do you get those momnets where you sail in the dead of night. or have to slay 44 pirats at an island for a chest filled with loot

PROS
-the game looks elegant yet simple
-there is allways new stuff to find and new threats
-the ships sails very nicely
-the navigation is awesom and i feel like a real sailor when i finde my way using the map.

 CONS
 
-there is not enough plants on the islands i am talking about the flowers.
-the animations on enemies are to simple.
-the pathfinder for the enemies are terrible (so its almost imposseble to hit them when they are running at you)
-when you get the option to craft a weapon you cant see the stats, so you dont know if its worth it.
-on the jungel island the pochers can trow their spears through the ground so you can¬¥t hide behind hills.
-i have like 13 of the same book. :-/
-i dont allways know where to find stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120949999', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3586, 'last_played': 1582240451}
review: After playing this game through so many changes and a couple saved content wipes I would like to say that this game is ok for 15$ and great on sale.  This is the kind of game that you get your fishing pole, build a boat, kill some pirates and just chill and explore.  The quests spread out are few and far between and IMO not necessary.  What I get from this game is after I'm stressed to the max from a different game and don't want to tryhard anymore I load this up, turn the graphics way down to see all the plants and just set sail.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999578160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1218, 'last_played': 1509053758}
review:
Salt wurde zu fr√ºh aus dem EA gef√ºhrt und f√ºhlt sich unfertig an. Es gibt einiges zu tun, aber die Wiederholungsrate ist sehr hoch und dem ganzen Produkt fehlt es an Tiefe und Inhalt. Die Vermutung liegt nahe, dass der volle Release nur ein Trick war, um das Spiel nicht als Early Access-Abandonware zu f√ºhren. F√ºr mich, der ich die Entwicklung des Spiels schon seit einigen Jahren verfolge, f√ºhlt es sich aber genau so an. 

Zu dem Preis und wegen dieser Mittel kann ich das Spiel nicht empfehlen. Ich hatte gro√üe Hoffnungen und es sah eine Zeit lang auch sehr gut aus, doch am ende ist man doch entt√§uscht.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032251571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1515031824}
review:
Yeah I'll be honest, this game has turned into an epic disappointment. This mainly stems from NO CONTENT being put into the game over the last 6 months. To my knowledge there hasn't even been any communication from the devs as to what's being worked on or any progress reports. The game started out as an interesting idea, but the devs are just FAR to lazy. Or at least that is what it seems to me and others. Get your stuff together devs or this game is going to sink.

Edit: Here it is November and still nothing. Fuck the devs. I want my god damn money back you greedy fuckers.

review: One of the best games I have played of the 51 I have.  The sailing/navigation mechanic is absolutely beautiful, even though the graphics isn't the best.  I have been playing this game for 3 years and I still love it and am still finding new things.  It is an infallible mark of accomplishment for the 3 game developers who made this.  They have my respect.  10/10 best survival game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037647626', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1030, 'last_played': 1645769943}

author: {'steamid': '76561198115883581', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1544156511}
review:
OK! So at first glance this game looks like a cartoon style pirate exploration game! If im wrong then please tell me, but I do love these types of games and when i first saw it im like I NEEEEEEEEEEEEEED IT!!!!! Like spongebob didnt when he didn't need water in sandy's tree dome! The game its self is very great despite all the negative reviews and comments on it! Your a pirate exploring the seas after you crash! (i think you crash thats why you walk up on a island with a dead pirate and some wierd dude!) For a game with mostly negative reviews this game is a diamond in the rough! All tho there are somethings that could be improved! 

Such as! 
1. sometimes in the pause menu your boat sinks to the bottem of the sea!
2. the deers look like laggy hackers when they run (atleast for me)
3. all tho islands are not actually close i have found it beocming extremly long to get to island to island! 
4. the deers get stuck on some things like the raft, rocks, trees, etc. 
5. I would park the raft a good 10 feet away from the island and then i would return to it being beached in the same place! (As if there are tide shifts and it lowers the water level(by alot))
6. This is just mainly a suggestion but i think there should be more people on islands like atleast some random dudes on every island that just sit next to a campfire or somthing!
7. there should be more animals you can hunt, likes pigs, bears, etc.
8. there should be animals that try to kill you like a bear!

Some things i like about this game!
1. It has a cartoony feel!
2. Your a pirate whats not to enjoy!
you start with a small raft and can make better ships.
3. every building is almost suspend in air on logs stilts!

This is a fun game to just pass the time in and enjoy! you can go teasure hunting! You can go hunt deer! whats not to love! The game dev was super awesome for giving me a key to the game to stream and record! I will have many hours of content and fun with this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198123629644', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 5366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3826, 'last_played': 1660749733}
review:
Salt is one of the most relaxing experiences i have ever found in a video game. The atmosphere, visuals, the sun reflecting perfectly off water, the way the boats sway and make sounds, the ambient sounds of different island types, and the AMAZING music all come together to form Salt. There is so much freedom as to how you approach this game, kiting enemies with a bow, getting heaps of move speed or armour or health etc. is amazing. Most enemies have different attack speeds and animation speeds to make dodging attacks interesting and not as repeatitive. there is a lot of depth to this game.

However, some things are not worth it, such as any cobalt weapon or armour. For the most rare ore in the game it offers nothing over items you can find on enemies or buy. One of the best weapons in the game (aside from tiger spirit spears) is the blade of duality, which can be found in Tier 2 pirate island chests, which are fairly easy to clear out at an early point in the game. Kinda ruins part of the experience to be able to have access to an end game item that early.

Aside from those small complaints, salt is a great experience if you want to relax and sink time into a fun game. The music is incredible by the way!

author: {'steamid': '76561198121496588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1559246988}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986715648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 1734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1727, 'last_played': 1580880333}
review:
This is an ok game. At the start, it really does not look like there is much to this game, but once you get farther in, you can see there is a lot to it. The part I like the least about this game is you spend at least HALF of your game time sailing from one location to another. Possibly more than half. It takes forever to get from one place to another. You can get equipment to make the trips faster, but it still takes a long time. I am talking anywhere between 5 minutes to 30 minutes of just sailing from one location to another depending on your destination. During that trip, there are no other ships or pirates or anything. Just random islands and open ocean. 

Then there are the legendary weapons like Sword of the Sun and Old Sword I think it was called. You have to kill boss type enemies with these weak weapons to get "Legendary" weapons that are not that much better, if at all, than Epic weapons. The best weapon I ended up getting was an Epic weapon called Spear of Tiger Spirit because it acted as a weapon with good damage and you could shoot it ranged with no need for ammo. The ranged part was very innacurate though. 

The variety of boats is actually pretty good. I got the raft, the sail boat, the old pirate ship, The White Narwhal and finally The Royal Madien, in that order. Each felt a true upgrade to the next and nicely designed. 

I enjoyed half of the time I spent in this game. Especially on the tier 3 pirate islands, but after a while you see how tedious it is to get the best items in the game, which is why I did not finish the game. You will find some fun here, but the mynute gains in armor and weapons just does not make it worth going after their "Legendary" weapons/armor.

In summary, there is fun to be had here, but a lot of tasks are tedious becuase of the distance and Legendary weapons/armor just don't seem that "Legendary" or even worth the time to bother with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196886641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1657773217}
review: It's alright. Worth $15? Not in my opinion. The game came out of EA way too soon, and that's apparent in the massive lack of content. It's fun for the first 4 or 5 hours, but after that, it just becomes a repetitive cycle of sit and wait on a boat for 10 min until you get to another island, where you might find some pirate npcs that all have exactly the same gear/attack patterns as the other pirates you fought on the last 4 islands. One of the things I liked about it was the treasure maps and whatnot, but even that is detracted from when you realize that the entire map is pre-made and not auto-generated like it should have been, which means that chances are there is a guide for every treasure chest in the game. There are about 3 varieties of islands (desert, regular, jungle) but you encounter the regular type 85% of the time. Quests are confusing, progression isn't explained, and it overall is just not a finished game. Spend your money elsewhere, or if you really are dying to play Salt for whatever reason, wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069207593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1530882083}
review: This game would be good if it was under five dollars. It's incredibly unfinished with every enemy being the same skin, each generated island is almost identicle and their is no variation in the loot. Overall this game would have been a hit if they had of simply finished it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984996684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1523558492}
review:
Although this game has been "finished" if feels more like a game that's just been released on early access. Its poorly optimised and written and there is very little in the game to keep you entertained once you get past the fun of having a ship.

There are no sea battles or random events at sea. The combat is basic and the material farming is lazy. The only thing this game has that gives it depth is the amount of different fish you can catch. There is no building mechanics and no way you can chance any parts of the world apart from clearing islands the repetitive easy to glitch combat.

A great idea of a game. Unfortunately that is all it is, an idea.. having played from early access through to release with very few good patches or content if felt more like a money maker that they didn't have any heart or skill to go further with. I spoke with a developer who gave me excuses like they are working on other projects or they it would be difficult to programme which means that they can design a basic game but not take it to what we expect from even the cheapest games from this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968023506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2997, 'last_played': 1663867123}
review:
Salt is a game I keep coming back to. Bought it back when it entered early access due to a video I watched posted by Paul Suarez Jr on YouTube. The game was quite crude still and the islands were boring. However it had great potential and the devs pulled off something unique.
Salt is a very chilled game with a lot to explore and quite a bit to do as well. It's difficulty level depends on how you play it. Some islands are very hostile and you need very good gear in order to survive. But you do not have to visit them if you so wish. 
I play Salt to relax. Sail the seas with my ship, park in the middle of the ocean, take out my fishing rod and watch the sunset as I catch the occasional fish. 
When I feel more adventurous I will find an island with pirates and clear it. A chest with goodies waits for me as a reward. 
Eventually I get burned out and leave Salt for a few weeks. But I keep on coming back to enjoy the beautiful atmosphere the game provides.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077772747', 'num_games_owned': 810, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1529895257}
review:
A game with a great concept and idea for exploration, between islands and fighting pirates to finding great treasures, but which ends up leaving you bored.

Hi, Unfortunately this game turned out to be boring, even within the few minutes I was in, when I started, it looked promising, and, the concept is good, the ideas are good, it's just that, it feels dead, dull and overall boring, I can't really point my finger on what is that make this happen, but well, unfortunately I can't recommend it.
Welp, let's go through the procedure.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*] Good performance
[*] Multiplayer
[*] Graphics Settings (Believe me, this is important, so many games doesn't add those and become unplayable for lots of people)
[*] Extensive Help information about almost everything you need to know.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*] Poor Animation.
[*] No option to change keybindings.
[*] Unimmersive. (this is not even a real word)
[*] Raft and boats are awful to control.
[*] Knowing what you can and can't do is hard. (Like expecting an axe to cut a tree, but then it doesn't)
[*] Mostly dead environment apart from the default animals of that island or pirates (if there is any).
[/list]

Like I said, it's hard to point my finger on what causes it to be boring, and it seems to have everything to work, but it doesn't.
Instead it makes you feel sleepy, looking for things you aren't sure about, trying things that are supposed to work but then doesn't, and then you find the tool/weapon's real purpose later, or maybe you never do.
Navigating is awful, not just by how the raft controls, but by the emptiness present in the meantime, for you then to arrive and find nothing of interest in the other island.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It's a survival + exploration game, although surviving is kinds hard, as you need to hit a tree in order for it to drop something, sometimes, or hunt some animals (which seems to be going in extinction), or find any by chance, etc.
Your body feels soulless, as you are what you hold (A flying tool), fighting is hit & Block, boring, but you can try a power hit, or to move away, not worth it...
Most of the terrain doesn't seem to be interact-able , wood you need to find on the ground, as tress can't be cut-down, or I didn't find some sort of special tool that isn't a normal axe...
Controlling the raft is awful, I get that they tried to go for a more realistic approach, but it's just awful and troublesome, after a while you get the course you wanna follow, but setting it straight is the hardest thing ever...
There are quests to do, but they are just as boring unfortunately, they don't add much to the game apart from some objective.
The UI is bad, as you can't move stuff around, and I hate having lots of panels on my right, as it makes me have to move my head and deviate my attention.

Well, I have lots of more things to say, but since letter limit is a thing, i'll keep it short.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Bad | 3/10
It had everything to work, but doesn't, unfortunately.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Nothing much to complain, they're fine, apart from some weird shadows sometimes, the characters are meh, nothing special, the graphics aren't the main issue with the game, having better ones wouldn't change a thing. 

[b]Graphics:[/b] Average | 5/10
I said they're fine, not good.

[h1]Sounds[/h1]
Something that has worked, I like some of the sounds, even thou some seems weird, and the song is nice, for the sound I don't have much to complain.

[b]Sound:[/b] Good | 7/10

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The controls are responsive, somewhat fine, but the ways to open the inventory and some tabs are annoying, it also ahs the lack of key bindings options.

[b]Controls:[/b] Good | 7/10
Works, but could have been way better, the shortcuts are not that good also.

--------------------------

So, even thou the game is fine in other categories, just the gameplay itself kills it for me, apart from feeling empty, it feels like no effort was put into trying to make this into something fun, but rather just to finish it.
I'm normally very forging with games, but this one doesn't deliver any sort of fun or entertainment to be worth buy.
I would gladly update this review if the game gets updates and becomes better, but for the time being, I can't recommend it, sorry.

PS: I keep the game installed on my PC for some months, so if there is a big update, expect this Review to be updated!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003065210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3861, 'last_played': 1694283517}
review:
Salt is a game I have mixed feelings about, so bear with me as I list some pros and cons.

The graphics are simple, so if you want something to make your graphics card scream with effort this isn't it. But it's clean, bright, and inviting. Every day looks fresh and new and filled with adventure, just from the sunlight.

There isn't a huge amount of story. It's a sailing/resource gathering/island exploration sandbox with a few quests to point you to new places. You kill pirates and take their stuff. Why? Because.

The combat can be frustrating at times and while there is excellent gear out there, it can take a lot of grinding to get.

The world generation is decent but not stellar. There are some good guides written for the default world seed, but if you use a custom seed it cane take a while to find specific things. Which may be good or bad, depending on what you like to do in a sandbox game.

The sailing, though... the sailing is brilliant. Do you ever have the need to just jump in a ship and sail across the vast ocean, riding the waves, wind in your hair, searching for the horizon? This game scratches that itch in all the right ways. It takes a little while to get your first big ship, but once you have it, you're standing on the bowsprit feeling the spray and smelling the salt air as your ship dances joyfully over the rolling waves. You shrug off quests and resource grinding for the sheer joy of sailing into the never-ending horizon. You are free.

So do I recommend Salt? Well, as a survival/adventure sandbox it's kinda meh. But as an excuse to sail... it's beautifully addicting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195175550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1365, 'last_played': 1519960012}
review:
If you are looking for a very simple survival game without grand expectaions, then you will like Salt.  Salt is a bare bones survival game; simple, casual.  The game doesn't promise AAA status qualities and from what I read of the negative reviews, that is what people had expected.
   If you want a simple, casual, barebones survival game to pass some time then buy this game.  I have had the game for a couple years and still havn't finished it because I play it inbetween other more "serious" AAA games. It's my  time-filler game and for that purpose this game is fun. 
   $7.99 would be a more appropriate price but otherwise I have no cons to list.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072249548', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1563722824}
review: started promising, then...well just read all the other reviews, they are right

author: {'steamid': '76561198051449188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3888, 'last_played': 1515295989}
review: When you make a game to make money it alway's fails. Make a great game for fun and the money will follow. This game had a great idea but gave up thinking it was good enough to make money instead of making it for fun. You can't dive under water, you land on islands and not even one coconut! Lol! I would not recommend this game for I feel like it's not finished. They should of been underwater discovering ship wrecks, Not one cave of hidden treasures... nothing but the basics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963059442', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1528957832}
review: Game is a great idea, everything else is trash

author: {'steamid': '76561198066068285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1854, 'last_played': 1574019603}
review: The devs took in on a stange path but it's still a quality product. Basically it started as a single player hang-out game with mild survival elements and a few hidden items and quests just to keep you playing and I liked that a lot, but they later decided to add more and more pirate nonsense and memes to it that I felt detracted from its value as a relaxing game where you sail around and think. I'd reccomend buying it but it didn't turn out like I hoped and doesn't seem to know what it wants to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198339484692', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 20313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5347, 'last_played': 1660513288}
review: This is such a great game, and was exactly what I was looking for.  It has the combination of quests, crafting, exploration, and combat.  It's not a fighting game though, so if you're more into combat games, first person shooters, etc. then Salt might not be the game for you.  I love the atmosphere of the game, sailing on the ocean, the sound of the waves, the islands, just everything about it!  It's a really unique game, and I'm very happy I purchased it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198080776790', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1525029704}
review: Came for the relaxing atmosphere. Disappointed generally.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211658841', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1704170923}
review: I very much enjoy this game and all of the exploration and adventure you can achieve while playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038641174', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2071, 'last_played': 1515370252}
review:
At the time when I had bought this game, it had promise. I got it for a few measly bucks. Easily worth it. But it came out of Early Access and it came out way too early. The quests are not all there, there's bugs and its so very boring with NONE of the promises they had set out to do.

The devs had said they would do monsters, pvp and the like. It really seems someone got bored developing the game and abandoned it.
developer_response:
Hey there!

Thank you for the feedback. I just wanted to clarify that we never promised any sea monsters or anything like that, though I do agree that would be pretty cool content! Our ocean doesn't currently allow for NPC pathing which is the main reason there's no wildlife at sea. 

Also, you mentioned the quests aren't all there with some bugs. Could you let us know which ones you've encountered that are bugged or incomplete? That will help us make sure we squash out any remaining bugs. 

Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062397737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1414244987}
review: Its shit

author: {'steamid': '76561198078649007', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1582723003}
review: Dont , Devs got on there ship and sailed off into the sunset. They seem to think they finished this game for some reason. Filled with bugs and low game content. I dont understand why they would not open this game up to steam workshop considering they basically said were done now with this game upon its release from early access. Also goodluck finding anyone to jump in multiplayer with you. Player base for that is non existent. Its worth $5 bucks in its current state but any more than that i would sail clear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205806281', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1527657979}

author: {'steamid': '76561198212228104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2480, 'last_played': 1617898415}
review:
I love this game, I just wish there was a bit more to do.
I'm still recommending though. So relaxing and atmospheric.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033064424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1503154811}
review:
Resume: BAD, BORING, UNFINISHED

I bought this game some years ago, appealed by is rather unique atmosphere, perfectly conscious at the time that it was an unfinished alpha game.
Since the premises I really lookedm forward to see what the development could have brought to a game with a loooot of potencial... unfortunately that day has never come, the game left early access without actually been completed, like many others EA games with bad and irresponsible devs.
This is a huge sandbox, but there's nothing to do in it, the world is empty, just few pirates or npc, no towns, nothing that makes a huge world like this alive.... quests are terrible too and in general there's no sense of reward in doing anything, and the game in general feel unfinished (as it actually is).

I'm really disappointed by this game, I really suggest you to not play it and look for something better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046193448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4019, 'last_played': 1522611753}
review:
I've put a little over 60 hours into the game and my thoughts are as follows:

[b]PROS[/b]: Beautiful - it really is beautiful, loads to do, manageable learning curve, more exploring than fighting. Not too much of a scramble to find resources, really great landscape generation, feels pretty balanced overall - good adventuring. Disco deer. The Treasure Grabber guy's dialogue.

[b]CONS[/b]: Inventory management is awkward and fiddly, the large ships are offputtingly hard to sail, balance of items available and craftable seems a bit thin/unbalanced in places, occasionally islands don't load till you're already inside them. Fighting feels a bit flaily - couldn't always hit the pirate I was literally standing right in front of, but no idea why.

Some finer points of consideration:

- Sometimes islands take a while to load in, or only the island loads, and the trees, rocks, angry pirates, and shrubbery only load once you're already skipping merrily across the landscape. It's bad when you find yourself suddenly surrounded by angry pirates but it's even more bad when you find yourself trying to run away through an awful lot of trees that weren't there a second ago.

- Hunting is a lot more fun when a glitch makes every startled deer do a spectacular and extremely fast kind of flipping-back-and-forth dance as it runs away from you. However, this makes their tracks impossible to follow. But on balance, I'd still rather have un-trackable disco deer happening to me than the normal boring kind, so this is fine.

- I was REALLY excited when I stumbled across the existance of [spoiler] black deer [/spoiler] for the first time. And then I was kind of disappointed that there isn't really anything very special to be done with their skins. This is a common theme, it turns out. You find something really cool and there's a decent challenge in hunting/acquiring it, but discover that it's not really worth much and there's nothing really cool you can do with it. I got the feeling at times that the devs are perhaps struggling to keep up with their own fabulously creative output. "We've invented these amazing items! But now we have to invent something just as amazing to use them for too..."

- This game provided me with [b]THE[/b] most satisfying gaming experience of maybe the last two years, it truly did, simply becuase climbing to the very top of one of the mountains really is a proper and considerably difficult challenge. Everything is procedurally generated, so there is no guarantee that you will actually be able to summit any given mountin. Doing so was IMMENSELY satisfying. My dumpy little bloke stood there at the top in his extremely silly hat, smeared in sticky fish juice, and veritably radiated pride. And then I fell off a mountain. Again. But I was still so pleased that I didn't mind.

- The landscape really is excellent; varied enough to be exciting without being confusing, really nice, natural-feeling island generation that seems to work very nicely. Other than when you're sitting in a spot in the sea where you KNOW there should be an island... only to have it load in with you floating calmly far beneath its surface, looking up through the trees and the grass. That's not really a massive problem though, until you - being a pragmatic sailor - decided that you should probably sail out from inside the island. Have you ever seen a whole galleon clip through a beach and then be launched fifteen feet in the air? If not, you're in for a treat.

- Speaking of which, I spent ages working my way up to getting one of the bigger ships and I was [b]SO EXCITED[/b] to start sailing around in it and filling it joyously with crap... until I discovered that you cannot both 
A) see where you're going and 
B) steer one of the infernal things at the same time. You also can't easily raise/lower the sails while standing at the wheel, which, when combined with the visibility problems, make "stopping becuase an previously un-loaded island is suddenly happening to you" quite difficult.

- The game has a brillinatly expansive feel yet manages to avoid feeling either bleak or too crowded, which is impressive. the gradual change to much bigger waves out in the deep ocean areas was pretty cool. I gather there is going to be something happening with features under the water, at present it's just blurry and blue. Which I prefer to blurry and full of shark. But still.

- The fishing mechanic isn't annoying! I LOVE it when the fishing mechanic isn't annoying!

- I had forgotten how much I love having an unlimited inventory! And then I realised I had forgotten how much I hate having an unlimited inventory! Because I selfishly want to be able to both carry absolutely everything I see and also find specific items again at some point in the near future. Efforts have been made in Salt to try and facilitate that, but they were no match for my hoarding prowess and I spent a lot of time scrabbling around looking for that one particular non-descript pair of boots etc. etc.

The game is pretty damned good for something that is still in development, but there are still places that feel a bit thin and underdeveloped. I believe this is, in part at least, because there is SO MUCH STUFF in the game already, it's so rich with features, creatures and loot that it struggles to live up to itself in some places. 

Ultimately I burned out on it a bit when I'd gotten past the disappointment of not really being able to sail around happily in my great big boat, and also realised that there wasn't really anything super-cool left that I badly wanted to be working towards. I made heavy use of the wiki - becuase otherwise I really would have just sailed around for hours running my boat into things by day and getting eaten by things in the dark by night as I gibbered and clicked wildly at the scenery.

I will be making my return to Salt, because it is beautiful, stylish, fulfils both my desire for adventurous exploration and my desire for messing about in things that float, and also because it is still growing and I am excited to see where it's headed. A pleasant way to spend an afternoon, set your own pace and enjoy the sunshine.

review:
Not for everyone.  Slower paced but some adrenaline shots are included. Surprises and tons of Easter Eggs. Patience here is definately a virtue. If you like fast, non stop action this game is not for you. Mature, meaning leisurely, need only apply.
Literately a  game for the ages. I recommend this game with these qualifications.

review: I believe that, personally, it is one of the greatest games that I've ever played. Simply put, I love this game. To the people in the comments, it upsets me that many believe that the game is bland. Although I agree that there should've been an MMO style server for multiplayer, this game still has a great story and is incredibly enjoyable when you play with a 'HEARTY CREW'! I hope that the developers at Lavaboots Studios can consider an MMO style option. That would make this game complete.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053725542', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4419, 'last_played': 1662948088}
review: Absolutely love this quiet and simple game. Intricate in its own right but offers a casual element from single to multiplayer. Definitely would love to see further development but alas ...it is what it is and worth the value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075776739', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1522665499}
review:
I realise that I have not played this game very long, so feel free to disregard my review. I love survival games and have come across a few that I really do NOT like. Salt is an example of a game that disapointed me.

What I dislike about this game:
Lego style graphics
Poor combat
WTF how do I do it mapping system
Islands full of trees that don't provide wood...in a survival game?!
I can't craft a pick axe, or axe...in a survival game?!
developer_response:
Hey there! 

Thank you for your feedback. I wanted to clear up a couple things that might improve your experience. You can craft a pickaxe actually! It's 1 hardstone ore and a wood log. Also, the reason we didn't allow the player to cut down trees is to encourage exploration. Some islands have almost a thousand trees on them and we knew it wouldn't be a fun experience staying on one island and cutting down trees. And since Salt is primarily about exploration rather than survival, we wanted to focus on that element if that makes sense! 

Please let me know if you have any questions about the game or if there's anything I can do to help with your experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198273905042', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1385, 'last_played': 1525178248}
review:
I love this game.  It is like Minecraft but with the sea.  I love the exploration aspect and upgrading your ships.  The fighting is not too hard, but can be difficult with the bosses, but you just need to out think them.
Recommend for anyone who wants an easy going, light exploration game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996653478', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1524903328}
review:
I really want to like this game due to its incredible concept.
Unfortunately, it is not fun enough for me.

Procedurally generated world of sail ship and exploration adventure, with melee combat and customizable ship sounded like a dream come true to me.

However, I can not like the game enough due to the following reasons:

1.The world is really too empty. 
There's no one at sea to be seen.
There's no settlements or town. Friendly NPC are almost always alone.
There is too little things to do/explore on each Island. Most of the activities in game comprised of either you killing pirates to unlock chest or hunt to reduce your hunger.
This sounded fun at first but it sucks after few hours.

2.It's very grindy survival game.
 
It's a survival game where you have hunger bar. And since hunger bar reduce really quickly, you almost always have to find animals or pirates to kill so you can eat off their corpses. 
A game that force you to grind is boring.

Additionally, it isn't easy to kill animals either. At least earlier in the game when you have no fishing rod or ranged weapons. You have to stalk them and stab them then repeat the whole thing for about 4 times.

I get it, videogame is a way to waste time, but when I brought this game I expect to get my time wasted by sailing in big ship and exploring procedurally generated world, 
not wasting my time climbing mountains and stalking deer.

3.No character progression.

Sometimes you have to kill just 3 pirates, but sometimes, you have to take on 10 pirates all by yourself. But guess what ? Even if you do that you won't get any stronger. The only thing you'll get off them are few coins and some same gears.
It's disspointing when you have to go through all the hassle of luring and stealth killing a numerous amount of enemies and yet you're still the same old dude who's just as strong as one or two pirates.

4.Single player ship control sucks.

It's an absutely great thing that you can walk around and explore your own ship entirely. Even famous sailing games like Assassin's Creed, Uncharted Waters Online, etc. doesn't allows you that much freedom.

And unlike in games like Sea of Thives or Black Wake, it's actually possible to sail the ship by yourself. But guess what ? It sucks. You have to manally control the ship wheel, or sail, or cannon. 
This isn't a problem in smaller boat where the steering control and sails are very near eachother. 

But imagine only you yourself do something like that on a god damn galleon.

5.You have to make your own map, and you don't even know where you currently are without using a tool from your inventory.

Some people might like this, but not me.

Automap with fog of war system would be better.
