author: {'steamid': '76561198050654670', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1514355806}
review: The game looks beautiful and it ran well on my PC. However, while it may look pretty on the outside, the core game mechanics as of now are broken or unfinished. Combat especially was extremely difficult as it is very easy for enemies to kill you since they lock on so easily and attack as if they had aimbot. Multiplayer was also not a good experience since each person in the multiplayer session has to do the story themselves anyway even though each person is sharing the same world. I wouldn't recommend the game in its current state but it does have room for potential if the developers stick with it and keep improving the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090309435', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1514409177}
review: Don't let the purchased-assests tier graphics fool you, this game is extremely fun and entertaining. It might feel a little tedious/grindy at some points but there is plenty of content and it is still getting updated. The multiplayer update especially adds to this games fun factor, it is a bit wonky with the whole client-sided loot and a bit wonky with client-sided saving as well but the game is very fun. A few reviews may claim it took them a while to figure out how the multiplayer worked but I'm sure they just didn't pass elementary school. The instructions on how to start a multiplayer game are at the very top when you open the game. The only thing this game needs to work on is getting a new artist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987331445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 7515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7220, 'last_played': 1660160135}
review:
I've owned this game for a while now, but with the release of the long-awaited multiplayer update, it felt like a good time to write a review.

Salt is the eptiome of being about the journey, not the destination.  It is not a game you play to beat.  It is a game you play for the experience.  A review I read a long time ago described it as "therapeutic", and I honestly can't think of a better word for it.  It's charming...with its atmosphere, graphics, and gameplay that pushes you to just keep sailing and exploring.

The game is filed under the survival crafting genre, but I feel like calling it that does the game a disservice.  You won't be building bases.  You won't be mindlessly chopping down trees for in-game days at a time.  You won't be constantly dealing with hunger, thirst, and temperature changes (there is a food meter in the game, but it's not a constant thorn in your side.  In fact, I believe the only thing that happens when it runs out is you don't regenerate stamina as fast).

You'll do none of those things.  What you will do is sail...and explore.

At first, you might be turned off by the game.  "Why can't I chop down trees," you'll wonder.  "Why do I have to find random logs littered on the ground?"  But the more you play, the more you realize that this system of resource gathering works to further the game's emphasis on exploration.  You won't be sitting on one island for too long.  No...you'll get what you can find and then it's off to find another one.  And it's a very peaceful experience.  You'll sail...walk around on the shores of islands...mine some rocks...hit pirates in the face with an axe.

All very peaceful...

The game isn't perfect.  No game is.  The grind to get certain things can be frustrating at times.  The procedurally generated, random nature of things means that some quests can take forever to complete, whereas you might find what you need for another quest literally on the next island over.  But the only real major complaint I have with the game comes from the combat.  It's clunky and bare bones.  You can block, attack, dodge, and that's about it.  There is a parry you can do, but the timing is so precise that it's almost impossible to do.  Not that it helps a whole lot anyways.  But the developers have said they want to work on the combat so it's likely it will get better as the game progresses.

Speaking of the developers, it goes without saying that early access on Steam has seen more than its fair share of clunkers.  But the Salt devs are one of those few that truly seem to care about their project.  So far, every major update has done nothing but make the game better.  And they're aware of their limitations as well.  They're not trying to make this big game that has everything everyone could want in it.  They're making the game they want to make and that they can make.

Salt may not be for everyone, but it's one of those rare games that truly satisfies the wanderlust festering within my soul.  It's a simple experience on its surface that has a lot of depth hiding underneath.  And it only gets better as time goes on.  With the addition of multiplayer, the game has reached new heights of awesome.

So grab some friends, sail the seas, hit some pirates in the face, and above all...have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113223290', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1514262705}

author: {'steamid': '76561198115889388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 12659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9335, 'last_played': 1682243026}
review:
Salt is amazing - although not for everyone, I think.
It's a procedurally generated adventure game with some survival elements. Many will judge it for its rather simplistic graphics, goofy character models, some might even say it doesn't have much content. But if you have those thoughts, just play more. And more. Spend as many hours sailing, exploring and discovering new islands as you can. This is the magic of Salt - only after a significant amount of time, you will see that it has much more depth than you previously thought. There is so much to discover, but you need to actively search for it. The game is totally open for you - all quests are optional. It's up to you what you are going to do. 
If you prefer games with clear objectives or focus on the storyline, you probably won't like Salt. If you are an adventurer with lots of free time and you're ready to dive into this world, then I definitely recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198338297966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1513667622}

review: I feel that I'm the typical Steam user.  I've spent around $2000 on a library of games I've mostly played less than 3 mintues.  "Salt" was a suggestion the other day, and lo and behold, I allready bought it a year or two ago before I realized 'early access' games were a scam....  However, I relaunched this title and I'm sucked in.  It's got ton of potential, and enough content to keep you occupied.  This is currently my go-to game, and I can guarentee, this will be one of my few titles that break 100 hours /played.   It's a no pressure open world exploration game, with RPG style items/equipment + crafting.  Log it for 30 min and still accomplish something.  Just write yourself a note as to where you were headed before you stopped off at that island full of pirates.  Beat some asses, take the treasure and keep sailing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970287177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 1774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1774, 'last_played': 1512817977}
review:
Pure adventure.

Of all the games in the overdone survival genre, this is perhaps the best. It does not concern itself with minutia and tedium. It may seem odd at first, but you can't even chop  down trees! You must come across logs laying on the forest floor.

Why is this? It is because Salt does not want to waste your time chopping trees down, spending perhaps hours of total game time swinging an axe. Salt wants you to get on a boat (from a raft to large battleships, where multiple players can all hang out) and explore. Salt wants you to fill your notebook and map-grid with amusing descriptions, while you chart the islands of its vast ocean. Salt wants you to find a chest, but it won't open until you hunt down a Deer - creeping up on them with your bow, after carefully tracking their footprints through the forest. Or a chest that demands you kill all the pirates on an island. Or a character with a quest, sending you off to chart the world, or recover lost items, or annihilate some pirates. Salt wants you to revel in its loot, and equip the paper doll of your character with cool gear, complete sets that aid in everything from sailing speed to sneaking, even rope, which will help you scale steep cliffs.

The reward cycle is constant, and the world is beautiful. The light playing on the swaying grass is gorgeous. This game has the most pleasing lighting I have ever seen. Long ocean voyages may sound boring, but when there's a thunderstorm at night, and you're spotting for campfires in the pitch black fog, you really feel the vastness of this infinite world.

To finish, I have always wished games like Minecraft would have quest generation. Salt has great random quests, and the map you fill in yourself (which is verified by in-game cartographers for rewards), make this game a true adventure. You will not be building a base, you will not be chopping down wood. You will be EXPLORING.

My only criticism is that the game lacks environmental variety. I wish for frosty mountains, and lava-flows at night from sleeping volcanos. Right now, you can become tired of the 'tropical theme.' Don't let that stop you though, it is still beautiful, and worth 40 hours of gameplay or more.

I *beg* them to expand this game, but as it is, I can still recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060369505', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5574, 'last_played': 1513808025}
review:
Wow! Salt just came out with it's biggest update yet Multiplayer!
As a long time Salt fan for many years this is the update I have been dreaming about, but how does it affect the overall gameplay experience of Salt?
The answer is, it changes everything
-Suddenly things like sailing the seas with 2 huge ships is possible, a scenario where this is applicable was when my friend would follow me as I taught him how to navigate to a jungle island.
-The story is great with co-op, me and my friends got to experience the suprisingly in depth storyline with a few boss fights along the way.
-The most enjoyable aspect of multiplayer is something one might not expect and it's NAVAL COMBAT! Not even kidding, although it was quite late in the game me and my friend's ship were outfitted with cannons and ready to go. Turned on team damaged picked a spot with open water and of we went, cannonballs flying everywhere, moving our ships into position for that beutiful perfect shot.
-Theres hours of pure entertainment and when the game isn't moving fast it's a relaxing and soothing adventure.
A strange thing occurs in Salt and I'm not sure many have noticed
When you start the game salt is a fairy normal survival game with the addition of sailing, however as you play more and more, the games tone and feel and what you can actually do changes drastically for the better. As suddenly your sail boat is a naval ship, your not looking for food to keep you alive your looking for treasure and loot to be the Captain Jack Sparrow of Salt! Then you follow the main quest and so much more!

Cons or ideas for future updates!
-Ai pirate ships to battle
-Improved naval battles, I.e ship damage, leaks that need repairing, torn sails, cannon holes etc
-new ship spawn system, this in my opinion is to overpowered and takes the risk out of avoiding sand bars and would be bad in naval combat.
-Dedicated servers (maybe) co-op seems to be just fine as long as their is ai ships to battle and board.
-Allow a crew system where players can be made part of a crew where they can access cannons and ship crates.
-A neutral pirate island city/ town with built in ports where pirate ships dock and npc roam, also shops and restraunts perhaps?
-Model the lower decks of some ships so they are accesable i.e pardon psuher
Salt is a great game, I applaud everyone in lavaboots studio for standing by their game to make it something truly great and worth playing so please try the demo see if you like it, but this is a must buy for anyone who enjoys a bit of adventure :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197983329401', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1560619193}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105632907', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1833, 'last_played': 1616984077}
review:
What can I say about this game except it is awesome and a whole lot of fun!?

Even at the Early Access stage Salt has so much content and can consume hours of your game time. The experience of being able to sail anywhere you want, stop when and where you want, and explore islands, build and actually freely sail ships, fight pirates, hunt for and dig up treasure, engage in so many quests, battle bosses, craft, decorate your ship any way YOU want to, and now play multiplayer with your friends! Oh, I cannot describe how incredibly fun that multiplayer is! I will just say that I loved this game in singleplayer, but experiencing the new multiplayer and adventuring across the sea with friends was easily 10 times more fun. (Moreover, how they have implemented the MP is incredible with how it matches difficulty to how many players are around!)

This game already feels very much like a complete game and the developers are always updating and very active. Further, they are very interested in player feedback and suggestions (especially on Reddit). The whole atmosphere of the game and community is also positive.

All I can really say about this game is this: open-world exploration, survival, crafting, adventure, rpg-elements, pirates, and an incredible amount of fun. The world is huge and procedurally generated. There is a main storyline with bosses. There is a lot to do and find and many ships. And there is a lot more coming from the developers. So if you enjoy any of that you will really love this game.

So, is it worth the price? Yes and more! The soundtrack to the game is similarly phenomenal - just wait till you listen to that piano on the title screen. I fell in love with the game immediately.

As always, check out game-play footage (of the recent game!) on YouTube or streams on Twitch to see what you think of the game. But for me, I can't recommend it enough nor thank the dev's for their hard, and persistent, work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003128922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13357, 'last_played': 1598812393}
review:
I have around 210 hours logged in the game. I bought it 2.5 years ago and played it on and off. A lot of games out there always rush you through things. Salt, on the other hand, is laid-back, go at your own pace do what you want kind of game. With the release of the Multiplayer, the game just got 100 times better! Kind of reminds me of the old D&D sessions I used to have with friends. Make our own adventures, run around, sail, fish, laugh, kill.... all in a good fun. Definitely, a must-have game for my library.

When first getting into the game, give it a bit of time to learn the mechanics and start exploring, don't judge the book by its cover.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027266297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1511534617}
review: A little slow to start as you figure things out but once you get a sextant and a compass you are pretty much running from there. Still a great game and I can't wait to play some more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019943462', 'num_games_owned': 549, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1541363251}
review:
As a huge fan of pirates and ships and the ocean I may be biased in reviewing this game, but I enjoy playing this very much.

Sailing and navigating is fun and relaxing, feels as realistic as it can for a simple single player game, there are lots of islands to explore and enemies to fight and quests to complete.

No multiplayer as of yet. It is going to be implemented later on.

Obviously it's an early access game, so It's not finished and needs even more content and polishing, but I have high hopes for this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110826696', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 10238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5045, 'last_played': 1661104622}
review: This game is the game that you want to play after long hard work. I hope that the developers will get more support and investments. Despite the fact that there could be more in the world of Salt , I cannot say that it's not a great game. Looking forward to buying new games from lavaboots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065435869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4194, 'last_played': 1522782620}
review: Entertaining little game.  There is nothing overly complex or exciting about it.  But it urges you to explore endlessly.  One island to the next, you find yourself burning hours and looking for that better gear or finding that one last piece for a quest.  Overall, a good way to feed the explorer, bug when/if your have it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198337073855', 'num_games_owned': 872, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1681232536}
review:
Un juego increible, muy sorprendido de lo que consigue, el no tener nada para guiarte mas que tu libro y talvez si tienes suerte una brujula, es excelente.
totalmente recomendado

author: {'steamid': '76561198024940637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1511231758}
review: I find this game really calming to play and I bring this out when I want something calm to play. Of all the survival games I have, this one is one of the most relaxing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017260906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1887, 'last_played': 1569430220}
review: Great for relaxation, just hop on your ship and go wherever the wind blows you. Character models could be better, but I guess that's just the style of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971964488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1517150544}
review: salty

author: {'steamid': '76561198154841900', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8000, 'last_played': 1654254982}
review:
A very nice and calming game with enough content to keep you going for 100+ hours. 

Recommendations go out towards people who are looking for a large open world to explore.
If you're looking for a hardcore survival game: this game is not for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010392957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2227, 'last_played': 1548815279}
review: Enjoy game very much. IT would be good to have an autofind when island is located. Traveling on water can get tiring

author: {'steamid': '76561197970346404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 22385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17069, 'last_played': 1633794646}
review: This game is an amazing labor of love. I've been playing it off and on since it came out in 2014, and the devs have kept adding to and improving almost every aspect of the game ever since.  It's a pure pleasure to play, and every time I start again after playing something else for a month or two it feels like coming home. Kudos to the Lavaboots team - they represent indie game development at its best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198265373242', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1512396682}
review:
i like the concept but combat sucks and its a total pain in the rear if you beach your raft.
it has a push option but its very weak at times. combat is boring you block, you attack, you block, you attack, you block, you attack and if 2 pirates gang up on you early on you will die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026943384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1510951911}
review: Just got Salt today and have been playing for about an hour, game looks nice but very basic with simple mechanics that left me a litte frustrated, mainly the combat system.  Twice now I've died in HC mode due to getting to the nearby island on the raft and had the game load in the terrain, a campfire and a pirate right at me only after I made it halfway up the island and saw nothing to fear.  Second time I died I gave the combat system a go and was ready (at least I thought I was) for the pirate this time so gathered up all my mats on the starter island again, talked to the mysterious stranger and set off on my repaired raft, again.  I approach the same troublesome island again and sneak up on the pirate this time, only to have my blows somehow miss him despite him being right in front of me.  All his hits save for what I tried blocking land, and yet again I am cannibal food.  Haven't played enough yet to give this a serious in depth review and feel bad giving a negative vote but kind of hard for me to appreciate the game if I can't fend off the first pirate I come across and get killled over and over.  Sad to say but at least in Minecraft when you swing your sword at a monster in front of you, your blows actually land.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116351676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 7450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6688, 'last_played': 1511479631}
review: When i bought i liked the idea and vibes but was worried i didnt see indexes of much content in the videos. There is nice amount of content indeed: 500+ items/equipment, quests, ships to build, different kind of islands, misteries to solve... well developed game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198163258415', 'num_games_owned': 34, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 23241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13536, 'last_played': 1617554671}
review:
Jogo muito bom....saindo um pouco daquela ideia q , para um jogo ser bom ele tem q ter graficos super elaborados.
Salt possui um grafico mais simples,mas isso nao significa q vc nao vai se divertir muito no game...jogabilidade simples,
o crafting eh facil,navegar pelo oceano,em busca d aventuras em outras ilhas,eh fantastico...mas como ainda esta em desenvolvimento,podemos nos deparar com alguns "bugs",como ser ejetado do navio,logo apos dormir na cama...kkk...ou o navio afundar se vc decidir andar por cima do mastro das velas...kkkkkk....mas nada q fa√ßa vc desistir do jogo.....nao pensem que sera facil realizar as Quest q os NPCs pedem,algumas vc tera q ir longe do oceano para realizar,outras vc tera q derrotar Bosses,q possuem o dobro/triplo/quadruplo de HP q seu personagem tem,tera q usar algumas estrategias para derrotar eles,enfim um excelente game,otima ideia,uma tematica de pirata muito boa....recomendadissimo...tenho mais de 200 hrs de jogo e ainda tem muito para ver desse otimo Game...

author: {'steamid': '76561198168252341', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1814, 'last_played': 1517644256}
review:
**I highly recommend buying this game if you enjoy lone survival, simple graphics, exploration, open world and Minecraft-esk games, and purchasing when on sale**

After 24 hours of game play, I've concluded that Salt is a very enjoyable and well put together game, despite being early access. This game starts you off right away to be left up to your own devices to explore at will. Unfortunately you will be sailing alone, only meeting friendly or enemy NPS at land for now, hopefully. There is a subtle storyline, but building a basic raft and sailing away is honestly the best way to go. Lovely ambiance, pleasing graphic style and an ability to drastically alter the brightness really helps out during dark times. There's a somewhat mysterious aspect to this game, adding another level I didn‚Äôt expect and was pleased to find. There is decent amount of options for boats, clothing and weapons, along with an acceptable variation in the type of islands you can find at this point in development. Navigation is a key feature for a better enjoyment of Salt as you slowly mark out your own map as you explore, which is relatively easy to pick up with practise and the right tools. Altogether, Salt is a fun game which brings draws you back wanting to explore again and again.

It must be noted that there are a few sensitivity, smoothness and loading glitches which are expected especially when loading new areas, fighting and viewing wildlife in an early game. Occasionally islands will fail to load foliage/buildings and can be fixed either by opening your inventory, taking a screenshot or accessing the ESC menu.

Overall, a pretty enjoyable game with major potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119329916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1668781861}
review:
It has been an amazing game so far and i just got my Pirate ship which if you are looking for one i found mine on the default seed at [spoiler]5 East 2 North[/spoiler] which cost me [spoiler]10 hard wood, 40 logs, 10 cloth and 10 fibre's.[/spoiler]

This game fits my favourite genres in many ways but this is gonna be a very short review. If you do buy this game and you have a Steering wheel of some sort i made a guide here http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1193531102 which will explain how to set up a Logitech one so you can sail the seas on a racing wheel. 

Here is one thing i like and dislike about the game.

Like 

- Game has Alot and i mean alot to do for its price tag.


Dislike 

- There are no pirates roaming the seas to battle with your ships :(

10/10 will sail the seas on a Logitech Steering wheel again

author: {'steamid': '76561198097644433', 'num_games_owned': 947, 'num_reviews': 299, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1499713898}

author: {'steamid': '76561197961535587', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1501041786}
review: Keeps getting better and better as development progresses. It's a casual and very relaxing, enjoyable gaming experience that I can recommend to anyone who likes exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030869901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 9764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9612, 'last_played': 1510600856}
review:
Salt is a laid back relaxing exploration game.
I am enjoying the pace.
The sound track of birds and insects on the islands and the sounds of the waves while at sea is great.
I recomend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299226674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1521091464}
review:
Great fun little game. Well, little doesnt descibe it very well. Its huge. If you like games that throw you out into the wilderness with nothing but your wits, this is the game for you. Make your ship, navigate and chart your own maps. Write a journal about your exploits. Looking forward to future updates and what the developers will bring to the table. I would be willing to pay 30$ in current state. Will be an amazing game when complete. As of yet, I have had 0 bugs, and no crashes.

-Con- I have a pretty powerful pc and the framerate drops significantly on Ultra. Very high still looks amazing and im pushing about 90fps consistantly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052409898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1508900511}
review:
I came to buy this game because after 500 hours playing a competitor, Rising World,  I needed some combat which Rising World was sorely lacking in.  Well I sort of got that in Salt but read on because it is not the only thing I needed.

     In Salt like all survival games you start out with nothing and work your way up to building what you need for survival.  Because resources are super rare in this game you will end up exploring alot to get these items.  Exploration is very same-y because there are only 2 biomes from what i found - the lush green islands you see in the screenshots and smaller desert islands with only sand and palm trees.  
     Initially it is easier to kill isolated pirates an take their items rather than make your own.  Itemization is decent, using the classification that WoW uses with Classic Everquest type stats for weapons and armor.  It doesnt take long to get what I think is the second most powerful weapon in the game, a blue grade scimitar (I ended up with three in the first 5 hours of gameplay).  I came for the combat but the enemies consist of pirates with 3 names (fight exactly the same (chopping wood combat)) a spider, a pacifist "deer" which looks like an elk, and reports of a tiger and a spider queen I never saw.  There are quests but the only ones I found were kill x deer, kill x pirates and find location of treasure (marked by a red x on the ground). 
     Building seems to be limited to items that can be carried on the person.  I found no recipes for building a structure or base.  The only exceptions I found were the storage box (don't build this) and boats and a campfire.
     Probably the most annoying feature of this game was when I tried to use an already existing hunters perch as a base.  I built a storage box and kept my items in it as I explored the nearby area.  I managed to wipe out an island with about 20 pirates and take their loot and I put a flag atop their highest mountain to declare this base is mine.  As I explored more and more I got farther away until one point I came back and the island had been repopulated by pirates and my flag was gone.  Then I got to base and my storage box was gone with all the items I had in it.
     In my opinion Salt is not as good as other games in the survival genre and I cannot reccomend purchase at this time

author: {'steamid': '76561198067176130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1562993353}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979377093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 7395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4780, 'last_played': 1702057872}
review:
Salt has captivated me in a way few procedurally generated survival games can. I'm really quite exhausted with all the Minecraft clones and zombie games; this game is neither. It makes a wonderful blend of relaxing sailing, fascinating exploration, and... well, adequate combat. The game is not perfect, but it's a work in progress with some signs that the developers have their heads in the right place.

Things you will do in Salt:

Build rafts, boats, and ships
Sail the open seas at your leisure
Be utterly lost until you acquire a compass and/or sextant
Forage for lumber, herbs, and fruit
Mine for stone, ores, and jewels
Populate a blank sea chart with islands you've discovered
Write notes in your journal (even connect notes to your map)
Go bow hunting for deer (or perhaps more exotic game)
Go fishing
Do battle with pirates of varying title and skill
Rob the corpses of said pirates
Uncover treasures buried beneath sand, soil, and sea
Amass trinkets, tools, weapons, musical instruments, and more
Pursue an optional main quest or many side quests at your leisure

If you loved the atmosphere of games such as Monkey Island and Legend of Zelda: Windwaker, you'll probably love this game. It's your own little pirate-infested archipelago extending farther than the eye can see in every direction.

Having talked the game up, here are some negative points:

The game features blocking and parrying - features I generally like - but neither feature really feels like it has proper impact on the combat system. Blocking is generally a game of greatly reducing your aggression to anticipate and partially negate incoming damage - rarely worth it. Parrying is a game of perfectly (I do mean [i]perfectly[/i]) timing your block for the moment the enemy's weapon connects with you - maybe another 100ms of breathing room would make it something I'd be more willing to master. Mostly, I just make with the quick stabby motions of a trusty dagger and keep lots of potions and bandages on hand.


EDIT: The fishing has been improved somewhat, I believe. I'm finding fish I had only read about since the 1.9.6. update. :D The following may still apply to some degree or another, but it's improving well.

The fishing in this... maybe I just haven't discovered the little tricks to getting rarer catches. I don't know if it has one, but it needs an upper limit on wait time for catches (that or I'm just inexcusably impatient, which I may well be). Other than that, I find myself building a stockpile of varying sizes of bass, regardless of equipment, magical fishing music, or super extra special lures. The fishing questline will likely be the last one I complete, apart from perhaps the cartography questline.

The game is, as [b]Early Access[/b] should imply, still in development. From a consumer perspective, this could be a negative, yes. But if this game looks like something you'd [i]love[/i] to play in its finished form, you do the game's future a disservice by choosing against purchasing it at this early stage. Besides, it's best to air your suggestions and gripes earlier than later - you may well have some small part to play in helping to debug and shape the final product if you buy in and participate now rather than later.

In conclusion: really awesome sailing game that is super relaxing and features just enough progression, crafting, and world generation to keep you going on the same save for weeks (if your attention span is as short as mine).

author: {'steamid': '76561198018982749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1517944727}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025213720', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3084, 'last_played': 1580116486}
review:
After playing the game for a bit, I actually really appreciated the lack of instruction the game gives you. There are too many games out there that hold player's hands. In Salt, you've got just enough information to properly invest in your character and make the right decisions at the time. The world and items have depth, progress feels EARNED rather than given, which is important to me, and I feel a sense of freedom in the game that is not overshadowed by the sheer amount of open world there is.

There are repetitive parts, such as the hunting islands, pirate hunting, and treasure hunting, but these can be improved on with more content over time. The best part about this game to me is the simplicity and reliance on gameplay to feel fun, rather than strictly on graphics and effects quality. It takes me back to the gamecube era, where gameplay was the main attraction rather than cutting edge graphics.

There is a depth to the loot in the game that feels very rewarding; eventually I expect that the encounters and islands will also have some environmental depth and unpredictability to them as well, but with the options to expand my character and playstyle currently I am more than happy with what the alpha has to offer.

TLDR; it feels like a real adventure, doesn't rely on polished graphics to feel fun, and has plenty of depth and promise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986805907', 'num_games_owned': 1982, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3565, 'last_played': 1521318563}
review:
I had been debating on Salt for a long time, unsure whether I'd like it. I like sandbox games, but I prefer voxels, survival, and multiplayer. Would a game without any of that(1) be enjoyable?

TL;DR: oh hell yes.

Since buying it, I've played almost nothing else for over a week. The game's fairly slow pace and emphasis on exploration is tickling me just right. Additionally, I've been repeatedly surprised by how much *stuff* is in the game. I keep finding out that there are more items, more books, more quests, more kinds of islands, more kinds of enemies, more ships, more things to decorate my ship with...

Before buying Salt, I thought that even if I liked it, I'd reach the satiation point with it in a few hours, maybe a day, like I do with most sandbox games. But there keeps being more to do and more places to sail to do them.

This is not an action game. Don't get me wrong: your character is fairly quick on their feet, and combat can get pretty hectic if you're outmatched, but overall it's got a slow, somewhat meditative pace to things. You sail across stretches of water, setting your own course to unexplored islands or toward sunken treasure, often fishing over the side of your ship as the waves roll the deck and the sun slowly sets.

It's lovely, and relaxing, and the music is strikingly good.


(1) The developer is currently implementing cooperative multiplayer, much to my pleasure, but when I purchased the game I was unaware of that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960348789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1507069191}
review:
You cannot gather wood from trees. An overwhelming amount if crafting recipes requires wood. How do you get wood then you might ask? Wood logs are lying around, one or two per island. And hundreds of trees around you laugh in your face while you are holding an axe.

The stupidity of this concept made me uninstall and refund the game the second I became aware of it.

Do not buy. Do not support this kind of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198326952438', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1753, 'last_played': 1580751287}
review:
I honestly meant to write this once I hit the required hours to write a review [I forgot how many honestly, I don't write these often] but Salt was literally too addicting that I kept pushing it off till now.

If you really enjoy survival, crafting and sailing, this game is definitely for you. As one review put that I readd before playing 'sailing feels right', and it indeed does. Sure, at first it's a bit frustrating with the raft, but once you get the sailboat and on up, it's so relaxing. The rolling seas are also a super nice touch. Most could have made the water flat, and while it doesn't get as rough as I'd like it to, it's still fun to climb a huge wave one after the other.

Now, this game isn't exactly a triple-A or whatever the term is, so it's gonna have some flaws and such that come with it. While sailing is nice and such, combat is another feature that's just as important and to me just feels clunky and slow. It takes a bit of grinding to get a goodd weapon, but once you're set, you're more than good to go. 

At this point, there's still some bugs, and as much as I'd recommend the game I'd like to warn that at this point and time that's to be expected. The only one I've really dealt with was teleportation and put twice as far away from my original destination while sailing, into a zone where enemies were above my level, so to speak. 

One thing that I initially didn't enjoy but have come to love, is mapping. I'm sure that most players might not enjoy it but who knows. In order to map the world, you need a sextant and compass. Using co-ordinates given to you, you take out your map and "draw" the map in the alloted co-ordinate square. It is a bit annoying at times but it gives something to do when you're sailing on your way to somewhere. I would also call finding someone to sell stuff to a con, but sometimes you end up finding someone to sell to just when you're about to give up.

Regardless, this game is worth both buying on sale and full price, I never thought I'd have so much fun with it honestly.

So to recap, pros and cons:

PROS:
Sailing is very relaxing.
Crafting is fairly easy.
Gathering materials at first is [relatively] easy.
Looting enemies is sorta fun.
Large inventory space.

CONS:
Clunky combat.
Clearing islands of enemies in order to open chests, it gets a bit difficult after half an hour to searching to find that one last enemy.

Also, I hope to see maybe the ability to build stuff on islands, maybe making little forward-operating bases for yourself, places to store stuff for later maybe. This game honestly needs and deserves the love that the dev's have shown  it and it only continues to improve as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074918980', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1601356452}
review:
It's oddly immersive for what it is.  Sailing alone on the ocean, you can practically feel the spray of the waves.  Walking along the shore, you can feel the sun hot sun on your back.  Walking through the woods, you feel the leaves and trees.

Again.  It's odd how immersive this game is.  Perhaps the low-poly/texture graphics leave a lot to the imagination.

It's a nice, relaxing game.

(The only part that isn't immersive is the pirates and NPCs.  They're pretty cheesy :) )

author: {'steamid': '76561198037452755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2127, 'last_played': 1612102806}

author: {'steamid': '76561198072420341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1506978064}
review:
I cannot in good conscience recommend this game in its current state. I bought it on sale (thankfully) the other day, and have spent a little over 2 hours in the game, not a significant amount of time, but enough to get an idea of how it is. 
[list]
[*]The game has little to no explanation of what you need to do. 
[*]The controls are quite bad in certain aspects.
[*]The crafting system is *okay*, but needs work.
[*]The environmental affects make it very difficult, and awkward to see at certain times (lighting effects, etc)
[*]The map system does not make any sense to me at all
[*]The Audio is bizarre, no music of any kind for long periods of time, kicks in randomly and stops aburptly
[*]Buggy saves.
[/list]

I'm probably missing some things, but these are what come to mind. I realize this is early access, and it may get better down the road, but at this point it is definitely not worth its current price, even on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981698816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1746, 'last_played': 1512627230}
review:
It may look cheap or even a little cheesy. ‚ÄúOh yawn, it's cartoony pirate survival.‚Äù 

It's efficient use of drive space might seem to imply simplicity or lack of effort. ‚ÄúHoly crap, only 653M?‚Äù

But the beaches are sunny enough to compel immersion, the adventures are interesting enough to compel completion, and the Caribbeanesque ocean is downright muy bueno. Given the size and scope of this game, I think it would be unreasonable to ask for waves interactive enough to buffet your boat and force you to steer into them, but you can see them rolling and even find yourself in the bottom of a proper trough. And since I keep finding my boats up on the land, I'm assuming there is a tide happening. Outstanding work on that water, dev team. Salt is a pleasure to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101039258', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1536937225}
review:
I've had a fair amount of time to explore, fight and sail and I have to say this game is so much deeper than I gave it credit for. The very act of sailing is deceptively simple, just point your boat and go, but then there's the act of going back to an island for a quest which requires genuine planning.

1. You need a Sextant to know exactly where you are in the world.

This is an easy tool to use. Just hotkey it and press the button and voila, you now know the grid your in. Go to your map and locate said grid and mark it with an island if your on one, otherwise leave it blank.

2. A compass to make sure your going in the right direction but the compass is a little weird. 

If you want to go North-West then make sure the red arrow is pointing north-east and the white arrow is pointing south-west, think of it as North and West with the white arrow being your East-West bearing and the red arrow being the North-South bearing. Once I figured that out, it was smoother sailing.

3. Understand that the map does NOT automatically update!

Make sure you know how to work the map grids and how to document an islands location and you won't get lost. It's immensely satisfying to see your map grow and to find your way back from a long journey. 

Sadly it has one big bad point. aside from being the best way to travel, sailing is boring. The devs have hinted to spicing up the ocean with roaming pirates and I hope that means ship to ship cannon battles and even some more dangers like sea monsters but that depends on whether or not the game is going to be realistic.

The main source of content is on islands. Islands however are fun, they allow you to collect resources and gather food for long journeys. You can also hunt, fish, barter, quest and play music (like buffing yourself) as well as document key features on an island to your map such as pirate activity, hunting potential, dangerous creatures, hut locations and so on so forth.

Again, sailing is boring but at the same time it's not awful. It works well and can be fun on short journey's but the ocean needs more activity aside from fishing. I hope we get cannon battles, I really do...

author: {'steamid': '76561198001969789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1506861508}
review: Played for 2 hours, got bugged, couldn's save, progress lost, uninstalled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001794713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 427, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1506878443}
review:
I absolutely cant understand the very positive rating. Salt comes off as one of these quickly put together unity example games, to show you how your first survival game might look like.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

+ I was thinking way too long for any positives....there is nothing worth mentioning

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- the graphics look bare bones, I knew that from the screenshots before of course, but ingame it comes off even more bland

- the world is bland and boring, every island you visit feels the same, there might be the occasional hut or a ruin, but thats it, its boring

- for a game that revolves around water so much, the ocean is completely empty.....no flora and fauna whatsoever

- crafting is a big thing in survival games and yet again this game is god awful in that aspect, you cant gather wood with tools you have to collect wood off the ground which goes against every survival instinct and the wood is rare to find, at least in my playtime I encountered almost none of it, there are multiple stone types you can collect and the one that is used in most recipes, is the most rare one......even for basic things like arrows or a campfire you cant find the ingredients...or at least its way too frustrating

- combat is a joke, you literally just stand with a pirate and hit then block, hit then block and exchange that in a slow comedic way.....

- the sailing is not fun at all, it only draggs out the game by a lot. The ocean water is completely flat, there are no waves to battle or manouver around storms or something like that, its like sailing in a big hotel swimming pool

- there is no real need for a food meter, as it doesnt add anything to the game, is this a survival game? Yes? then why cant I chop down trees to make a fire. Is it an exploration game? Okay, then why keep me busy instead with hunger.....

- there are quests in the game, but I would hardly call them quests as they are so mondane and boring

- everything is presented to you in text form, you find books and literally have to read like 4 pages of a book to get some quest information, I didnt like that at all, I dont mind reading, but here it was way too often and way too long


Dont tell me this is just an early access game and its going to get better. Salt is in early access since 2014, the boring and bland core gameplay is not going to change. I dont know why people would put hundreds of hours in this game, when there are so many better survival/exploration games out there.
Subnautica costs 5 bucks more and is so much better and richer in gameplay. Cant recommend Salt at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260930680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1051, 'last_played': 1660344508}
review: 20 out of 10 This game is AMAZING! i love it. There is so much sea to explor and with every update there is more content and its only getting better. Salt is definetly worth the your money. However if you like fast paced action or a huge story line salt lacks in thoes aspects. It has pleny of room for a story in the future and there are a few goals/side quests (no main quest) but you get a more free felling during game play with out one. and there is combat if you know where and win to find it. Any way the reason i love this game is becuas after rocket leauge or CS:GO when your raging or just tired of to much compitition you can come play salt and enjoy yourself a little.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969571435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1506766221}
review:
I'd give the game right now a solid 61%. 
A positive rating-ish mark.

Reminds me of the game Unturned in the very beginning, right now its extremely simplistic in everything. The sound is pretty basic, the atmosphere is very generic, the island buildings and generation is very simplistic, graphics are pretty simplistic, advancing is slow and annoying, the map feature is cool but also really annoying at the same time, and there's all sorts of things that make this game just a very basic shell at the moment.

With time I hope it evolves into something more.

There's a couple things that really bother me
- The gathering system sucks.
- You can't cut trees yet they are everywhere?! 
- Everytime you shoot a deer they run across the island.
- The brightness. Oh. My. God. 
- Not enough islands. 
- Islands that are impossible to walk across because they're just a series of mountain tops.
- Way too grindy for everything.

I mean, it's an early access game, this is to be expected. I like the game. I just might have to wait 6-12 months before I continue playing because there's so much that needs to be done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014896114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1506740166}
review:
I'm sorry, but no.....
Get ready folks, I do not rant and this is a long one, about *A* thing that made me return the game.
Got this game on sale for $5 and as much as I feel like a d*ck for saying this, but it is not worth it. Do not get me wrong, I definitely think there is more than $5 worth of content but oh man the game doesn't feel even at 15% completion. It feels like a pre-pre-pre-alpha where developers are saying "ok as you can see, we will have land here, and NPCs will stand over here" etc. I probbaly would have even kept the game (I mean honestly it's cheaper than a movie) but this one.....annoying thing..: When you are walking through an island/land birds will chirp. Sounds good right?...well, in this case, you know that buzzing sound you have when you are playing a track/song on *loud* but there is this silence with the electric buzzing in the background, that crackles and gives off static sound when you connect or disconnect your headphones or speakers? That's exactly how the birds make them selves known in this game: crackling connect/disconnect sound, speaker buzz, birds, speaker buzz, connect/disconnect sound. It's not even for the fact that it breaks imersion when that comes on, you seriously do not think about it that way....but it is strictly because that buzzing and crackling annys the crap out of you. Its makes you feel as if you are on the phone menu and there is a button you can not skip, so you mentally make the " *sigh* T_T really?" face while you wait through it. In fact, it literally made me want to rush through an island and GTFO outta there as fast as I could. The game also feels dead and completely lifeless. I kept playing thinking maybe if I go deeper it will get better, but no. Returned the game, even if it was $5, because I was more annoyed than bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198311365060', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 7832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3430, 'last_played': 1667071567}
review:
tl:dr - Cool game, but really its an RPG with ship elements in it. If you're looking for on-the-sea action, get Sea of Thieves. I really enjoy this game, but there are a few things I wish were different about it. Also, Salt 2 is in the works I believe, so I'd just wait for that.

Pros
It's just not what I originally thought it was. Seeing as it was early access, I assumed there would be much content to be added, and there was. 

To start there were ships, pirates, treasure, exploring, etc. I expected that they would eventually add more pirate-like things, such as naval battles, merchants traveling by sea, and a crew. None of this was added, however, and most of the content was angled toward exploration. 

Salt is definitely more of a game in which you explore the world, looking for islands and becoming the strongest adventurer. I have to admit I was a little disapointed when I saw that this game came out of early access and generally, no more content was to be added. 

This game also got quite boring doing the same thing repetitively- explore, fight get loot, repeat.
-Can get repetitive
-No naval battles
-No more content being added

Pros
This game has TONS of items to collect and use. It also has many sidequests as well as a mainquest to follow. There are also boss fights, and mini boss fights, such as fighting pirate captains on their island, or island challenges where you have to destroy all pirates or animals on an island. The way you explore in Salt also is pretty fun. There aren't pirates at sea or massive waves or anything, but the game really has a lot to it. The game also has various NPCs that you can trade with and get sidequests from. Salt really has a lot of content to it.
-Bosses
-Island Challenges
-Tons of items
-Quests
-Exploring
-NPCs
-Trading
-Treasure to find

Conclusion
I honestly think this is a pretty fun game, and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys sailing around, exploring, doing quests, or really anything that anyone enjoys doing or having in a game in the Pros list above. I wouldn't recommend it to people who are hoping for exciting naval battle action as it's really more of an RPG with tiers of weapons, armor, loot, and sidequests. Sadly, there is no more content being put out for this game, though the company is working on a new game called "Wild West and Wizards," which should be pretty cool. It also seems that there is going to soon be a Salt 2, so if you want to wait for the (hopefully) superior version, I'd wait for that. Thanks for reading!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008560932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1599675300}
review:
****EDIT

Good news, the developers have indeed fixed the game breaking bug. The game still has a quiet, tedious charm to it that may not fit most peoples' fancy. A lot of mundane game play for those who enjoy a grind. I still haven't played quite enough for a full review, but at least the developers are listening. Cheers.

**Original Review**

I enjoyed this game for a short time.  It doesn't hold your hand.  You learn as you go and it's a neat concept moving from island to island.  There is a lot to explore, but islands can be rather empty and boring.  There's not much in the realm of building, besides ships.  You can't just chop down trees and dig, this is not a minecraft-like game.  Combat is underwhelming.

Here's the big problem with the game: there's a game-breaking bug that can take your mediocre experience and drop it into the abyss.  Sometimes, your boat may fly into the air.  Once it sails into the heavens, you can't get it back.  Even destroying and replacing the boat seems to continue to launch it into the heavens.  In other words: no more moving island to island--the whole damn point of the game.  I had this happen a mere 2 hours into the game.  It has happened twice and the only solution is to start over.  In a game where I already find little attachment, a game breaking bug is the deal breaker.  This game is hard to like, and this bug makes it easy to uninstall.  I'm dissapointed, consider it has a positive following.  However, I don't understand why it has a postive following--I couldn't enjoy it no matter how hard I tried to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000538414', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 3236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3158, 'last_played': 1505511615}
review:
I'm still on my survival/crafting kick so I picked up a game called Salt. I guess it's called that because this game is full of islands and pirates; well land based pirates at least. Though there are a variety of ships, I've never seen another soul on the water.

This game has a lot more loot variety than most of the others; not including 7D2D. You have several types of armor, weapons, and accessories. I haven't needed to build a base yet, so I'm not sure if that's a thing.

Unlike the other games, Salt is populated. There are merchants, pirates, inns, etc. However, they are spread out amongst hundreds of islands, so you might not see anyone at all or a small handful depending on the island size and the resources.

Combat is with other humans/ mostly pirates and cultists. There are no wolves, bears, etc. You can swim a long ways too, though even a raft is much faster. I found an abandoned pirate ship, repaired it, and now I ply the waters in style. It seems weird to control a 60' long ship by myself though‚Ä¶.

Food has to be scavenged and is always low. Trees bear fruit and deer are plentiful but shy easy so killing one takes patience. It is unlikely that you will make a clean kill with one shot, so you'll be chasing them down. A head/neck shot does massive damage though so you might get lucky. The flee AI for deer is great. You won't guess which way they'll run unless you box them in somewhere.

The map has to be populated by you. It's just a blank sheet of graph paper with longitude and latitude marks. You can find or make a sextant and compass to help with this and you can also WRITE NOTES on it. How nice that someone finally got this. It's so nice to be able to write stuff down. Things like "chest I couldn't open in nw corner of the island at 5E 12N, etc. I don't mind maps that hold your hand but sometimes it is quite fun to do your own. Note that there are several markers ready made for the islands too.

There are lots of chests, buried treasure, ancient ruins, etc. Exploration is HUGE in this game.

While there is no multiplayer just yet, it is in the workings. The author wants some form of multiplayer because they're going to add cannon to the bigger ships and then you'll be able to have ship to ship battles in multiplayer. For us single-player folks the cannon can take out shore-wandering pirates and deer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140394739', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1555913403}
review:
It's like someone took all the depth and art out of Legend of Zelda Windwaker and replaced it with basic crafting and okay FPS mechanics. I think I honestly enjoyed watching lets plays of this game more than I enjoyed playing it, because I found the hunt for logs tedius and staying fed more difficult than I expected, maybe its because the bow mechanics felt a bit wonky and I couldn't kill dear all that effectively. 

Overall its a peaceful and beautiful world that, like many of these island sims, still lacks depth. If the game had co-op I would see it being a lot more fun, running around with a friend, clubbing pirates for their booty. But as it stands, to me, the game feels empty and a lil lonely. If I could give this a see for yourself I would because the price is good, and the visuals are good, but since I'm forced to take a hard stance, I'm not so much going to say "DON'T PLAY THIS GAME, " but I will instead recommend checking out the HD remake of of Windwaker if you have a WII U. That game has gorgous cell shading, and island after handcrafted island thats interesting to explore and really cool bosses, instead of what you get with this game... Islands, many of which are really similar in appearance and combat/survival mechanics that don't feel balanced yet. 

Hopefully more will be added, escpecially in terms of cool bosses, but I' m not 100% educated on the world generation, so IDK if thats even a viable option, or if all that effort will be literally lost at sea to most players.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972271775', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 3675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3669, 'last_played': 1542515694}
review:
Already a ton of reviews. instead of a review I would rather type out a wishlist.  

1) Ships. The entire game is based around ships. It is your home, your transportation, and your storage box. We need more ships, loads more ships. Both crafting and littered to be commandeered, We need ship upgrades. Not more box types or beds but structure upgrades. Better sails, rudders, paints, material types, stats. Ships need a lot more love. We need ship battles. We should be battling AI long before multiplayer is released. This should be implemented in prep for PVP and ship to ship combat in general before Multiplayer is even a forethought. I mean seriously what are you going to do with a friend? Pick up logs together? LOL. Ships, need a lot of love in this area.

2) Islands. the only thing more detrimental than the ship is the islands. We need more, we need a lot more types. Volcanic, tidal, barrier, coral, and mix the lot. We need something to enter. As it stands there is what.. 3 buildings that you can enter? So basically most islands are barron flat ~ surfaces you walk around on to pick up logs. That is not really an adventure is it? We need ruins, I don't mean more columns stuck on the ground. I mean Aztec empires long lost. Cave systems, Beached ships, ghost towns, abandoned villages, we need something to explore. Something that tells a story without a quest, think Roanoke Island. 

3) Danger. We need threat. As it stands I have a better chance of finding end game loot than dieing. Sharks.. seriosly, it's the ocean, think about it. Bears, boars, snakes, Long forgotten traps. We need a sense of danger, a threat. 


My opinion of the game as it is. Definitly a lot of time and love has gone into this. The devs seem to communicate and listen. The game is definitly headed down a good road. Updates are pretty regular and usually pretty good sized. Honestly, the game is boring as it stands. Don't get me wrong, fun on that first run but it don't take long to see that massive hole in content. It don't take long to realize you will be staring at the same four or five islands for hours and hours. If you buy the game, buy it to play threw once and shelve it. It has a long way to go. Multiplayer is not going to be a saving grace. Instead of one person board out of his mind now you have two people picking up logs on the same map. This is going to be a great game if the Devs see it threw. My opinion anyway. As it stands, not yet.

Edit 07/09/18
Fixed Your you're, thanks :)

So it looks like the Dev team has called it complete. Other than a few patches, it's done. For five bucks? Absolutely worth it. You will get a few hours out of it. Unfortunately my entire wish list still stands. 

 It's my understanding the Devs are moving forward on another project. 
Based on Salt I am looking forward to see what they dream up next. I feel Salt was a leaning tool for them and from here their games will only get better!

author: {'steamid': '76561198124041298', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 8649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7978, 'last_played': 1543472549}
review:
I have been playing this for a long time now, its sorta my comfort game at this point. Very chill, and being as I have watched this game from the update just before the ship redesign up to now I might as well toss my two cents in.

1. Graphics: The graphics in this game are very simplistic, that doesn't mean they are bad graphics, they are fantastic as they are and despite the minimal design they really add to the games charm.

2. Gameplay: The gameplay here is fairly good, the combat system has been polished somewhat but it does still need a bit of work. Sailing is absolutely fantastic, it makes you feel like a true sailor to go across the sea with compass in hand and consulting your personally drawn map.

3. Nitpicks: These are pretty much the only things I could find that bother me, you can probably disregard them as personal preference or nitpicking...
The first issue most people will have is that multiplayer does not exist yet, the devs have stated that they will not add multiplayer untill most of the big updates are finished, so fear not! It will come soon. I would recommend buying a couple copies for when it does come out.

The second issue I have is that the storage systems are incredibly expensive. You find so much loot in this game, and while the inventory is practically bottomless, it is nice to have chests marked out for where you want your booty to be stored (Arr), however a chest costs 6 hardstone to make (which I barely ever find), and 6 iron(Nearly impossible to find) if you want a decent chest. Crates are cheap but they have like... 5 slots, certainly not enough space to store all your ill gotten gains. Some cheaper alternatives would be fantastic.

Besides that, I must have gotten pretty lucky with most of the early access titles I have been following, because this game not only has potential, but I belive that it could be one of my all time favorites when its done.

I give this a 9/10, seriously, buy a couple copies, save the extras for your friends when multiplayer comes out, and in the meanwhile get on a ship and start exploring! Arr!

Edit: It has been a few years, multiplayer is out now, the game is still just as enjoyable as I say it is. However, the Dev's stopped updating the game, no more things are being added to the game. Unless moddability is perhaps brought into the game as of right now it just has exactly what I say it has, and nothing more.

If you are okay with that (I certainly still am, I come back to it all the time) than please, by all means buy this game, I would reccomend it at any price you are most comfortable with, I don't hold it against the company that they would turn away from this game to move on to greater things. It is a good game to wind down, with a bottle of rum. I am changing my review to 7/10, still highly reccomend, but its not going anywhere else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049209780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1517, 'last_played': 1569544837}
review:
This is one of the most beautiful, enjoyable and pleasant open worlds I ever played.

I played the version 1.8.0 before, and now I'm progressing through v. 1.9.5 . The developers have added many new features and improved a lot the visuals of the islands and NPCs. Even without the soon-to-be-implemented clouds, the skydome is amazing. The sunrise and sunsets are breath-taking, and also is the night sky full of stars. To my surprise, the game has included tides, working synchronously with moon phases. I must say that, as someone from Brazil, and now living abroad, this game truly makes me fell at home somethings. Specially when contemplating distant islands from beachs during the sunsets.

With new lore flashed out through books, enemies, dialogs and events the randomly generated worlds of salt seems much more consistent now. The developer have also added new items and bosses, which keep making you wish to explorer outward.

For future updates, I wish that the islands get more populated and the NPCs acting more lively. I'm eager to see other boats trading from island to island, even if they are just following a programmed track. I'd also like to find actual villages or cities of friendly NPCS; different tribes (firendly or hostile) with languages we must decipher to comunicate.
Likewise, I hope that oceans also get more populated with sharks, whales, storms and currents.

Besides all updates we're still going to get in the future, I already recomend it for anyone as a very good game the way it now is.

review:
Que 4 heures de jeu, mais je suis enthousiasm√©... Bien plus √©volu√© en l'√©tat actuel que ce qu'en pr√©sentent les vid√©os francophones sur YouTube. 
Et l√©ger avec √ßa, que √ßa en tourne nickel (juste de rares bizarret√©s plus marrantes qu'autre chose :  Premi√®re nuit sur le bateau, premier plumard : au r√©veil, perso' et bateau envoy√©s en l'air, pour retomber de tr√®s tr√®s  haut dans la flotte - Tu parles d'un r√©veil ! : M√™me Bobonne l'aurait pas invent√© - trop g√©nial, le gag du lit-catapulte ! - Me dites pas que c'est  un bug... Serais d√©√ßu.)
Prise en main relativement facile, un univers et une ambiance-son des plus sympathiques, du loot √† foison, un craft qui m'a l'air pas mal et qui va s'√©toffer au fil des d√©couvertes... Que du bon ! Seul probl√®me, pour barrer le radeau, il faut tourner le dos √† la proue, mais d√®s le second bateau, c'est r√©gl√©, puisqu'on dispose d'une roue de gouvernail.
L√©g√®rement emb√™tant aussi : m√™me de jour, si on veut distinguer les d√©tails des sous-bois, on a int√©r√™t √† jouer avec la luminosit√©, mais comme on y acc√®de rapidement, en cours de jeu, par un simple ESC ou, plus direct, la lettre O, c'est pas trop g√™nant... 
A part ces petites contrari√©t√©s, je me r√©p√®te, mais que du plaisir ! M√™me avec ses pirates et de rares b√©b√™tes pas sympathiques, √ßa reste un jeu hyper-cool, une occasion de pure d√©tente ludique sans prise de t√™te.
Quant √† l'interface, quelque peu d√©routante au d√©part, elle est de fait tr√®s bien con√ßue, quoique l'inventaire devienne, apr√®s moultes trouvailles, quelque peu bord√©lique. Heureusement il y a une barre d'acc√®s rapide 10 emplacements (faut cocher la case dans les options) : clic droit maintenu et chiffre, de 1 √† 0 pour attribuer... 
Autre truc : apr√®s on dispose d'objets √† placer (lit, portraits, bras√©ro, supports de torche, etc ) qu'on peut r√©cup√©rer par un "E" maintenu.
Et oui, d√®s qu'on a un bateau avec cabine, on peut l'am√©nager et disposer d'un lit : plus de bois √† gaspiller pour les feux de camp ! 3√®me type de bateau : le bateau de pirate - un deux mats -, qu'on trouve g√©n√©ralement aux extr√©mit√©s d'une carte, et qu'on peut r√©parer : 40 bois + 10 bois durs + 8 cloth swatch (craftables √† partir de fibres v√©g√©tales) + 10 plant fibers (craftables √† partir de bambou) - Je le signale pour vous permettre de vous y pr√©parer, puisqu'on ne conna√Æt la recette (clic sur le poste de gouverne) qu'en trouvant l'√©pave -. Des bateaux plus √©volu√©s existent, mais il faut en trouver les plans...
Des mat√©riaux de construction √† partir de pierre et de bambous sont craftables aussi... Le craft semble tr√®s riche, mais on y acc√®de lentement - surtout quand on ne sait s'orienter, et qu'on compl√®te / rend les qu√™tes "au petit bonheur la chance"...

Un petit conseil en passant : D√®s que vous avez le bateau de pirate, gardez n√©anmoins le deuxi√®me bateau en tant que canot. Pourquoi ? parce que la nage fatigue √©norm√©ment et qu'aborder une √Æle avec une endurance √† 0, c'est pas l'id√©al...; d'autre part, un gros bateau est bien moins manoeuvrable, surtout dans un groupe d'√Ælots. Plus  pratique d'amener votre canot √† proximit√© et de sauter √† l'eau - Variante : √† partir du canot, g√©n√©rer le gros bateau ("B") au plus proche.
Un autreconseil : parsemez votre bateau principal de torches (qui durent √©ternellement), y compris dans la mature et le pont inf√©rieur - Vous le rep√©rerez de loin -. Pour fixer la torche  ("T") sur le porte-torche (1 ironite), "E" non maintenu.

A quand une traduction fran√ßaise ? - Parce que si l'anglais ne d√©range pas trop dans le jeu et pour le craft, pour les bouquins √† lire et les qu√™tes, c'est quand m√™me assez frustrant... - l'occasion peut-√™tre de m'acheter un dico' et  de r√©actualiser, voire d'√©toffer mes maigres r√©minescences, le jeu ayant de rares dialogues et un rythme cool qui permettrait ais√©ment la chose...

Personnellement, j'ai pas encore pig√© la fa√ßon de me servir de la carte... (quel rapport journal, onglet Map, et carte ?) Si quelqu'un a compris et peut m'expliquer en bon fran√ßais... (?)

J'ai commenc√© √† r√©diger cette √©valuation il n'y a pas trois jours, apr√®s 4 heures de jeu; ce soir, j'en suis √† 48 heures (non ! 58,3 - eeeuh...) et viens de l'√©toffer / rectifier... Oui, je sais... 
M'en fous ! M'amuse.

Tr√®s tr√®s prometteur ce Salt...! Un petit bijou √† la fois de simplicit√© de conception et de richesse de fond : √ßa change agr√©ablement. Et on ne le soup√ßonnerait jamais, mais qu'est-ce qu'il peut √™tre  riche en contenu, ce jeu !

Remarque Mac Sierra : √† la r√©attribution des touches (pr√©vues qwerty), l'√©cran plante syst√©matiquement...; le jeu est cependant jouable, mais en qwerty. Par contre, aucun probl√®me sous Win10

Je reprends en janvier 2018 et - d√©ception ! - Le jeu n'a gu√®re √©volu√©... Je me serais attendu √† voir l'artisanat d√©velopp√© (construction, terrassement, cuisine, etc) , mais non ! On a maintenant le sempiternel mode multijoueur qui attire les foules avides de baston, fi√©vreuses de d√©molir ce qu'un autre a laborieusement construit...

De nouvelles MaJ r√©guli√®res apportent un plus non n√©gligeable : les pirates et leur coffre sont enfin signal√©s par un petit point √† peine perceptible (orange - bleu) qui s'agrandit en approchant (surtout utilisable la nuit - gaffe aux araign√©es ! - Donc fini de chercher des jours de jeu durant le ou les derniers pirates manquant pour ouvrir le coffre. De m√™me pour le gibier pris en chasse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030754853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 5536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5480, 'last_played': 1574311622}
review: I've put several dozen hours into Salt, and I'm still hard pressed to say why I like it. I guess there's just something deeply compelling about its cycles of presence and absence. It's a game of lush islands separated by vast expanses of blue, of intense action separated by hours of stillness, of gorgeous musical vignettes separated by long, lonely stretches of ambient quiet. It sounds dull (and it can be at times) but it fosters a sense of anticipation you rarely get in modern games. When you add that to its masterfully realized sense of place, its enormous scale, and its weird, wonky beauty, you end up with a game that's pretty epic.
